EDIT: As of the most recent patch, max game timer has been raised from 60m to 90m thanks to feedback.

Like many similar games that support matchmaking, the timers are oppressive when it comes to making fully informed decisions, particularly as a newer player, and particularly when there's so much more to process here than most. There's little hope of me ever touching matchmaking, and I say that as someone who would like to play against more than bots.

But unlike many similar games, it is possible to play Co-Op/Solo vs AI, and some effort has been made to keep this experience varied - at least until you reach an intermediate level of play and have to play against bots with massive +income advantages, which encourages cheesy play to counter. However, the ability to pause the timer freely in PvE makes up for a lot, so long as you're not taking over [strike]an hour[/strike] 90m total to play a game typically meant to take 20-25m. The server will disconnect you with little warning if you're as reliant on pausing as I am and don't know about the [strike]hour[/strike] 90m limit.

There is 90 seconds of setup time, then a game flow of variable time battles -> placement (typically 20-30s, with extra on one specific turn to choose a bonus spell) -> repeat. During this time, one must evaluate how to spend two different-yet-related currencies, evaluate the lanes of other players to know when/how to attack/defend them, and calculate placement locations for an increasingly complex board state, without extra allotted time to do so. In fact, the game's economy is linked to real time, with your primary currency-generating unit generating currency-per-10s. Instead of them generating more over a longer time, they generate faster over the same time in later waves.

If you're not willing to do significant out-of-game study akin to a MOBA or RTS, you'll be at a huge disadvantage when it comes to the timers, and that's if you don't have APM limitations like I do.

So, its only a PvE game for me, but there's enough meat to the PvE that by the time I'm stuck playing against heavily handicapped bots, I'll have gotten my money's worth. And that's fine, but add this to a growing list of games I wish I could play PvP in that aren't tailored to slower play.

If you ever played Legion or Squadron or any of the other WC3/SC/SC2 PvP tower defense games then you are quite literally guarantee'd to love this.

It is the apotheosis of all those custom games wished to achieve.

There is no competition in this very specific genre that gets even close.

They consistently patch for both QoL and meta adjustment.

Buy this game immediately.

Insanely toxic community (might as well just mute if you're going to MP), and while the solo play is relatively fun in the beginning the devs have employed the 'AI cheat' method to the harder AI difficulties which means your skill stops mattering at a certain point and it mostly boils down to luck with whether or not your AI teammate is going to screw it up or not.

UPDATE 2: 400+hrs in and not slowing down. New season came out and the game's in a really great spot - highly recommend checking it out.

UPDATE: I've now played for close to 100 hours. If Lost Ark hadn't come out around the time I started I would probably be at 200+hrs. It's quickly become one of my staples and I see myself playing it for a while. 

This game has an insane amount of depth and keeps me wanting to play more. There are so many things to manage and keep an eye on that the game never feels boring. The devs are also super active and constantly trying to improve the game. 

I like to compare the knowledge aspect of this game to Starcraft 2. I've always wanted to play Starcraft 2, but the sheer amount of information needed is so intimidating that I didn't have the drive to pick it up. LTD2 has a nice balance in that regard. You will have to work at this game if you want to keep playing. Luckily, the community is very welcoming and always ready to help new players out. The casual game mode is also a lot of fun and a good way to get a feel for the units/mechanics. They have comprehensive charts and graphs of every aspect of the game so you're able to go back and review why the game turned out how it did. There is certainly a learning curve, but if you can get past that you'll feel yourself improving each match. 

If you're looking for a strategy game that will take some studying but not so much that it's intimidating, I'd highly recommend giving LTD2 a chance.
Active dev team, fun strategic game play in deciding what units to use, how to position, when to build income etc. Great balance and always more to learn.

If you're a fan of the Tower Defense genre you should definitely get this game.

I'll start with the gameplay, all the units have their specific purpose in the game and while RNG appears in various aspects of the game (not only what units you get to use for a match but also things like AoE having random secondary targets) you have control of your lane and your placement and economic decisions will always be the most impactful factor in how the game turns out.
The UI looks very clean and there are tons of tools for learning more about the mechanics with statistics and metrics that measure your gamestyle (do you play agressive and try to leak ennemies or do you focus on income and holding for example).

In terms of the community, the devs are awesome the game is regularly updated/patched with both new content and balance changes, the in-game shop is purely cosmetic and provides no gameplay advantage and you can easily earn both the free currency and paid currency by playing the game (joining a guild helps with the paid currency). What I like the most is that they're actively trying to improve the game and involve the community.
Some players complain about toxicity and bad apples do exist but I rarely find anyone with malicious intent. There are pings that facilitate strategizing with your teammate without having to type so language barriers are not a problem.

TLDR; It's a very good game made with a lot of passion, just buy it it's good.

Super fun game with a small but active community. The devs really took the spirit of the old original WC3 map and enhanced it beautifully.

Ranked mode can be a little intimidating at first and the game does have somewhat of a steep learning curve, but it's worth it. Every game feels different. There are also casual modes and a really well-done singleplayer mode that they put a lot of love in.

Frequent updates and the game feels very well balanced and allows for different playstyles unless you play at the highest rankings, but this is pretty much normal in any competitive game.

Free to play with a fairly priced cosmetic shop - just hop in and try it out, especially if you played Legion TD on WC3 back in the day. I really have nothing negative to say about this game.

I used to play Legion TD back in Warcraft 3 when I was a kid. It's nice to see that the devs from the original mod have continued. It's awesome that they're doing indie development now, and I really love the game.

I have a lot of fond memories and nostalgia for those old days. I love to see concepts from those days updated and evolved over time! I always thought, when I was a kid, that those custom games were super sophisticated and fun, and it's nice to see that even as adults and as an independent game, this complex and rewarding game is continuing to evolve and entertain thousands of people across the world.

I think some of the updates from the original are amazing, and I'll outline them below:
- Different game modes can be accessed in the lobby, which is obviously a major UI improvement over the original mod.
- The graphics and models are also a lot better than the old mod
- The game is as new player friendly as it could possibly be, given how punishing this game can be for new players. There are prompts suggesting which units to buy, auto-send, roll recommendations, and more that make it easy for new and returning players to pick it back up.

Generally, I'm just impressed with the continued development for this game. I wish that more devs from those devs would come back to make their own games. They probably are, but I want to see some of those old favorite custom maps come back with new updated games of their own like Legion TD.

Steam Review: Buckle up, buttercup, for a review that's as spicy as Legion TD's late-game waves.

Imagine a tower defense game with the attention span of a goldfish and the strategic depth of a black hole. That's Legion TD. Matches are shorter than a TikTok dance, meaning you can squeeze them in between loading screens, bathroom breaks, and existential breakdowns. Perfect for filling those awkward silences in your Discord calls when everyone's pretending to be AFK.

Here's the deal: you plop down towers, they shoot stuff, you win (or cry, depending on your opponent's RNG). It's about as simple as tying your shoes, except with less frustration and fewer laces to trip over. But don't let the ease fool you. This game has more layers than an ogre's onion, with enough unit combinations and strategies to keep even the most jaded tower defense veteran entertained.

Plus, it's the size of a hamster on a diet. Takes up barely any space on your hard drive, which is crucial in these days of AAA games that require you to mortgage your firstborn just to download. This bad boy runs on a potato powered by hopes and dreams.

Pros:

Matches shorter than your attention span: Perfect for the ADHD gamer in all of us.
Easy to learn, hard to master: Starts simple, then kicks you in the shins with strategic depth.
Fills those awkward gaming lulls: Like a digital fidget spinner, but with more explosions.
Tiny download size: Doesn't hog your precious storage space.
Community surprisingly chill: No screaming kids or salty tears, just good ol' fashioned tower defense smackdown.
Cons:

RNG can be a brutal mistress: Sometimes the dice hate you, and that's okay. Just blame the dice, not your lack of skill (like I do).
Learning curve can be steep: Don't expect to be a tower defence Einstein overnight. Be prepared to get stomped... a lot.
Can be addictive: Just one more match, I swear...
Overall: Legion TD is like a delicious slice of pizza: quick, satisfying, and leaves you wanting more. It's not gourmet, but it hits the spot every time. So go forth, ye brave tower defenders, and conquer those waves (or die trying). Just remember, the only thing smaller than the download size is your margin for error.

Rating: 9/10 would recommend (but maybe not to my therapist).

This game is great. Features 2v2 ranked mode or 4v4 classic mode. The goal of the game is to build towers to fight off waves of enemies (wave 1 through to 21) and defend your king. You also have the ability to generate a resource known as mythium, which you use to purchase mercenaries to attack the other team's towers and then hopefully their king. Whichever team's king dies first, loses. This game has an enormous amount of depth, and just keeps getting better as you play it more. Great to play solo or with friends.

I spent plenty of hours playing this game, unfortunately I have to give a thumbs down because i'm a casual player and they ignore the Classic mode problems. In Classic, you can opt/vote for Income and Chill every game, which of course everyone votes for every time.. this 'bonus' to the Classic mode forces you to spend all your mythium every round and then you receive bonus gold. They recently added Bankers which benefit from that particular game mode by an inordinate amount - specifically because of this "income and chill" functionality. Bankers are fine in ranked mode, since Income and Chill doesn't exist there,  because you can save up at least one extra round and then send a reasonable force to wipe them, but with Income and Chill turned on that forces you to spend all your mythium each round or else miss out on the extra gold. The reasonable DPS and gold income from bankers sets off a snowball effect where they basically determine the winner of the game if a player on the other team knows how to exploit bankers in Classic. The more bankers you build, the more income you receive every round and you get decent DPS along with them the more you build. In order to mitigate this, the opposing player needs to wipe your defenses and kill off the bankers at least once every few rounds. Unfortunately in order to do this you would have to turn off Auto and save for at least one round or more - and sacrifice getting the gold rush bonus every round you do that.
The other reason for the thumbs down is that the game play becomes stale very quickly in Classic for casual players. Every game is just deciding when to send as a group on level 21 or 22, sometimes people try level 20. That's it. Building cool combinations of units is interesting but ultimately has no effect on the Classic end game since it's just about everyone picking a level and sending everything at the same time. 
So unfortunately, as a casual player who has played the game for lots of hours I can say the end result is very mid and they don't seem to be doing anything about improving Classic mode or making it more interesting. They introduce new units and even though people complain about the new units being broken in Classic they won't fix it since they seem to focus on their ranked and hardcore players who don't see any problem with the new units since those players don't bother with Classic.
Lastly, the UI is sluggish and quite often when you stop your mouse over something it won't show the tooltip - until you slightly move the mouse again. The game takes tons of CPU and GPU power for being a relatively simple game. I have a 13th gen i7 and RX6600 GPU that plays MW3 fine and can tab in and out easily, but Legion TD 2 bogs down the entire system if you try to do other things while playing..

How To Make Breaded Garlic Mushrooms

PREP TIME: 15 minutes

COOK TIME: 20 minutes

COURSE: Appetizer, canape, starter

CUISINE: British

SERVINGS: 4 people

CALORIES: 281 kcal

INGREDIENTS

155 g panko breadcrumbs
1 teaspoon garlic powder
¬Ω teaspoon onion powder
¬Ω tsp smoked paprika
sea salt
black pepper
2 eggs beaten
55 g flour
20 button mushrooms approx 350g
2 teaspoon olive oil

Quick Chive Dip:
2 teaspoon cream cheese
1 tablespoon plain Greek yogurt
¬Ω tablespoon chopped chives
black pepper

INSTRUCTIONS

1. Preheat the oven to 200ÀöC/ 392ÀöF
2. Drizzle ¬Ω teaspoon olive oil over a baking tray and spread it out with a piece of kitchen towel.
3. Tip the flour onto a plate or shallow dish.
4. Whisk the eggs in a shallow dish.
5. In a shallow dish or plate mix the panko breadcrumbs with the garlic and onion powders and season with salt and pepper.
6. Wipe the mushrooms with a damp cloth or piece of paper towel to clean. Make sure the mushrooms are dry.
7. I find it easier to do the mushrooms in 4 batches - take 5 mushrooms and roll them in the flour, then egg, then the breadcrumbs, coating thoroughly with each.
8. Place the breaded mushrooms on the greased tray and repeat with other batches of mushrooms until all are coated.
9. Spray the mushrooms with a little olive oil - if you don't have an oil spray then drizzle from a teaspoon slowly over the mushrooms - and place in the oven.
10. Turn after 10 minutes and spray with a little more olive oil if they are looking dry.
11. Cook for another 10 minutes until they are deep golden and crispy.
12. Serve straight away.

To make the Chive dip:
1. Mix everything together in a bowl and season to taste.

NUTRITION
Calories: 281kcal
Carbohydrates: 43g
Protein: 13g
Fat: 7g
Saturated Fat: 2g
Cholesterol: 82mg
Sodium: 321mg
Potassium: 448mg
Fiber: 3g
Sugar: 5g
Vitamin A: 242IU
Vitamin C: 2mg
Calcium: 86mg
Iron: 3mg

From the moment I fired up Legion TD2, a wave of nostalgia washed over me, taking me back to the cherished days of Warcraft 3 and the original Legion TD map. To think that the same ingenious minds, who were just high school students back then, have returned to give us this sequel is nothing short of remarkable. Even in their early days, they showcased an uncanny ability for game design, gifting us with intricate strategies and gameplay mechanics that captivated us for hours on end.

Fast forward to today, and Legion TD2 stands not just as a continuation, but as a masterfully refined evolution of its predecessor. Everything that made the original so captivating is here, but now it's enhanced, polished, and honed to perfection. This isn't just a revamp; it's a complete reimagining that maintains the core game loop while adding layers of depth and polish.

Visually and mechanically, every aspect feels smoother and sharper. However, what truly stands out is how welcoming Legion TD2 is to newcomers. The game seamlessly guides players, offering an "easy to learn" approach, but beneath that inviting exterior lies a depth that promises a "hard to master" challenge for those who crave it. Both veterans and beginners will find themselves immersed, with strategies, challenges, and thrills catering to every level of player expertise.

For the loyal fans, Legion TD2 serves as a heartfelt journey down memory lane. For newcomers, it's a warm welcome into a world that's been crafted with passion, love, and an intrinsic understanding of what makes strategy games so alluring. Highly recommended!

If you enjoy strategy games, and feel like trying a unique take on the Tower Defense genre, give this one a shot. It has a bit of a learning curve, but with the variety of AI difficulty settings, along with pretty decent matchmaking, it's relatively easy to learn.

Quality verification team for this game are the monkeys on banana heaven. They're just mashing the button that says "yes, passable patch, there's no gamebreaking bugs in there"

[h1]The Bad[/h1] 
[b]*[/b] Freezing issues that last anywhere from 2 seconds to 40 seconds. Absolutely unplayable.I'm not exaggerating, I clocked it.  The game is 100% unresponsive and windows is ready to shut it down.
Some might say this is my system, not game's fault, but this only began to happen after a patch 2 weeks ago and I looked into every possible cause from my side but I can run every game just fine (EA Battlefront 2, csgo etc.) my specs are at the bottom. My friend also experienced a milder version of this.


[b]*[/b] Odd bugs, such as the ability to pick wave 10 skill reward on WAVE 1. This happened to me in a ranked match, thankfully it didn't actually let apply the ability on my units, but on wave 10 I didn't get to pick anything, basically handicapping me.

[b]*[/b] Toxic community. Now there are exceptions if you're playing in canadian timezone (duh) but generally speaking your teammate will screw up their gameplay and it'll all be your fault because you didn't do their bidding. People just can't take the blame. They're not nice to newcomers either. This is especially bad because it's a teamwork game and to win you MUST communicate but so many people will tilt, point fingers and whine instead of try to win.

[b]*[/b]  B R U T E  Imagine this, you're protecting the king as well as you've been protecting your virginity. Suddenly, 2 brutes appear on your melee attack wave. EVERY ENEMY, except the BRUTE gets targeted and your last few units are destroyed by the green chad. This boils down to units not prioritizing between targets. Warcraft 3 also had this, but it atleast targeted lowest HP unit. So brute would be prioritized after a certain wave there. Meanwhile this game's targeting system is as follows : "TARGET ANYTHING BUT THE BRUTE"

[b]*[/b] Fighter value system : Very poor indicator of your teammate's ability to hold the wave. When calculating your fighter value the game takes into account your damage/shield types and gives you a decent value you "should" reach but it's a very primal indicator that's often misleading. If it wasn't there at all and people manually kept track of sends everyone would be more aware.

[b]*[/b]  The bots. Maybe you don't intend to play against bots, but the game has co-op and every single bot in this game is dogshite. Need I mention if you disconnect you get replaced by a bot until you return? There's around 6 difficulties and the first 2 makes you yawn even if you're new to gaming in general. The 3rd aka medium is serviceable. The 4th and the rest is absolute destruction. There's no balance here and the difficulty should be a lot more gradual than this. The bots are also predictable in their building and mercenary patterns.

[h1]The good[/h1]
[b]*[/b] It's legion TD, I guess? Good game to play as quick distraction as every game takes around 30 minutes or less. UI is good and more newbie friendly than warcraft 3's but that doesn't say much for 2 decades old game comparison.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
The game is decent, but its bugs and toxic players  might ruin your fun. They don't have an effective solution to this and I've teammates leave as early as 1 minute into the game. This game WILL test your patience for all the wrong reasons.

I've been back and forth on this over the years, but don't buy this game.

People have been exploiting issues with the systems since release, and will always be exploiting issues until people stop playing. 

The game is forced 2v2. You will be stuck with a rando that is proud of being high on drugs, watching porn, intentionally trolling, griefing (there are many acceptable ways to grief that the team doesn't punish, since there is such a low playerbase), or otherwise illiterate or unable to play the game. 

If you criticize anything on these forums, you will be absolutely torn apart by toxic assclowns with barely functioning English, and the moderation team will not do anything. This is the community they want to create- a horrible cesspit.

For several years, people with ratings over 1800 created smurf accounts and kicked the ladder down by sabotaging games. This has not been addressed fully. 

The team has no intention of fixing the issues with the game. They apparently just want to make griefing easier and the game worse (Bankers and Fiesta are 99% griefing trolls).

The game has always and will always have horrible server issues starting with the login page. Sometimes it just doesn't work. Then you can lag on the main menu... Then you can lag coming into a game... then you can lag every round, and finally, up to 3 other people a round will D/C randomly. 

Some people use the D/C as an exploit, as when the game reloads your assets, you can see through enemy fog of war. If people don't know what to build, they often D/C to allow the AI to act for them. You will very rarely get a smooth game.

THE
STEAM
AWARDS

In general, this game is not only a worthy successor to the old Legion TD Arcade map of Warcraft 3, but an all around enjoyable game that can be part of your day-to-day for quite a long time. Rounds take roughly half an hour at average. The game can become quite in-depth, with a medium skill floor, but a very high skill ceiling the higher the rank goes. A very good challenge, and a wonderful community. 

However, the devs seem to lack business awareness when it comes to their IT infrastructure. Since server lags, that make the game a pain to look at, are very common and happen often. Causing me to consider deleting it and certainly writing this reply. 

The server lags happen too regulary to have a one-time root cause and are mostly occuring during peak times of the game. I hope the devs intend to learn a thing or two about IT infrastructure in the future, or this game might actually have severe issues sometime soon.

TLDR: Well made. Fairly easy to pickup, yet nearly impossible to master. And if PVP isn't your thing, its single player campaign excellent rogue-light puzzler. 

Like Dota 2, Legions TD 2 started as a Warcraft custom game and from there expanded to a standalone release, and despite not having the large financial backing of Valve, the quality of Legions TD 2 is just as good as Dota 2. The game runs wonderfully, the UI is easy to tell what's going on despite being a fairly data heavy game, and even the post game infographics really helps you to get a sense of how you played and why you won/lost. 

[h2]The Good[/h2]
It's extremely easy to pick up and play. PVP consists of you putting down a tower and then sending mercenaries to your opponent's lane as they'll be doing the same to you. From there you develop an economy and place more towers and send more mercenaries to your opponenent. This continues the mercenaries break through either yours or your opponent's towers and then attack the king at the end of the lane. Once the king's HP drops to zero, it's game over. Simple right?

[h2]The Bad[/h2]
The single player campaign is fun, but lord is it tough on the hard difficulties. You pretty much have to resort to some sort of cheese tactics to beat the ai on hard. From what I understand, a large part of this is due to the constant balance patches which tweaked some of the single player missions into absurd territory. 

[h2]The Summary[/h2]
Legions TD 2 is a hell of a fun experience. There's a real sense of personal knowledge progression the more game you play as you develop ways to optimize the placement of your towers, when to send mercenaries to your opponent, and which boons and bonuses to take as the game progresses. Definitely a worthwhile experience for fans of TDs who are looking for something competitive.

This game is essentially a money making machine disguised as a tower defense game. 

If feels like a free to play game, but it's not. It requires purchasing the base game. If you want more maps/campaigns, pay up! Feels pretty scummy, in my opinion.

There's only a few maps/campaigns, at the time of this writing, but imagine how much dough you would have to shell out if they had 50 maps/campaigns to purchase?(smh) Definitely not consumer friendly.

Also, keep in mind that this game is ALWAYS online. What happens to your investment when the devs get bored and decide to pull the plug on the servers? There is no value for your money here.

The game itself is enjoyable, however, lazy programming, always online, and a profit driven approach is a buzz kill. 

I can't recommend it.

I've been with this game since its birth on wc3, and its release on steam. Far more complex than any TD out there, if you want to call it that. 
Basically, you build an army that comes to life when each wave begins. You ration some gold to hire workers, who gather mythium, while building towers. Use the mythium to send monsters at your enemy, increasing the chance of their defenses failing that wave. This ensures that if they spend too much money on gem production, you will make them leak. It comes in 2v2 and 4v4 modes. After you clear the wave, your towers teleport to a spot standing in front of your king, until everyone clears the wave. If an ally leaks, your towers attempt to prevent them from reaching your king. Enemies gain gold from monsters leaked on opponent's side. 
 You can also spend mythium to upgrade your king, increasing their ability to survive when reached by leaks. The ultimate objective is to increase your mythium production, allowing for bigger offensive sends to your opponents, causing them to leak, defeating their king.
A wide variety of "perks" to choose 1 of at the start of each match. different perks added after wave 10. The game has a wide variety of towers, receiving a different set every match. Each tower has a different attack/defense type. These matter as each wave has a different attack/defense type, and they each have their strength/weaknesses. for example pierce does 85% damage to fortified armor, but 120% to swift armor.
 Highly recommend the game. Devs are very active and open to feedback. Can see them in game and friendly, as well as on discord and forums. Regular updates modifying towers based off of usage/win rate. if towers arent being used often by the general population, they will get a slight upgrade to increase frequency of use. If a tower is chosen too often, with a high win rate, they will give it a slight nerf to balance it out. this is then monitored to see if the tweak needs adjusting. Money is not needed in this game, which is wonderful these days.
Addictive and fun game, Lots of active players.

If you played Legion TD on W3 then this is a sequel that did everything right. 

Simple to start and learn TD type game where your 'towers' come alive to battle with waves of enemies. 

There are different type of damage and armour for all units, and your job is to find the perfect balance between those to clear all waves.

PVP is based on sending mercenaries to the enemy lane, but you need to monitor and cohort with your team on which wave they are weak to break their defences and kill their king. All leaks go to kill the king(that you can upgrade)

Game is well balanced and the playability is endless due to various possible builds. Downside is that they currently only have 21 fix waves (after wave 20 units are the same but stronger every wave) and 2 different modes (2v2 and 4v4).

Hands down one of the best, most in-depth cooperative strategy games I've ever played. Legion is at it's heart a resource management game, but it resembles a real-time chess match or heads up poker game at the higher levels of play. The number of combinations of units you can use and the number of opening strategies you can employ are virtually limitless, and very fun to play around with. That said, I am continually impressed just how viable different playstyles are! You can approach this game so many different ways and still find success, as long as you're communicative and cooperative.

The devs are extremely attentive to the community, and continuously patching the game for balance and adding new units to explore. On that note, the community is international in scope, and on the whole very friendly. To be successful at a cooperative game in which you really depend on your partner, you really have to be a team player, and it's good that most folks are. I am impressed that the devs are committed to holding free prize tourneys every month that are open to all players, and because of the tiered system, everyone, even newer players, have a chance to win their bracket's cup. 

It's worth every penny. Please come join our community and see what this game has to offer :)

GREAT Auto-Chess, Mediocre TD.

11/12/23 Update - I have noticed drastically less chain rerolling of griefers, etc. Because of that and their continuing honoring of regular updates and community interaction, I am flipping this back to recommend.

So, you have to go into this with far more of an auto-chess mindset than a TD one. If you are looking for that classic WCII:ROC mod game type, this is not for you. You don't have lanes in the classic sense, and the odds of things hitting and the order is chaotic to say the least. If you invest significant time in the minor nuances (unit movespeed per round, the assumed "melee" range vs melee range, etc.) there is a universe of a game here. Is it worth shoveling a couple hundred games of potential shit to uncover it? Maybe!

Look, I enjoy it, but it is a quick (15-25 min) experience that I can play with having kids. But it is a far cry from what I hoped for and the nostalgic feel that I was after.

AMAZING GAME!
Quality chill game. Easy to start, hard to master. Playerbase is fine, toxicity is low, on middle elo it takes max 1-2 mins to get a game.

Starts off addictively and after some time, almost 20 hrs in my case, you start hating it. It's fun at first, then gets dull. You have a cash shop for cosmetics and other stuff. Usually I don't mind that but I'm not used to buy a game and have parts of it locked behind a paywall for features/game modes. There is 0 progression and the game as a whole is very bare bones. I loved it because I loved WC3 Legion TD - that's the whole nostalgia ride even though its very different. It would have been a great game if the devs gave a **** for it.

Sometimes the community is chill, but when they are not chill they are EXTREMELY TOXIC. I don't know how someone can RAGE so hard over a video game - and for silly reasons like someone having 1-2 more workers than the enraged dude thinks is necessary. Like??? Chill bro. It's literally just a game. You're gonna be alright. Anyway, these are high rank players, gold and above, so they've 100% been around long enough to be toxic many times before, but I guess the "report" function in this game is just there to look nice while serving no real purpose. BTW there is no real casual mode in this game. 

Fortunately, usually the games are chill enough to be fun. HOWEVER- for some reason, the game will randomly crash out of nowhere after an extended period of playtime. This crashing is especially bad on classic mode, where it will permanently lock you out of building with your teammate and just instantly destroy the match for you. WHY is such a bug still in this game? I have literally never had this problem with any of the hundreds of games I've played before. Even if they couldn't fix the crashing for whatever reason, they should have at least fixed the classic mode reconnect bug, but nope, it's still there, and has happened to multiple people I've played with, including myself. 

Game-breaking bugs, toxic community at higher levels. Unfortunately, while this game can be very fun at times, I can't recommend it.

I have been playing strategy games and Turret Defense games in particular for a long time, 20+ years. This game is extremely simple in that once you learn how to win you can win every time BUT there is no alternative way to win. There is no different strategy that works. 

However I think the thing I like least about this game is that it's a money grab. For $23 if you paid full price you get an extremely short campaign with little replay ability and if you want any other campaigns you have to pay for the DLCs but the DLC is just as bad. This game counts on you wanting to play PvP or else you will be done and over this game in about 6 hours.  Oh and btw, if you do want some options for your avatar or other embellishments they try to force you to pay. How? The game gives you very little for free. For hours of playing you will get enough currency to most likely get a fragment. Oh which you need 10 to get anything but most likely the thing you get will not be something you want. 

I could keep going but TLDR: You get very little game for the money and there is almost no replay ability.

After returning to his game after a hiatus I wouldn't recommend. I find the lack of resources to learn about the game frustrating. The only info is generally how different units work individually. There isn't any in depth guide about mastermind and what makes for a good pick over a bad pick. It also seems that you're punished for not going mastermind via testing with other factions. Which makes me wonder why even offer factions? The game doesn't feel balanced around factions but individual units so it's completely pointless to have factions other then flavor. 
The game is fun but the amount of effort and time it would take to enjoy the game just doesn't feel worth it especially when what info I'm lacking isn't available. Why do some units perform better when placed just one square over? No idea. 

To summarize if it's your game or type of game or if you played the original then I think it's for you. If you're new to this style of game I can't recommend unless you're willing to spend hours and hours just learning the game before you get to start enjoying the game. Having to spend 15 hours just even figuring out how to properly play the game makes, in my opinion, for bad game design.

I do think that if there was a more updated guide to strategy and wave by wave strategy that would help tremendously. Hopefully like all games it will improve in the future.

Legion TD 2 has transformed my gaming hours into pure delight! It's like a tower defense fiesta where every tower is a special guest and the creeps are just trying to crash the party. Imagine a tower strategy game with all the cool kids flexing their unique tower styles ‚Äì it's a tower catwalk!

What's even better? The creeps are strutting their stuff like runway models on a mission. It's like they're saying, "Hey, we're here to invade, but with pizzazz!" And you, my friend, get to strategize your way through the runway chaos.

The multiplayer mode is where the real magic happens. It's like a LAN party where you and your squad team up to create the most dazzling tower ensembles. It's not just strategy; it's tower artistry!

Legion TD 2 is like a happiness potion for gamers. If you're ready to RSVP to a tower-tactic extravaganza and experience the joy of defending with style, join the Legion TD 2 celebration. Your gaming world will thank you for the invite!

A tower defence game with the PvP aspect appealling to me the most.  Its fun and relaxing for me, and I genuinely enjoy playing it while speaking with a friend or watching something on the side line. The initial process of learning the game for the PvP aspect can be a challenge. But once you get the hang of it, then it'll be very fun.

The campaign is mostly just a set of different puzzles you need to figure out which i havent done.

For the past 20 years every few months I would boot up Warcraft III just to play legion TD and then I found this game and it scratches that itch and then some. Very well balanced game along with an very active community that allows you to play way more games in a session then you ever could on Warcraft III.

Don't get this unless you are into PvP.

I think the game shines as a PvP thing, where you get dynamic back and forth.  I'm not sure why you would play this over a MOBA though, but at least it's not instantly stale and predictable.  There's not tons of skill and interesting decision involved however, you just need to pick (of luck into) the right counters and that's that.

PVE wise, the first couple hours of free trial suckered me into buying the game, but the following 1.5h just left me uninterested (20 minutes beyond the refund window :P).  The campaigns are basically just fixed puzzles which can't be solved with every faction. So you can basically grab a guide, pick the best faction for each challenge, and complete it without thinking.  Or you can just do trial and error until you find something that works.  If do what I did and try to stick to one faction throughout the campaign, you basically hit a wall at some point... that wall simply evaporates when you pick the "right faction for the challenge"... disappointing.

So anyway.  Can't say I'd recommend... certainly not for single player anyway, which was my goal.

I have played almost every competitive online strategy game around currently, and over the last decade, and LTD2 is fun, balanced, and most importantly the most fundamentally sound design from a strategy perspective. Skill is expressed in the game in a variety of ways that are ingrained in the fundamentals of the game in a way that no other strategy games have been able to do.

It doesn't need to refresh sets, or release expansions of units to keep the game fresh, because the game isn't just the units in the same way that other strategy games are the units, or the cards. And as a result, you don't have to spend money on the latest cards, you don't have to re-learn the entire meta every 3-6 months, or when you return to the game after a hiatus. 

You aren't 'playing the units' like you'd 'play set X', or 'play X expansion' of other games. You're just... playing the game, and using the units in different ways every single game. You can come back to the game time and time again and have just as much fun and be able to showcase your skill just as much without having to spend a day learning the current meta.

All this game needs is to get a stroke of luck to catapult the playerbase up and it should eat up the entire genre.

+- At first the game can be a bit overwhelming as u have to learn tons of units in order to compete (8 races with 6 units + upgrades + in ranked u play 'mastermind' which gets random units). Usually not a problem since most players will try the campaign or VS AI to try the game before playing MP

+ The community so far was great (no nolife afk/rage quitters, flaming LOL players or trolls)

Keep up the great work!

Tower Defense

What an absolute hidden gem if you like the original Legion TD WC3 mod!

Based on the very simple premise of: protect your king and kill the enemies' king. Build fighters in your lane to defend enemy waves that get stronger and stronger and hire mercenaries to attack your lane opponent. On top of that coordination with your team mate is key to winning so the game really shines when playing 2v2 with a friend.

While the basic concept is relatively easy to learn and understand the game gets incredibly complex and tactical very fast and no two games will be the same. But if you are into that kind of niche this game really ticks all the boxes. You will either love this game or simply hate it.

Which also leads to one of the bigger downsides: The player base is relatively small resulting in the usual problems for multiplayer ranked games. The skill range in match making can be pretty big to make sure queue times are not too long. Since I only play 2v2 with a friend I only get flamed occasionally by my team mate (joking) but I imagine coordinating with a random team mate can be a tad frustrating sometimes.

Devs are generally pretty active with balancing patches and communicate updates and their plans for the game regularly.

Let us begin with our first play thru....
UPDATED: 
November / 2021
November / 2022
May / 2023
Game is fantastic for a LANE semi auto-battler.
"Semi" as defense unit placement is just as important as unit level or unit type.
Units that mesh together to create strength is a must as knowing what to level or when.

Teamwork in any team play style is a must! 
No, you smart a$$, 1 versus 1 clearly there is no teamwork, but we are sure that you will be wishing you had a teammate.

If you build, and place, with no reason, method, or wit to learn the game, you will lose many many times, and begin to falsely hate it. 
Better yet, rage, claim it is not balanced, broken, cheaters... which would all be completely wrong. This team is very active in all aspects. Freaking cool actually.

There is method, a process, and its always changing with new units, unit improvements that are constantly monitored, and human change of tactics, let alone, many game variations.

ONCE AGAIN, THIS IS NOT AUTO CHESS, NOTHING LIKE IT.

This is a lane auto-semi-battler. What does this mean?

Its one, two, or four lanes.
Place Units, Upgrade Units, Send Units.
The lanes are occupied in a one versus one, two versus two or four versus four lane ratio.
The object is simple;
1. Do not leak, or invest in pampers.
2. Make your enemy leak, perhaps, offer them some pampers.
3. Grow workers to create bonus income for each wave.
4. Keep your King alive longer and buff your King too, its "Good to be the King".

So many people say "Oh, this is or sounds boring", until you lose 20 in a row and are angry.
Then the "boring" turns into prior stated, rage of imbalance, scream in cheaters, and then start watching videos on how to play while trolling and rage venting, all for nothing.

The growing process continues with a "light-bulb" that actually comes to life in ones head, proving everything we have written here, is true and rage is foolish judgement.

NOTE TO EVERY PLAYER;
You don't know it all, won't know it all, and after 1800 hours of play time, I am only Platinum level player and one with years of experience. 
The best in the game have played 3000 hours and upwards.

To put it in scope, that is only the third level in the seven levels there are.
So take it from 1800 hours of play time, its not a grind, its how much time you learn mastering and learning from mistakes of others and your own.

In my case, as I am a visual learner and do not excel in reading, playing with trial and error.
My learning style I was born with, a slow process, but its gets steady results and improves like fine wine over time. 
(ADD or ADHD users, will understand a bit more perhaps) 
There is no sprint to the finish here. 
"Slow and steady, wits at the ready."- ab

IN CLOSING;
Not all YouTube¬Æ videos are current, many game changes monthly, super balanced and active small team. 
MOST YouTube¬Æ videos are not good advice or guidance, playing is the only way. 
Videos only good for tips.
Most videos are outdated, or just made by players who think they are good, and just are desperate for content. Many of the videos, the game mechanics have been completely changed or improved.
There is only two or three players worth learning from, and they do not stream.
Play, play, play and challenge yourself.

Good luck, have fun, as losing is a must, even close games.
You will win some too and spoil overconfident foes. 
Wear a hat if you will be prone to pulling hair out, otherwise welcome to the bald club.

Its the best feeling in the world to watch your opponent not leak the entire game, over-send extra units to me every wave and be cocky, then you suddenly smoke em' because they did not build defense, are ranked higher, and I played smarter. Makes the ten prior losses that much more tolerable. Get In here already!

Tip: 
"Leaking" around here... is NORMAL as it is inevitable. 
DO NOT make a habit of it, because it gets harder on your mates, even if you are in a Fiesta build where leaking pays you more each wave, still can hurt your team if done without coordination.

Teamwork is strongly encouraged, in a diplomatic, majority vote, play style.

Dictators DO NOT do well at all in this game. Try to tell anyone what to do, and you get less cooperation. Since bully dictators do not get it, they will rage themselves right out the door.
Many dictators will rage in chat because they can't accept this fact and attempt to force their will, futile as it is, just to ruin their bonus, behavior score, and quit. 
No worries, they will then make a new account in shame, just to do the same.
The "Does Not Play well w/ Others" achievement does not exist yet, we lobbied for it to tag all bully accounts, but its still in production or deep thought.

So be a good teammate, as choices are by majority vote in team games, and with fast discussion, plain and simple. 

Yes, you will get the occasional AFK and those who disconnect. Don't forget the rage quitters in team formats from time to time, but don't worry!!
They have hardware for them too and they wont be around for long when its a habit and the developers do monitor it and have closely monitored it for two years.
If you do not wish to team play, then play one versus one or the campaign and save your access to the game. There are no cheats for this game, so any you may find are scams.


SUMMARY
Core Features
Party as 1-8 players. 
Play 2v2 and 4v4 match made games.
Single-player/co-op campaign.* (~8-12 hours) and 5 levels of AI's.
Friendly & active player base. 
Still going strong as of July 2023.
9+ years of development. Thousands of hours have gone into refining the core game loop.
Highlights
Enjoyable to learn. Efficient 15-min tutorial. 
In-game companion ("Game Coach") gives you tips as you play. 
Co-op campaign is beatable for players of all skill levels. 
New-player friendly matchmaking eases you into PvP.
Infinite replay ability. 
No two games are the same. Even after 4,000 hours, the game is still fresh.
Best-in-the-world game balance. 
Driven by both data and feedback to ensure strategic variety and competitive fairness.
Stats for days. Ranked seasons & rewards, profiles filled with graphs & tables, full match histories, and leaderboards.
eSports. $750 cash tournaments every month for only the best. SO hard to get partners.
No pay to win but only win if you play. 
In-game purchases are 100% cosmetic.
Global servers. All multiplayer is cross-region with no lag.
FairPlay detection system. AFKers, griefers, and toxic players are dealt with quickly.
Weekly challenges. A puzzle-like competition to find the best build with a set lineup.

Awesome game with a great dev team who are very smart at consistently improving the game.

Definitely worth picking up if you enjoy trying out tons of different strategies. GREAT game if you have a duo queue partner to mess around with, but not required by any means.

While the learning curve is steep, the sandbox mode and statistics breakdowns are very well made. They aren't required by any means either - if you are fine with losing some games, you can get started in competitive play quickly, and learn by doing.

Your opponents totally creamed you? The post-match breakdown lets you view 10+ different graphs of statistics, plus each players' build on every single wave. This means you can understand and put together WHY you lost way better than any other tactics game I've played. You can even copy and try out the opponent's strategy in your next game to get a handle on it - maybe it's actually op, or maybe there are weaknesses you didn't know until you played it.

It's a big boy game with lots to sink your teeth into!

5/10 Perfectly acceptable game without a ton of competition. That is to say I would give serious consideration to playing something else should it become available. I tried Dota Underlords for a bit, but that game feels like its dead for some reason. I started with this franchise in Starcraft 2's arcade mode. Which, in my opinion, was a better game. There was just more you could do. Plus. I loved the Nature builder and almost nothing from that builder found its way into this game. 

Pros:
-Decent strategical layers: 4 types of offense and defense, decent combinations. 2 game modes. Varied ranges and conditions. I.e. Flying units decreasing crowding and switching up targeting priorities.

-Graphics and sound: They are clean and fun. Solid U.I. 

-Campaign mode: Fairly challenging while highlighting key aspects of game play.

-Bots: Where I spend the majority of my time. I went 10-0 in my ranked placements (check my achieves, hard carry.) Then my next 2 games I had a bronze teammate vs a gold and plat player. I had a teammate underbuild only using one type of unit placed very poorly. He leaked 60% or more on the first 4 waves while asking me to leak to feed his units. Even though I declined to leak we lost by wave 7. In ranked. Its a waste of time unless you want to babysit your teammates. Luckily the bots are well tuned and allow you to explore the game at your own pace.

The Cons-

Updates: Game has very little direction going forward. They love releasing broken towers that don't fit well into the game and end up scaling them back. Cough. And the also will completely destroy a towers functionality on a whim. Because they are literally that clueless and they want to dumb their game down to increase their player base. Cough, cough. They are going with the sensationalist strategy of hype over everything. Keep chasing the high instead of developing the game into something truly special that would organically bring in more players. The few years I have been playing this game they have only ever subtracted from the tactical layers of the game. And there are some glaring issues they refuse to fix which turns this game into more of a gambling simulator then a tower defense game. 

-A.I. Targeting RNG: Sometime the Wave will switch targets randomly, sniping you dps melee unit as the lines meet. The RNG aspect of this isn't a major issue, but it can cost you games. Which is frustrating. And if you are going to try and deny this as a fact, all I'd have to say look at the weekly challenge. You can use the same build vs. the same wave and get wildly different results. The main issue here is the fragility and inflexibility of formations. For example. If the send a snail your formation meets the wave too quickly and you and your dps gets sniped as the wave registers it as hitting the wave before your off tank. And ranged waves.  These are major problems that expose certain towers and builds. 

-Game pacing/balance: Now. The game is designed for you to say: "Ok, I'm going to be weak on these waves. But I can gain advantage on these waves and push harder." That's a cool idea. And in a perfectly balanced game that would work. But this isn't a perfectly balanced game. And some towers are simply that much better then others. For example. The seahorse. Gives its health to the frontliners while dishing out small amounts of damage. Its broken. And how do the devs respond, the only way they can. Damage, cooldown and health nerfs. Creating a seesaw of overtuning or underperforming with no clear middle ground. Adding a merc who disrupts healing, or adding a merc who spawns at the end of the lane and pushes up. Not even an option for these people as it would undermine certain towers. Do you see the problem. They already have mercs that counter certain towers. Like safety mole, who counters Aoe or brute who counters high single damage towers. Methodically unbalanced. The more variables you have to work with the more ways you have to achieve balance, but also the balls you have to keep in the air. Turns out the most import aspect of balancing a game is balance itself.

-Placement, Placement, Placement: The most important part of the game. Literally. And yet. There is no way to preview late game tower placement. No blueprint mode. No way of knowing how the tower will react to the wave. Made worse by the fact that you cannot adjust your towers placement without a hefty loss of money. Putting a tremendous emphasis on game knowledge to the point that knowing that sending a brute and snail against a nightmare on wave 6 will cause the brute to insta focus the nightmare. Boom. Game won. While that specific example may not be true, the game literally is that niche and ridiculous.

Summery: Fun game that's hard to pick up and even if you do you are always one bad move away from losing any given game.

Legion TD 2 is an absolute gem in the realm of tower defense games. It effortlessly blends elements of strategy, teamwork, and excitement into a captivating gaming experience that keeps you hooked for hours on end. As an avid gamer, I can confidently say that Legion TD 2 has set a new standard in the genre, offering an unparalleled level of depth and enjoyment.

One of the most impressive aspects of Legion TD 2 is its strategic depth. The game presents you with a plethora of choices, from selecting and upgrading your towers to coordinating with teammates to form a formidable defense. Every decision you make has consequences, and the constant need to adapt and counter your opponents' strategies keeps the gameplay fresh and engaging. The level of depth allows for endless possibilities and encourages creativity, ensuring that no two matches are ever the same.

The graphics and art style of Legion TD 2 are visually stunning. The attention to detail in the design of the units and the diverse maps creates a vibrant and immersive world. From the lush forests to the desolate wastelands, each environment feels unique and adds to the overall atmosphere of the game. The animations are smooth and fluid, bringing the battles to life with a satisfying sense of impact.

What sets Legion TD 2 apart from other tower defense games is its emphasis on teamwork. The multiplayer mode encourages collaboration and coordination, fostering a strong sense of community among players. Working together with your teammates to build a synergistic defense and counter the enemy's attacks is both thrilling and rewarding. The game truly shines when you and your allies execute a flawless strategy, outsmarting your opponents and achieving victory together.

The developers of Legion TD 2 deserve commendation for their dedication to the game's community. They actively engage with the player base, listen to feedback, and consistently release updates and patches to improve the gameplay experience. This level of commitment ensures that Legion TD 2 remains fresh and enjoyable long after its initial release.

In conclusion, Legion TD 2 is a triumph in the tower defense genre. Its strategic depth, stunning visuals, and emphasis on teamwork make it an unforgettable gaming experience. Whether you're a seasoned strategist or a casual gamer looking for an immersive and challenging title, Legion TD 2 is an absolute must-play. Prepare to be captivated by its brilliance and get ready for countless hours of thrilling tower defense action.

I got this game a year ago or so. After about 20 hours I got mentally stun locked by just how much stuff there was to learn about the game and I put it down. Fast forward a few months, seeing content being made about it and frequent updates to the game it got me interested again and this time I wanted to really give it another try.

After a dozen or so games VS bots and watching some YouTube videos, I felt much more ready to jump back into ranked (the standard game mode). I was constantly getting wins and not just by getting carried either, I felt like I improved my skills and was better at the game.

I'm not going to lie, the depth of the game with the lack of fine guidance was a big quit moment for me initially. Yes there are tutorials in the game, and honestly they are pretty great at teaching the fundamentals. But there is a lack of specific tutorials to teach things such as when to hire workers and what units are good to build when. Viewing the unit roster is a fine bandied fix but it's a bit of a stat dump when it comes to interpenetrating what you are looking at. 
There is a link you can click when viewing the unit to learn more about it and some general tips on how to use them. But the link is kinda hidden and pretty small in the unit card among the sea of numbers. Not sure why it can't just be made more obvious and not send you to the wiki, Having to tab out over and over to check multiple units for their tips is pretty tiresome after a while.

With all of that being said. This is one of my new favorite chill PvP games to play. Each match feels pretty unique with it's play styles and diversity of units. If you decide to give this game a go, don't hesitate to check out some basic/ advance guides on YouTube by different content creators, and be patient with the game as there is a ton to learn. With my current playtime of 122 Hours as of writing this, I'm still learning new combos and strategies with units and merc sends.

TLDR: The game is very fun, but extremely deep and complex, give it time and patience and you may have a new fun PvP game to play!

Overall: Great tower defense/autochess game that is constantly updated and has a great community and is well worth the price. This started as a WC3 mod that has constantly been improved. 

Positives:
- Constantly updated with balance changes, new towers/characters, community gamemodes, and single player. The devs are great. 
- Game never feels too repetitive with how many options there are
- Good options for both causal and competitive gamers
- Fun with friends

Negatives:
- Games can be somewhat on the longer side
- The late game building at times can feel stale

Skip it unless you want to spend $20 for a fleeting feeling of nostalgia.

I played legion td when it was a warcraft mod.
My first recommendation was negative, due to the average graphics and the feeling of ill-matched character models. But giving the game some time to get used to it, I started to see its better sides. So what do we get for this paid version compared to free versions like the one for Dota 2.
pros:
- speed of the game, we are able to play 2 full games during one.
- we get a whole lot of small changes that significantly improve the comfort of the game. (combat stats, practice sandbox, unit positioning grid, attack range view)
- we get a lot of small changes that increase the depth of the game (better balance, game modes, more interesting approach to leaks)
- an internal store that does not affect the win, but gives us the opportunity to build prestige based on the results in the game.

What bothers me is the graphics.
cons
- heavily simplified character models (needed for the game to run smoothly with a large number of players and heroes)
- heroes detached from time and place and statistics not corresponding to the model (attacking overgrown plants next to spaceships, archers, elementals and mechs or anti-aircraft guns)
- a bit high price in relation to the size of the content

I think that the game has amazing playability and will surely provide a lot of fun. The price could be a bit lower, but juxtaposing it with the time you will play with it, I think it's worth buying.
Easy to play. Hard to master. You'll enjoy continued growth as a player, multiple strategies and ways to approach each match, and ranked that has decent matchmaking.
This game is far more intricate than it seems at first. If you are lookin for a strategy game its a fantastic pick up. Plays well with friends too.

There will be plenty of hours for you to pump into this game between learning when to send mercenaries to the opposing teams lane and learning builds/combos. Highly reccomend.

Legion TD 2 is a fun game for those who enjoy autobattlers, tower defense, or something in the middle of both genres. I find the game interesting and enjoyable. I often play it during meetings (when I am not expected to present). I find the community to be pretty friendly for the most part (I only mute my teammates like 25% of the time). You can very easily mute pings, text, or suggestions so it becomes easy to just enjoy your game and not worry about others.

The only frustrating thing is I don't seem to be getting anywhere in the rankings. I find myself pushing 1800 every season, but for every game where I feel challenged by the teammates or pushed ahead, there are five or six games where the lack of placement, use of the 'auto send' button, or understanding of the wave strengths/weaknesses is abysmal. All in all, I have fun playing this game and will continue to do so. It's a low-time investment skill-based strategy/autobattler that is never the same game twice.

The game has 2v2 ranked, and 4v4 unranked. Sometimes it has 1v1 events for the weekend.
There is also a campaign now, I guess? Never bothered to check it out.

For those who are curious, there are no pay2win mechanics. Everything purchasable is cosmetic. It's an easy-to-learn high-skill ceiling game that requires little effort to enjoy yourself.

Update: After many years of developement this game has truley surpassed the original! If you enjoy Tower Defense games this is a must buy. The goal is to clear your wave with the minimum amount of money spent on towers as possible without leaking. You buy workers with your leftover gold which farm mythium, which you use to send units at the enemy ontop of the normal wave of creeps to make him leak. If you cause him to leak you get bonus gold. Sending units also gives income that you get at the end of the wave. So the game has so much replayability because you keep trying new builds that let you clear the wave while making max workers to get your income way higher and cause leaks to your enemy. So much fun and different strategies to win I have litterally thousands of hours into the original and am having a blast with LTD2!

Game has potential but feel empty after a while. Not to many options of progression in game. Game is focus about sending and pushing workers in right time. Every other aspect of game is just illusion. I wish TD2 will grow and implement deeper and complex mechanics&gameplay rules. 
For now its good to play from time to time but not worth of full engage

If you enjoy chess, poker, TD's, and auto battlers, this may be your favorite game.

It starts relatively easy..as a noob you can put units anywhere, build workers whenever, send mercenaries whenever, and you CAN still win. ONLY as a noob though... 
This games mechanics run mad deep, and each unit has incredible potential. I am hundreds of hours in, at my peak top 1k ranked top 200 classic, and I'm still not good compared to these dudes at the top with these wild strategies. 

Ranked is a decently balanced 2v2 mode (I recommend for new players, as you get matched with ONLY new players); until you hit diamond you don't really feel stuck in elo hell. However, as an expert+ player..some diamond players should not be in diamond, even expert lol..either way, if you really are better than the rank you're playing, you should be able to win even with a bad teammate.
However, classic is an intense difference. Because this game is heavy on economy flow & synergy in builds, 4v4 becomes infinitely more difficult and MOST people that play it don't understand that. You can still have a solid time in classic when you queue as any rank, but personally (as a Legend classic player), unless you queue 4 stacked you inevitable have gold-plat players on your team that have no idea how to play the way classic is intended to be played..which is essentially crank to 19 and send 21+.
I don't queue classics at all solo, they are mad frustrating and so many people are completely non-receptive to criticisms which inevitable throw the game.

My last comment is the price..I understand this game is created by very few people and maintained by them, (whom I commend greatly and they are incredible at keeping this game afloat) but it is more expensive than it should be. I understand $20 as a base price game, but in order to get in game aesthetics you have to spend money.
I have helped cast multiple Nova Cup tournaments, spend over $250 on in game essence, and you can see my play time in this game...I'm still at ONLY HALF of the in game aesthetics overall. It's not the biggest deal, but if you are a collector (as I am) you should be weary that this game can become a money pit.

However, this game overall is incredible and I paid full price for it when I bought it. I am not upset with the money I spent in this game by any means, its just something to take into consideration. 
As a new player, understand it is ONLY aesthetics that you're spending money on; most people don't spend money in game, which I respect their patience and ability to stay withdrawn from it. I personally love them lol, I have all but 6-7 skins & half the cards.

This game is a 9.5/10 in my eyes, and only getting better as the devs keep it pretty balanced and add new units, modes, and campaigns. The .5 off is the price & ability to gain essence in game for more in game aesthetics, which I know isn't really important to many people.

I don't usually make reviews on steam, but this game really deserves it. Let me get started by saying that if you like strategy games like card games, tower defenses, RTS, then you are going to love Legion TD2!   I started playing Legion TD over 10 years ago, it was a custom Warcraft map, it was  amazing! But nothing last forever and they closed the servers where we used to play... But then i got some great news! they were lauching a Warcraft Reforged! a place were me and my friends could play legion TD once again!!! but i was completely disappointed by how terrible that game was, and once again there was no place to play Legion TD... Then i came across Legion TD2 on steam, i was happy but kinda skeptical, i tought wow this is great! the reviews are nice, the Devs are active, but since this is primarily a multiplayer game i was afraid it didn't have a decent playerbase and i would be stuck in queue forever... oh boy was i WRONG! I promise this is the most useful review for this game that exists. I had to fight 3 months from April 2022 to June 28 2022 in order to post this truthful review because the developer took issue with it and used steam's 'guidelines' to silence me and my review for not being slavishly praiseworthy.

I played legion td in WC3 over a decade ago from it's very earliest iterations, and when I found out Legion TD 2 was on steam, I was positively over the moon. I immediately bought a copy for myself and for my significant other to support the developers and enjoy the game.

We began with AI and played AI only to become competent, unlocking all the AI achievements such as campaign on hard etc. so we felt confident we at least had a basic grasp. I found the game to be extremely similar to the original (even using many of the same models, similar voice clips and dialogue, and unit names) and quickly became almost as obsessed with the game and community as I had been with the original.

Pros
NONE! FLEE THIS TRASH HEAP OF PEDOPHILES, CORRUPT DEVELOPERS AND ABUSIVE BULLY MODERATORS LIKE IT WAS HEROINE WITHOUT THE HIGH.

Cons
-Childish developers will personally harass you with their administrative powers if you don't slavishly shower the with enough praise while speaking in chat
-Developers will give you 0 warning and a 500 hour mute on your account (with a little note that says first "warning" as well as penalties and negative points against your account if you talk to them in General Chat, or suggest they made a mistake with a patch, or ask when they will be fixing a known issue
-Know issues that devs refuse to fix include but are not limited to
*The game not connecting you or kicking you out and then giving you leaver penalties and punishments even if you made it back into the crashed game within 1 minute and began building, TOO BAD.
*Mercenaries will QUITE OFTEN sit inside the fence and NOT SEND on the round you sent, even though the tooltip in the bottom left will show 0 mercenaries waiting inside the pen.
*Minions will often line up at one gate and not the other. There is NO CONSISTENCY regarding this. At first I thought the last team to leak would have their minions move through after, explaining why one side is usually let through before the other. But as I continued to play I noticed quite often I would be the last in the game to leak, but the enemies minions would line up long before and still be standing lined up LONG AFTER even if both enemies leaked, and an invisible gate would hold the minions back while letting my partner's leaks through, costing us the "base race" every single time it happened. There is no discernable reason for the inconsistency in the invisible 'king gate.'
*As demonstrated in the weekly challenge, the exact same set-up in the exact same locations is so powerfully affected by RNG it can make the difference between a full leak and a full clear. You can use the tutorial tool or just run a weekly challenge to see this for yourself; reset the wave but change NOTHING in your set up, and run the same wave again. If you do this 20 times you will get 15 different results on average. meaning that even with perfect towers and perfect positioning and perfect minion control, you will quite frequently be screwed over by RNG and BAD CODING.
-But all these cons pale in comparison to the personal behaviour of the 4 developers of the game.
-For example again, if you say in global chat "Hey I see you guys made another patch. That's great. There are some big issues still not fixed, do you think you guys could fix it soon?" you will get NO WARNING, FIRST OFFENCE a 500 hour mute on your account, as well as some weird 'penalty points' that say "afk or leaving games" on them even though you didn't leave a game or afk. (In this specific example. no games were played where a mute could have happened in game.)

Now, when my S.O. and I jumped into a ranked game, we came across fellow Canadians in our game, and used the in game cross-team chat system to cheerfully greet one another, and upon discovering we were from Quebec, Alberta and Saskatchewan, we joked "Trudeau is the only thing that can unify our provinces" and all agreed "Mad Max Bernier for PM". There was no cursing or unpleasantness. I myself made 3 comments, the ones above and "Freedom Convoy, honk honk!" for a total of 3 comments over the course of the game, all totally within terms and conditions and violating no rules. Friendly, polite, Canadian banter.

Seeing as those were my only 3 comments, you can imagine my surprise when after the game I had an account penalty and had been "muted" meaning I could not speak in party, I could not ping in the game, I could not talk to my S.O. in the game, I could not use the general chat. I couldn't even ping what waves I wanted to send or anything. I went to the forums and made a 100% no violation post explaining the situation that had occurred and how I didn't see what I had done to warrant these absurd, ridiculous penalties when I had done nothing wrong. It was not venting, or flaming, I was reaching out to the community to say "Hey, this doesn't seem right. Is this a one-off?"

This is where the problems started FULL FORCE. A developer of the game removed my post and gave me several day suspension from the forums with no explanation. I went to the review section and wrote a nice review about how I would have LOVED to recommend the game, but I could not based on this horrible practise of censorship for absolutely no reason, and that if they stopped censoring I would change my review.

The developer escalated the situation by having my review censored on steam. This made my review invisible and locked it from being edited. I opened a ticket to steam support, who said "The developer has done this, we can not help you." I took the screenshots from steam support which said the developer was responsible for the bans and suspensions, not steam, and posted them in a forum on the Legion TD 2 community on steam, with proof.

The developers permanently banned me from the Legion TD community sending me 1 small, poorly written message which said "we had an internal vote and permanently banned you for conspiracy theories." despite the picture proof from steam they called it "conspiracy theories."

When I opened tickets about this, Steam confirmed once again that "The developers of the game had made these bans" I spent 3 months opening Steam Support tickets and steam placing 100% of the blame on the developer. Last night I finally convinced steam to delete the review entirely so I could write a new one.

if you like coming up with strategies, counter-strategies, and countering counter-strategies, this game will for sure get you hooked.

You have 20 seconds each wave to decide the best method of:
 - Tower Defense
 - Hire Mercenaries to attack your opponent (they mix in with 21 pre-set waves)
 - Manage Gold production (Buys defensive units)
 - Manage Mithium production (Buys mercenaries that make you gold for offensive units)

All in all, very intense and worth full price. The only change that could be made is to make waves 1-21 random so people can't build strategies around them.

It's not free, yet its worse than Legion TD in Warcraft 3. Much more shallow.

Below listed missing things from the free version in Warcraft 3.
- Less units to build, less upgrade paths, no "hero" unit, less auras
- King has only 10 upgrade points, no king aura upgrade, no king control
- No champion challenge function
- Launch settings (modifiers) such as 3x send, mirror, AC and so on
- Wood/Crystals mining is simplified, for the worse.

All in all each game is about the same. Due to many mechanics being simplified or simply not there, there are much less viable strategies to play with.

Incredibly enjoyable game! If you are a fan of tower defense games or tactical games in general there is a high chance you will like it. There are 2 campaigns for singleplayer and co-op play (the 2nd one being paid DLC - it's great if you like the game and want to support the devs!). It is also a very competitive game with very high skill cap. Takes quite a long time to learn all the small details but it's definitely worth it. Ranked 2vs2 mode is very nice and balanced - usually takes 30s-1min time to find a ranked game with evently matched player (currently plantium as of writing this, but started as low as bronze and was always evently matched). There is a very nice sandbox mode where you can test out a lot of different setups and find out which mercenaries are best to recruit in each situation. Surprisingly there are good AI bots to play with and a very nice game coach mechanism which constantly helps you improve at the game. Highly recommended even for casual play if you like to hop into some games from time to time and spend 1-2h a day/week!

Really amazing game for competative players!

My prefered way of playing it is as a duo in ranked mode but alone it's also very acceptable since you can ping about everything in the game incase your 'solo'-ally doesn't talk back for whatever reason.
The game also has a 4vs4 mode for those with bigger groups of friends.
Plenty of small updates and fixes which shows that the developers care about the state of their game.

For those interested in tournaments, they also have those going on for different levels of player skill so a bit of everything for everyone! 
The game also has skins you can buy with earnable ingame currency or for which you can pay real money. 
You can decorate the side of your playing board with statues of minions/enemies you can earn through playing which adds another layer of costumization. That never hurts! 

There are guilds, weekly challenges, solo campaigns, bot matches of different difficulties, global chat, etc etc.
I have met people from all over the world being them japanese, brazillian, german, south african, ... Everyone plays!
Queue times are very short. Usually less than 2 minutes and a match can take 20 minutes so it's really great.
Rarely do I meet a toxic team mate but it happens as such is the nature of human kind unfortunately.

All by all, my favourite multiplayer game which rewards knowledge, teamwork and skill. I keep coming back for more even if I take breaks now and then. I recommend it to everyone who likes a tower defence kind of game (the minions being your non-stationary towers) and for those who enjoy auto battlers.

Legion TD2 is a strategy game that takes players on an epic journey through a fantasy world of warfare and diplomacy. From the moment you start the game, you are thrown into a fast-paced and intense strategic experience, as you must build up your army, recruit powerful heroes, and defend against waves of enemy units. The game's visuals are stunning, with detailed and highly-detailed characters and environments that truly immerse the player in the game world.

The gameplay is challenging, but also rewarding. The game offers a high degree of depth and complexity, with a variety of different units and heroes to master, as well as different strategies to employ. The game's multiplayer aspect is also well done, allowing players to compete against each other in intense matches.

The game's replayability is high, with different difficulty levels to choose from and a lot of different playstyles to experiment with. The game also has a lot of content to explore, with new units and heroes being added regularly.

In conclusion, Legion TD2 is a fantastic strategy game that is sure to appeal to fans of the genre. Its depth and complexity, coupled with its stunning visuals, make for a truly engaging and immersive experience. The game's multiplayer aspect is well done, and the game's replayability is high. Overall, Legion TD2 is a game that is well worth your time and money.

It therefore takes time to master. But once you start to get the flow of it, it's relaxing, challenging, competitive as well as creative all at the same time. Very nice and quite rare mix
