Teamplay, communication and coordination are essential as the better you and your opponents get, the more the victory will depend on this. One error can ruin a perfect game, just like chess.

I'd dare that for some people Legion TD 2 would be extremely hard to put down. It's the spiritual successor to the SC2 mod, but has its own set of unique rules and play-styles. With this said, I found this game to be rather pigeon holed in terms of min/max optimization. Certain play styles exceed far above others (as to be expected). However, in a game where there are literally minutes of down time, and very few "optimal" ways to build and counter at every given round, it doesn't reward creativity or uniqueness with its various approaches to the game in ways which ever feel rewarding or novel to each match-up. The "skill" is in how, when, and where you set your pieces; not exactly like Chess. That's not to say that deeper mechanics don't exist. In fact, this game has grown rather well over the few years since it's initial release. Rather, I find that certain tried and true builds/guides will champion ingenuity and to me that makes competition a slog and a bit of a "skill-based" joke. If I can watch a video on YouTube highlighting optimal starts and sends - which will outpace any one person's own research into such a topic - and it's still tactically optimal against most match-ups and through most updates, then why not just replicate this every match? This may be less of an issue at higher ranks, but again (for me) this ladder just doesn't reward skill in anyway that feels unique. The matchmaking is all over the place. Sprinkle in toxicity, and it just doesn't feel worth the time to grind as the "fun" aspects of Legion TD 2 can result in instant snowballing losses which lead to chain harassment from both teams.

If you have ever played Legion TD on Frozen Throne, or Squadron TD on SC2, or Mines and Magic on SC2 or any of the many other "TD but you have income and can add to the opponents wave for more income because it's also PvP" type games, and been ruthlessly crushed over and over and over because no one running these lobbies is remotely interested in a fair fight and has stacked their team before anyone else ever joined and will literally kick you if you ask for advice. This is worth buying just for the matchmaking.

That said, I also like the way playstyles both encourage you to do things differently and reward you for playing how you happen to enjoy playing. The recommended value and being able to easily check how your fighters, mercs, and so on are doing also makes learning much easier than in the other games. I do however, wish they actually pointed out to you the screen with all the information on how your stuff is doing, how much damage are your tanks eating, how much damage are your DPS dishing, how about your mercs? That all of these are on the same screen off in a corner is sometimes annoying.

I did have some performance issues in the main menu when the Background was the default Earth King, swapping that to Beta King mostly solved them, and the actual game runs fine, it was literally just the animated Earth King made my FPS tank.

Also, the game has 0 problems matching you with people on the other side of the world, which makes me very glad they have dedicated servers. And pings...

A great game for those who want to play competitive, but kind of casual at the same time. 

Pros:
+ it take very little time to learn
+ plenty of different modes
+ easy to play, hard to master
+ a normal game takes between 15-20 minutes and feels satisfying
+ good and at the same time light graphics. The game is tiny
+ great User Interface and overall design/usability  of the menus
+ good communication/ping options in game
+ easy and quick matchmaking
+ good statistics

Cons:
- gets repetitive quite quickly. After some time 60-70% of the game is the same
- campaigns were a bit disappointing for me. Colorful different maps and in the end you play on the same terrain as always

Overall super happy with the game. Can recommend to those who enjoyed Warcraft 3 modes or to those you are looking to play several satisfying 20-minutes rounds after work.

An excellent mix of co-operation and competition.

The ranked play is where this game truly shines - the decisions you make throughout the game shape your defence. You are rewarded for playing strategically, without having to micromanage anything. It's got a variety of helping tools to suggest builds and units for beginners, and experts can always look further ahead into the game, to optimise their build, predict dangerous levels, defend when they're weak, and capitalize when they're strong.

The game swings heavily in the favour of the winning team, but there's always a chance for the losing team to save up resources to make a final desperate attack, allowing for some brilliant comebacks.

The developers are constantly improving and balancing, and are active in discord, and responsive to feedback.

Not a fan. Core concept is fun, enjoyed campaign enough but for multiplayer you're forced to do a draft that includes every character in the game. Make the barrier to entry much higher compared to single player since you have to essentially memorize every single character in order to start playing multiplayer. 

I like games in this genre as a chill podcast game that adds some challenge, but multiplayer makes it a total sweatfest to even participate. 

Also, no indicator on timers while picking the starting loadout in multiplayer. First game I was reading unit descriptions and got kicked for being AFK, no warning or timer. 

Sadly the single player is very, very short with no sort of progression system and very little reason to play. After finishing what felt like the first tutorial levels, you're immediately prompted to buy DLC to continue the campaign.

Edit: Forgot to mention that the game doesn't have a comfortable resolution for the monitor I use (4k tv), UI scaling feature is bug ridden, and alt+tabbing makes it so none of the controls work anymore. I get it's an indie game, but for a 4+ year old game I would hope that basic functions like alt+tabbing wouldn't break the game.

I've been playing Legion TD since some of the earliest Warcraft 3 custom game releases and picked up this standalone sequel during early access. This game is not for the weak of mind; it rewards analysis, introspection, and accountability. 
What it lacks in raw fidelity, sound design, and pazazz, it more than makes up for those with great, regularly-updated balancing, excellent UI design, and a massive variety of tools to understand the game better and play it the way you want. I've played this for 149 hours over a longggg time, so it's not something I can grind because the gameplay isn't super varied. However, it has heart and is very satisfactory to do well in, especially when you dedicate mental energy to the game. Big recommendation, with the recognition that I couldn't play this as consistently as some other games.

I played the campaign and couple matches in multiplayer so far. I like it! It has certain charm to it with the various mechanics it provides. They are well laid out, not overwhelming but plentiful! 

The meat of the game is in the combat phase, but it does feel its lacking a little "oomph". Each hit on a critter is like a feather tickle, not like an army of soldiers fighting. Since so much time is spent on looking at the creatures fighting, how about getting it more enjoyable? Via selected sound effects, screen effects and hit indicators for example. Such as that not every hit needs to produce a sound, but when it does, it's meaningful to the user.

Take a look at Hearthstone for example, when a creature on board hits another creature on the opposite side of the board, theres a whole bunch of stuff happening FX-wise; shakes, indicators, shattering, "ramping up", particles and debris flying around etc.. it makes the experience more enjoyable.

I've played many games that this one is "cloned" or inspired by.  Warcraft 3 had quite a few custom maps that operated almost exactly like this game.  Starcraft 2 has a game that is almost identical.

All of them share the same issues minus one.   That one difference?  Those other games were free (assuming you owned the primary platform WC3/Starcraft 2).  You have to pay for this version but you gain no real benefits for doing so.  Honestly, you're better off playing the custom maps in Starcraft 2.

That said, another major complaint about these games which this version hasn't solved either is the fact that economy is all that matters.  If you don't build "perfectly" or if you start to leak, you fall behind and unless your opponent makes some massive mistakes you've already lost the game and are just dragging it out.

I personally haven't experienced any versions of this cloned game format where people who leak, have a slower economy early on, or otherwise make a few mistakes are able to come back and win (all things being equal).  I expect the typical argument here will be "But if your enemy has a leaver you can maybe win!"  or  "Maybe they'll hit a special wave or two that they aren't prepared for!?!?!"

In both of those situations, you're relying entirely on luck vs skill.  Getting lucky that the enemy has someone flat out quit the game or somehow start leaking enough to actually let you catch up isn't enjoyable.

EDITING MY REVIEW

SO i am editing my review as I now have more hours. If you are looking for a casual game this is DEFINITELY something worth playing. If you are looking to get into ranked just dont. HERE IS AN EXAMPLE: 

You WILL be matched with a teamate who is possible MULTIPLE divisions below you. (Me diamond, teamate gold, enemies both plat). When you lose for obvious reasons you will then lose more ELO because well you were diamond and your enemies were plat. The dev team needs to look into REAL matchmaking and realize that the skill gap gets EXPONENTIALLY bigger the higher rank you go.

I know this will not change as many games have a failed ranking system, but here is my reasoning why I suggest avoiding the game if you are into ranked. I will probably continue to play it as a decompress from work but go play league of legends or something, at least its free.

Updating my review again.

I get bored with most games fairly quickly, but I've put well over 1,000 hours into LTD2 since it was first available on Steam many years ago. I still return to it almost daily for a game or two - obviously, LTD2 is very well designed.

There's a wide range of units and not a single one feels useless and there's a good balance between risk and reward, leading to a lot of variety in terms of play styles and strategy. There's 2v2 ranked play if you want to be very competitive, and a more laid back 4v4 mode for casual players like myself.

With the addition of weekly challenges (solo content), a campaign which can be played solo or with a friend, and a sandbox mode for testing builds, this is a fully fleshed out product. The amount of polish from such a small development team is commendable.

The community used to be extremely toxic but over time that problem seems to have resolved itself; much of this probably has to do with the FairPlay system which punishes poor behavior and auto-mutes people who've been reported frequently.

The developers, even after all of these years, are responsive to feedback and will talk to you on the forums and Discord to help you out with issues.

The game is okay for being released. There are a lot of quality of life match making concepts they could implement to improve the player base count. This game is a getting a negative review for atmosphere of mods and community helpers on discord.

I will split the review for those who would be new to this game and those who came here from WC3 days

WC3:
- Beautiful! You have the feeling that it is a Legion TD, but in the same time, it's like playing something else with the designs, colors and music.
- Some new things that did not exist in original - Mastermind class! Nice way to play something completely different than rest of the classes.
- Campaign! Even as Co-Op!

New People:
- Don't give up and don't stop learning. People from the original know the point of the game and you might find yourself overwhelmed by the amount of things, but game is easy to learn!
- Easy to get in Lobby with your friends and play together!
- A really nice learning curve from the Campaign, however, you might loose yourself when you switch from classes to Mastermind

Message to AutoAttack games:
- It would be great if you can add more classes. I know it's hard to maintain the balance, but I really believe that the community is the same as before and will provide a massive feedback!
- More mastermind options!
- More campaign options! (I know they are coming but I can't wait! :D )
- And this is just my honest opinion: x10! Remember it? I do. I would love to see x10 version of LTD in this game!
- Last but not least - provide some public website or Trello where community can share ideas with you and in the same time comment on each other's ideas.

Total Score: strong8 out of 10. Did not expect this gem to be so great! Love you all <3

It's currently my favorite strategy TD/auto battler game on Steam.
Endless replay value. There are aspects that are better in the Warcraft 3 custom map versions of the game (where the game originated). Although those are negligible, and I choose to play the Steam version over the currently supported Warcraft 3 versions (There may be a few versions, I believe team Oze is doing a great job with it though).
I like that the dev keeps releasing new units to keep the game fresh, as well as skins, however that brings me to my main criticism.
Skins are too costly/hard to acquire for free. The game already costs money, but the skins are priced like this is a free to play game. VERY expensive for a tiny skin you can barely see, and 95%+ are just recolors/textures, and not actually changing the 3D model in any way. The only ones that have any sort of change to the actual 3D model are I believe Fission Atom, MD Safety Mole, and Friendly Brute. Apologies if I missed any. I‚Äôm at about 960 hours in game, I‚Äôve currently bought 2 skins without spending additional money (green and a blue value which are not the highest) and have enough for 1 that is orange rarity (highest value). I dislike how you need a guild to acquire the premium currency for skins.
The card system is also very fun and a nice touch, you can unlock cards from playing and by going to the card shop where you have a chance to acquire rare cards and even the ever illusive secret cards (finally got one at 955 hours‚Ä¶), once you have a card you can put up a monument of that character on the side of your lane or use the character as your profile picture, this is an incredible idea for added flair and customization for players that does not affect power level or offer any actual gameplay advantage.

Ok, if you are reading the reviews of the game to know if it is worth for you I'm going to tell you if this game is for you:

* If you like auto battlers this is a good one.
* there are several game styles that you can choose, from some that are random like other auto battlers to more strategic/planified ones.
* the depth of this game is INSANE, it is easy to learn but extremely hard to master
* this game is very rewarding when you learn how to properly play it.

Learning how to play each unit and how to play economy is crucial to win the game. This is one of the most strategic auto-battlers that you can get. The price barrier... about that you have to understand that the developers took a huge risk in this game and also is in constant content patches and balancing is constantly happening, I would recommend this game if you are:

* Looking for an alternative to other auto-battlers like tft, or hearthstone battlegrounds (or not even an alternative, this is a great 1st choice)
* You like certain amount of randomness but not chaotic levels of randomness (that also is a possibility if you are willing to)
* A young but active competitive scene where there are actual cash money rewards.
* Constant meta developing.

A really lovely TD game.

Since the WC3 TD mods I'm in love with the TD genre and am always in search of games that give me similar feelings to that (for me) good ol' "WC3 TD mods- time. Legion TD 2 comes in closest for me. The game is already fun, but gets with every update (so far) better and better. 
The units feel unique and fun to use. Overall everything is relatively balanced and it seems that the devs have an eye for overused or overperforming units needing some tweaks and act accordingly through their patch releases.
The graphics are good, but nothing too impressive. Don't expect some fancy light show like on TFT maybe, but a pleasant view for the eye.
Also the game is beginner friendly with an extensive tutorial and many easy-to-understand tooltips - not like some other auto battler-TD's (looking again at TFT). You quickly get an understanding on what every unit does and what's recommended to use. The game practically looks out for you and even tells you after a loss where you might have decided wrong.
There are different game modes, like Campaign/Custom against AI/against other players or the "Weekly Challenge". The campaign isn't fully released yet, so I can't say much about it. So far it's fun, but short. You can get different/better ratings on how well you do. Custom against AI are just games. You can choose the AI-difficulty that applies to all AI players in the game. Right now, you can't choose for every AI individually. If you choose hard, every AI is on hard. Custom against other players is the online mode. You get it. The "Weekly Challenge" is just beating someone else's score. This is interesting for learning other people's strategies and having some sort of ladder/ranked/competition place.

So what's not to like or rather not (yet) to my/your/our liking?
The AI:
If you play with or against AI, some choices it makes seem kinda random and inconsistent. There are games where you get swarmed with stuff they send against you or where they are practically a better teammate than you. I remember one or two games where a silver (=easy-ish) AI gave me more pressure than some gold (=shouldn't be as easy-ish) AI. You can somewhat take it with a grain of salt that the AI isn't that consistent and forth not that easy to read/predict.

The enemy waves stay the same every game:
This is somewhat of a 50/50 nice/bad thing. On one hand you can "learn" the waves and develop your perfect strategies against the enemies every round. You know what to expect every round (you can even see it in a small preview at the top of the screen). On the other hand this may get a bit boring, especially if your enemies - may it be real players or some player-AI - don't send extra stuff over to you. Here I'd say would be some more variation welcomed.

There is no endless waves mode:
The game always ends/wins with the enemy team losing their king unit if too many mobs broke through their defenses and depleting the king units health to zero. For me that happens usually in the 15th round (if I'm playing against AI). This is sometimes really annoying, since around then you may really love your army and have developed some awesome strategy to defend for days. Here I'd appreciate it if there was some new mode to come in to really deep dive on strategy stuff.

However, i do have a gripe with its match-making, where i tried to do a ranked match with a friend and we couldn't get to play together, which is really annoying and the match gets cancelled with out proper reasons.
But, besides that, its a good game, and is actually worth the money in my opinion.

The best Tower Defense game ever. There are many aspects in the defense, mainly:
- building "fighters" to defend your lane, positioning, types and compatibility/synergy
- building with another builder on a combined lane (good for playing with friends, kind of like co-op) to defend the lane
- building "workers" to get income 
- attacking opponents with "summons", identifying the right type to send on different waves and depending on what your opponent's fighters are
- strategy, going full income or complementing teammates' weaknesses
- deciding whether to upgrade the "king" which you are to protect
- builder types - random, fixed, income etc.

Very in-depth game and an endless learning journey. The learning curve is a little steep at first, it took me around 10 games to get a hang of all the mechanics (1 game = 10-30 mins) and was a whole lot of fun after. 
The matchmaking time is around 1-2mins, there's a rank system, a discord server for all the discussions and strategies etc. and twitch streams.

Great game! You can play casually, there is very little stress, compared to many other competitive games. Community is nice in general, very little harassment is encountered.
Playing duo with a friend is the best way to enjoy the game. Solo is also an option, but a way lesser one, imo.
Devs are very active.

What is this game anyway?
The basic game loop is:
Purchase towers (units), purchase mercenaries, purchase 'King' upgrades, invest in workers -> your units defend your lane from current hostile creature wave and enemy player mercenaries -> repeat
In case that you fail to defend yourself, your 'King' will be attacked by leaked units, he is the last line of defense and once he falls, you lose.

What makes the game interesting and fresh is the fact that your tower choice is always very limited and random; the random part is fair, it has a rules that it uses to give you random units, so you generally have something that works.
There is, however, a non-competitive tutorial mode, either a campaign, or regular vs AI mode, that you can use to get hang of the game with pre-selected units.

There is an economy that you also manage, so apart from being able to think of a build from random selection of towers, you need to minimize your spending on towers, maximize your spending on workers (that help you get more money in the long run).

It's a complex game overall. I've played 118 hrs so far and I wouldn't say that I have mastered any part of the game, the amount of unique interactions is on par with DotA and similar games.

Can't say anything greater than the game says itself. Played the WC3 mod for years and years, and this stand alone adaptation is everything I've wanted and more. If you're a fan of strategic TD games with an added PvP undertone, this is the game for you!

If you love TD games, Autobattlers, or the strategy part of MOBAs this is the game for you.

Once upon a time there were TD games. They got boring because the towers were all the same.
--Then came MOBAs and they were great, but very stressful and involved, also require clicking at exactly the right minute.
 --Then came the autobattlers. Which were awesome, had a variety of units, but very RNG heavy.

Along comes LegionTD2:
All 4 players play against 21 standard creep waves and do your best to farm/repel the waves. using your autobattler units. Use $ to add creeps to waves of your choice to make your enemy's job harder(impossible).

Pros: 
-Not Pay2Win. The purchase of the game covers everything, except skins.(a few options vs bots unlocked with in game free currency, but not needed for MP)
-15~60 second to find a ranked match.
-Excellent AI. Gold plays as well as a 1400 player.
-Diverse units that each play very differently.
-Tons of strats and synergies, no perfect META
-Very little "Luck" most plays are math, not RNG.
-Decide how much RNG you want in your unit selection. A. choose a FIXED set of 6. B: Pick 1 and 5/9 randoms. C: to pick 6/10 D: Random 6 every turn.
-Game lasts for 15-30 minutes.

Cons: 
1. My friends are mad that I stopped playing other MOBAs and mods of them.
2. I want skins for my units and mercs!

A very faithful adaption of the classic Warcraft 3 mod "Legion TD". 

For those new to the game:
Legion TD is a co-op competitive tower defense game. In the standard multiplayer modes you and 1-3 others all have a lane of incoming enemies that all join together and attack your "King" - if your King dies - you lose. On the other side will be an equal sized team of opponents doing the same as you.

The game is round based, every round a wave of enemy units with various strength and weaknesses will spawn and attack your towers (which respawn with full health every round). Any enemies that you fail to kill will go and try to attack your king but if you clear all the enemies in your lane then your forces will teleport in front of your king to protect him from any "leaked" enemies from your allies lanes. The enemies in each round are the same but your opponents (and you) also have the options to send various extra enemy units with the wave to try and break through the defenses.

The main complexity of the gameplay is balancing the two resources in the game - Gold and Mythium. You spend your gold on building all of your Towers but you can also spend gold on Workers - these are non combat units that mine Mythium and increase your rate of Mythium acquisition. Mythium is used only for sending extra enemy units with the wave to attack your opponents defenses but this also provides consistant Gold income every round depending on the enemy you choose to send (generally the more Mythium it costs - the more Gold income it provides). What this means is that you always want to maximise worker production while building just enough towers to not allow any enemies through - the more efficiently you do this the more exponential your income growth can become. There is too much strategy to really get into too much depth here but this game has some serious replayability compared to other TD games due to this design.

For those who have played the Mod enough to know what to expect:
Everything you expect should be here - most of the units from the original game are here with several interesting changes and additions that allow for new strategies. Mastermind or randomised towers is the most common way to play as you get an additional bonus you can pick from 20 or so options including things like "+3 income and +3 rerolls", "+5 income and 1 reroll", "44 income after wave 10" and all sorts of interesting things.

The game seems pretty active and only takes a couple of minutes at most to find a game, all in all I have nothing to criticize.

Exceedingly well balanced, incredible deep strategy, and a learning curve that while initially steep, quickly becomes satisfying makes this one of the best strategic team games I've ever encountered. This is as close to chess as the genre gets. The fact that the community is overwhelmingly positive with few toxic players seals the deal. Can't recommend this highly enough.

Super fire. I was looking at this game for about a year because I used to just play the arcade mode TD games on SC2 and wasn't sure if it was worth the 20 bucks. It went on sale so I swooped it up. I am loving it. 8 races, lots of units, I've put in lots about 22 hours so far and I am still itching to play it every day, so much to learn and try. Definitely happy with this purchase. I do really hope they continue to keep content coming like different maps, seasonal events, altered game modes, new races/units. Hopeful for continual content support, but overall legit game.

Pros:
-Classic mode is very fun because its 4v4 which is the core gameplay of the original custom map in WC3, Ranked is only 2v2

-A varieties of units you can choose from and mix and match to create powerful combos

-Basically the same mechanics from Legion TD on WC3 (building towers, making workers and sending for income)

Con:
-The units you can send to attack your opponent in the game isn't balanced because you can send any of the higher cost units early which will have very high stats if you just save mythium. This means that some guy can save mythium from round 1 all the way to round 9 and send anything with very high stats on a boss wave with only needing to invest a few workers. Weird thing is I remember the original Legion TD game have a way around this by not letting you send high cost units until after wave 10.

-Shutdown mechanics is a joke, a majority of the players either don't care to use it to their advantage or straight up doesn't know what it is. When the enemy team is already ahead and this mechanics take effect you would still need a good amount of workers combine with saving for a round or two just to try and attempt to leak the enemies. Which means you only get rewarded after you manage to leak the enemies, so unless you constantly leak them when the bounty is at 100 golds or higher it won't do much to help you catch up.

-The game is very reliant on having good teammates. The opponent that you are sending units to aren't the one sending stuffs to you, so if your teammate won't send auras and strong units on important waves to force them to not go all in on income you will just be forced to just build units to try to prevent leaks. If your teammates won't help then the only option is just to watch yourself losing slowly the game because your income isn't up to par to build more units in late game.

-The game doesn't have a match making system in place to prevents better players from being matched against new players and those who are trying to learn. So matches are often just one sided, very rarely will you get in a match that will have most players on the same skill level. This is terrible if you are new to this game and are trying to learn how to play and what to do. 
Edit: The new match making system is terrible it will match you with any players from any ratings so its basically nonexistence.

UI has been improved a lot and the team continues to reiterate and add more updates all the time!  I'm absolutely loving this game now and it's become my most played of the past couple years.   Great PVP elements!

It's a very fun game, well worth giving a shot. Gameplay takes about 15 to 30 minutes per game and while it can get rather formulaic tactics wise especially once you start getting into Gold Ranked matches, there is enough variations that you need to start playing a lot of games to feel like you've seen everything before. 

Matchmaking is quick, most of the time I can get a match within two minutes and it is extremely rare for matchmaking to take longer than three minutes. The server connection is astonishing to me, I'm from the USA and I've played with Germans, Canadians, Danish, Australians, Argentinians, Brazilians, Czechs*, French, British, and even a few Russians with very few game ruining connection issues. Most of the time I don't notice a thing or the fighters are just a little out of sync for a bit.

*No idea what the proper term the people of the Czech Republic is so I just went with the ethnic group.

I'm not too active in the community but most people that I've run into are communicative and willing to work together to secure the win. The pinging system works pretty well for general communication so that you typically don't need to make use of the ingame chat.

I would note that the first match after booting the game up always takes far longer than normal to the point that I've often just left the game running in the background so that I won't have to wait through the load when I'm in the mood to play again that day. Also there is some sort of bug with closing down the game itself because exiting the game will cause it to freeze and stop responding, usually requiring me to hard shut down the game with a few rare times having the game shut down after a while frozen.

Your goal is to get past the other team's defenses and defeat their king.

I discovered this game a few months ago, and absolutely loved the game. I think it's a very high quality game, with a lot of great elements. 

The learning curve is a bit steep but not too much. Some concepts require subtle knowledge, but the community is awesome, whether on twitch or on youtube, and you can get most of your questions answered there. 

What I liked : 
x the pace of the game : each game is around 20min and it feels like the right timing. 
x the community and all the ressources to learn. 
x the soloplayer campaign in solo and hard mode.
x all the subtleties and complexity of the game. 
x games are super explosive, and can blow up at any time. 
x game overall pretty well balanced, a lot of viable comps.

What feels a bit harder : 
x The learning curve : quite many units to learn when starting, and some of the more subtle concepts are harder to grasp (different types of sends, etc). 
x if your computer is a bit old, loading times can be a bit long for first game of the day.
Fun game! PvP oriented. Requires equal parts strategy and discipline to win.

TL;DR; The learning curve is frustrating, nothing makes sense. In 2v2 as a total noob, I progressed up to nearly 2000 ELO / Expert rank. After 500 games I have a lot of knowledge, but get stuck in Platinum forever despite a positive win rate, because I play with random teammates, and 9 of 10 matches against 2v2 parties are losses. It's extremely unfair.

Long Version:
The only competitive mode is 2v2, but it totally gets ruined for me, because random teams must play against premade party teams all the time, and it's extremely unfair, there are 100 reasons why 2v2 party teams have a clear advantage. I'm losing 9 out of 10 games when I play with a random teammate against premade parties, I could just alt+f4 and leave, it wouldn't change the outcome.
Especially on Saturdays, when people play for guild rewards, there's more than half of the games against premade. It ruins all the fun and I can't progress. Teammates also get toxic, and frustrated. 

Then, the whole learning curve and rank progression does not make sense at all. It goes downwards. The more I learn, the more I lose. I came to this game with zero knowledge, no guides, no builds, no Twitch/YouTube, not splitting, not knowing all auras, not even reading the special abilities and spells of units. I only played auto-send and only saved if my teammate made a call, but I did not even know what good sends are.

Yet it took me less than 100 games to hit Platinum rank, about 150 to be Diamond, and then around 200 games I was close to 2000 ELO / Expert rank, or in fact it said my rank was top 1.2%
However, from then on, I had some technical difficulties, lots of disconnects, and I went down to Platinum 4, and then I never made it higher than Platinum 1 again. That's 300 games stuck between Plat4 and Plat1, and this is mostly because 90% of the games against parties are losses.

There's no way to properly learn how to play this game, when parties are completely unpredictable. They might have a special strategy / build prepared, that they will perform, no matter what. They might save 4 or even 7 rounds in a row... You can't exactly predict what they have in mind.
I've played lots of competitive multiplayer games, and I usually hit the top 2% ranks in every single game that I stick to, but on this game I just don't know what to do anymore, it all seems random, and the matchmaking is unfair which prevents you from learning and progressing.

Btw, the release date of this game says 1st of October 2021, I started playing early 2022, and thought this is a new game, and that I'd meet lots of new players - but it's not! Steam Charts tells me, there have been players in October 2017 already, and in game you can see that this is the 9th season already! I thought I'd buy a quite new game that is growing, but it's the opposite. There've been lots of toxic old players, who were raging at round 1, just because they've checked my profile and raged that they were teamed up with a new player, despite my always positive win rate.

I've never had fun playing this game without friends, simply because the mechanics are so over-punishing and insufferable (to a certain degree). 

Each match contains 20(+1) waves of tower defense. In between, you build your units, buy workers, etc. The problem is that if you mess up or place the wrong (economically and strategically) units during the first 5-10 waves, you're screwed for the rest of the match and become a liability to your teammates. So, why the hell should someone undergoing this stay throughout the match? Of course, they punish you for leaving early... but I'd rather spend my time doing something productive than being helpless while watching the enemy team dominate you for the next 10-15 minutes.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I actually love playing this game with my friends, but I [i]heavily[/i] dislike that this game requires a constant connection to Steam, despite having a single-player campaign, an in-game unit codex to learn from, and a sandbox mode to plan your strategies. What I'm saying is you cannot access [i]any[/i] element of the game, including solo play, when offline. I also didn't realize LAN play was not at all supported, and therefore apparently [i]all[/i] gameplay happens only via Steam connection. To that end, [b]Legion TD 2 uses Steam as a form of always-online DRM[/b], and I don't like that in the least bit.

I thought I had purchased a standalone product, and not a license to connect to an online service. This information wasn't communicated by the store page. I prefer to own the games I buy, not to be forced to play them during some arbitrary "oh ho ho, but will it still be accessible in the future?" timeline. The gameplay is good, but this license model is seriously disappointing, and would be more at home in a free-to-play title.

This game is great. I've managed a thousand hours, and it's my downtime game for sure. 

There are still mindboggling issues, though, and some of them are: 
- The countdown for mythium is still 0.5-1.0 seconds delayed, after all of this time.
- The fighter value-counter, which measures how well you're doing round-to-round, is still not even remotely accurate five-ish years after the Beta was released.
-  No way to make sure a toxic player isn't in your next queue; you can only mute them whilst in-game. 
- The XP counter takes ages to ever go up. I play a lot, and getting far in the levels (and with little-to-no reward, too....) is time-consuming in a manner I've never witnessed in other games. 
- No way to give feedback, even for an indie game. That's always been odd. 
- The amount of content's gone up, but still lacks in basically every aspect. 

Other than that, a thousand hours speaks for itself. This is a great game. Easy to get into, beautifully difficult to master.

After over 300 hours of play this is my synopsis.  

High potential game with tons of strategy, nuance, and mechanics that doesn't have the population for fair match making in any mode.  In addition, they make incomplete changes to units such as nerfing units but not nerfing their costs.  I'm the type of player that doesn't read patch notes.  I like to sort of figure it out and make mistakes on my own.  So obviously some frustration I bring on myself.  But the way they make changes make virtually zero sense.  For example, they will nerf the power of a unit but not the gold cost.  They will buff the power of unit without increasing its gold costs.  So you basically have this weird situation where some units are more powerful per gold than others.  Power doesn't translate perfectly either b/c there is sort of a strategic set up required.  Where you place units matters.  So if they do a small buff without increasing gold cost on a high utility unit then it's broken strong.  People will gravitate toward that unit or series of units in matches.  It's horribly unbalanced, inconsistent at times, and the matchmaking is designed to rapidly make games as opposed to focusing on quality.  Most people I speak with don't mind the difference between 1 min and 5 min in a queue for a match in any game.  What's 4 more minutes for quality.  I found myself going back because it was a great way to pass the time but I'm just sick and tired of the game at this point not having the consistency from developers that it should.  High potential game with low investment from developers for quality.  

I don't recommend the game as there are many better strategy based games out there that are more polished and offer better pvp matchmaking options.

I don't think this game knows what to be.

This is not really a tower defense game in that you don't place pieces to "intercept" a coming wave.  It is a grid of pieces you place like chess.  But you don't really play against your opp characters. There is this "middle-ware" layer (for lack of a better term) that you attack your opp with.

It would have been much simpler and better IMHO if it was a just single vertical or horizontal lane that your game pieces fought directly against their game pieces.  I think it would have been much more exciting and much more variant.

Also,I have to say,  I got really frustrated toggling between my "defense" lane and my "offense" lane to see what fighters vs. mercs I should (have) pick(ed).  The only way to see your opp characters is during fighting, yet you can't really see how to develop your defense without seeing the mercs they picked.

In the end, it wasn't fun anymore, because the game is all about this very nuanced balance between leveling up your "defense" and buying your "offense".  In order to learn nail that subtle nuance, there is an extreme amount of mind-numbing reps to put in first.

Nice try, but I gotta uninstall - sorry.

Actually a great TD. If you've enjoyed the good old legion td wc3 map, you'll love this.
If you haven't played that, you'll definitely still like the game if you're into TD.
The game is a coop pvp TD, but unlike other competitive games doesn't really put any stress on you, just build how you want or strategically leak whatever you want. 
Besides the TD aspect, the game introduces a great economic aspect, you really have to watch what you and your teammates get sent, what units your opponent builds and act accordingly. Or just spam workers and pray your teammates can defend whatever you leak while you increase you net worth.
There are different "mastermind" play styles that add a tweek to how you play, and none of them are strictly "bad".

Honestly, the gaming mechanics are inexplicable. It is a very frustrating game to enjoy. It rewards lower tier players by giving them an unfair advantage. For ex. During a classic game, as you progress throughout 21 waves, you obtain income from the monsters while defending and attacking. It costs gold, achieved through income, to purchase monsters that you place to attack. So, if I start wave 1 at 5 income and player 2 starts wave 1 with 32  income. By the time the wave 10 comes around. They've already compounded their income to the point where they can purchase an extra few monsters to defend and workers to attack with. Just causes a very unfavorable gaming experience. Especially, if you're playing against multiple players like a 4 vs 4. Not enjoyable when 1 game can take up to 40 mins. Game mechanics require a more level playing field.

4-14-21 edit. Creators have implemented a rebalance which makes the game a tad bit more favorable and "fair". There is a hint of unbalance still. However, with skill and a little bit of luck. You can over come the adversity. Which really bumps up the thrill and excitement of coming back and winning a game. Still a few things I'm sure will be tweaked over time. But I really like where this game is going. Would recommend at this point.

[h1]Feb 2022:[/h1]

[b]TL;DR:[/b]
[i]"Players are going to find abusive mathematical strategies over and over, despite you taking the time to properly play and learn the game, you're still the one setup to lose if you don't abuse mathematics."[/i]

Before you jump in to trash a down vote review, this is to get your attention, you have to respect the issue I would like to present you with this game at the time of date mentioned above.

The good/great thing about this game:
Despite the small budget the devs had to work with, they made a good product visually and mechanically it's almost bug free & it is engaging. Now you're wondering why I'm down voting. What ruins a potential fun match is simply because there are too many mathematical loop holes that players are abusing and it's a little difficult to fix this sort of issue because it seems to be a complicated math problem (specifically with abusing resources by withholding on myth and releasing powerful units at early levels). This is a math problem devs need to look into.

[b]Practical example:[/b] More often than not, I play against opponents holding back on sending with mythium but release all they got on level 10. I received today a kraken on level 10 and my allies received something not far from that. I've had similar experiences cause us to lose with even less powerful units at the same level stage.

[b]You're unfortunately setup to lose regardless how well you play the game's intended mechanics.[/b] Players are going to find abusive mathematical strategies over and over, despite you taking the time to properly play and learn the game and read up on forums, you're still the one setup to lose if you don't abuse mathematics. Not because your allies are bad or because your opponents are good players. Rather because you can abuse math to your advantage. Making this game... a mathematics focused game (regardless of dev intentions) with a facade of 3D modelled characters, animations, sound effects, etc... that may make us feel that there's something more going on.

It's not poorly designed product in any way and obviously most games are based on this fundamental.

But what I'm trying to articulate for you is, more often than not, you will face matches where there's nothing you can do, your opponents are not necessarily good at playing the game's intended mechanics, rather they just found a loop hole with mathematics to survive long enough to unleash an end game unit on to your lane from the very first boss (lvl10 - I received a kranken, like what?).

I've been putting the time to learn strategies, different damage and armor types and positionings and auras and units to send on what units and analyze what my opponent is building... all of that just for me to deal with a kraken on level 10...

If the devs genuinely fix that, I will review this over time if I don't lose my temper due to this none sense math matches, I will edit the post and recommend this game when the time is right.

This is the most enjoyable game I've downloaded in a long time.
A great mix of RTS and tower defense with tons of strategic value.  There are tournaments (at the time of writing 2022) with real cash prizes, and constant balance updates.
8 different families of creatures to cast and mastermind options from YOLO where you just get a random set of creatures to Greed, where you are limited to one reroll and get a little extra starting cash.
If you get into the competitive Esport stuff, there's practically endless replayablity.  And 6 tiers of bots you can play with.
It is a team game, so whether playing against AI or ranked matches, you will always be paired with a friend or random (or an ai if you are playing against the bots alone).  You can play with up to four players on a team, but that's more a fun feature and not super balanced.  It is made for two vs two.
The AI is competent (depending on the tier of bot) and challenging until you learn the really technical stuff, like which wave has which weakness and which creature is good against it, how many you need to clear it, whether you should send mercenaries to your opponent, whether you expect them to send against you, and of course balancing economy vs attack/defense strength.
Quick tip: learn to split and when to buy workers from youtube.  It's really helpful.  At the end of the game they display the grid, the creatures on it, money, power, ect for each turn of the game, to learn where you made mistakes, or when the opponent tricked you to push when he had a long send stashed away.
Like I said, a great and strategic game (based on a warcraft 3 mod (like dota) at a very reasonable price.  They have monthly tournaments.  Prize pools are small for now, but you never know when an Esport is going to be popular.
Buy it.

The single player alone is worth it on this update to the classic OG Autobattler-Tower Defense. QOL updates include giving you heads up on the attack and defense types of upcoming waves, a nice clean interface, and estimated recommended gold values to hold the next wave, updated dynamically based on your opponent.  Additional content includes variable builder types; like Castle (You start with less income, and gain a massive boost after the first boss), Chaos (your available towers are randomized each round), and 6 others to mix up and customize your playstyle.  The interactive dev team, simple but effective and visually distinct graphics, and many different builder types make it well worth it.

On the surface Legion Tower Defense is a spin on tower defense that weaves upgrade and build mechanics between waves of unit vs unit action.

Daunting at first-glance, It's actually very easy to get into. The in-game quick-references are very readable and useful. It's fun to pick up and play with friends.

Hidden under the relative simplicity is a numbers game that combines strategy, game knowledge, and some luck which allows for a wide breath of skill expression. The players that are very good at this game are very good at it.

[h1]Legion TD 2, a lackluster Battle net port[/h1]

While many players no doubt will remember Legion TD the popular tower defense game set using old Blizzard assets in custom game modes, the owners of this IP have indeed finally moved out from this bloated shadow and into the light as their own product. Featuring a few new gameplay options of 2v2, 4v4, and previously for limited time, 1v1. 

First of all, this isn't a tower defense game. Originally it made its entrance as such in Blizzard but the new game features a total of 2 towers. This is better classified as a competitive tactical autobattler, which leads me to the second major problem, the lack of gameplay. Due to this being a port with little design effort, Legion TD 2 is unfortunately a small group effort, and while its developers do still put in effort on development, it can be said at this point they spend more time on hype and attention. The basic fact of the game is that there's only 21 rounds, and due to the lack of unit flexibility and importance of placement, you really don't have much interaction with the game itself. You will often find issues with the AI units on both sides outright ignoring your tactical placements, poorly balanced units that serve no purpose other than to detract from your teams strength, and frequently encounter both graphical issues and gameplay hang-ups where waves get stuck resulting in all players waiting nearly 5 minutes for a background timer to notice something is wrong. Oddly for an autobattler, units excluding a few all follow the same path of a single upgrade. There's little to no unit customization in a genre that calls for adjusting and tuning units based on the wave battle system. Resulting in the entire gameplay loop being building more units rather than having any further unit improvement options. Even compared to its fellow Blizzard tower defense games, Legion TD is quite empty for upgrading. This may be in part due to the small team and attempts to balance gameplay further or part of their own design.

Secondly, it's now a fully competitive game. This is different than launch as originally the classic mode was essentially unranked and they had 2v2 set specifically for ranking. Now regardless if your a casual chill player, you are ranked in every game mode. This is extremely problematic when your rank will enter the top few thousand just by occasionally playing matches, [b]even by losing[/b]. Within a matter of hours you might well be fighting the top few hundred people in this games community who no life this game and live off of spreadsheets and patch notes. This is the real problem since gameplay swings heavily based on the economic situation you maintain via sending units and building workers. Once you reach this point you'll often find yourself inexplicably outclassed by various meta strategies, outright cheese, and people who risk their entire team just to build workers in order to destroy you. Gameplay choices where you'll find your own teammates griefing in order to build up gold, playstyle Fiesta, as it's called. Along with a host of other numerous small frustrations that leave you pondering the actual thought that made it through. 

However again, this is a small group effort project and they're bringing us this specific vision of a game. When the entire project team is less than a dozen people it's far easier to end up with glaring blind spots in design. As such if your interest is in a competitive autobattler that contains co-op elements, this is for you! I highly recommend bringing at least one, but for reliable gameplay I'd advise bringing three. If your interested in this if it was a tower defense, I recommend wishlisting this game. The developers have stated towers might be the way of the future unit releases. If you aren't a big fan of either, I highly recommend you don't buy this game as it's quite niche and you will not find any unique or exciting gameplay originality here.

My introduction, and addiction, to this style of game began with Squadron TD custom game mode in SC2. Legion TD2 is a well-polished entry in a long line of supremely popular custom maps. 

Pros: 

Great gameplay
My favorite type of indirect PVP (defend and send)
Depth of strategy and unit interaction (placement is VERY important)

Cons

Slightly dated graphics and UI, but I personally enjoy it
Difficult learning curve for new players (join the Discord and watch FlightTV to learn!)

The community is much smaller than many other games, but with a very active base I think this game fills a much needed niche in the currently oversaturated market of Autochess/TFT type games, autobattlers, etc. None of those games have the consistency of carry over game-to-game that Legion has and personally I think the balance of RNG in the form of randomizing but allowing for selection of units is a great mix to allow for skill expression while introducing enough variety to keep you coming back.

Legion TD 2 is the sequel to Warcraft 3's Legion TD strategic auto-battling custom map that was doing auto chess better  well over a decade before auto chess even existed(?).

Game itself is endlessly intriguing and is well balanced with only a few outliers.
Its depth allows for a variety of different playstyles and a wealth of opportunities for player expression.   
It is easy to get hooked into experimenting with different unit positionings, economic strategies, ...

Unfortunately, cosmetic and casual progression are both reminiscent of a free-to-play game: expensive and glacial.   Developers say that this is just due to issues of scale, but honestly, models like these are rarely (if ever) reversed.
An older and arguably better auto chess style tower defense game, a sequel to the Warcraft 3 custom game. Legion TD 2 is truly unique and fun.

The developers and their team are awesome despite being only a small team of 4. They consistently communicate with the community and listen to suggestions regarding balancing, game modes, and anything related to the game. They host tournaments with prizes for players and even host lower ranked divisions so everyone has a chance to get involved. 

The player base is not huge as it is a pretty niche game/genre, but I enjoy that aspect of it as the community is smaller than usual at the higher ranks and you get to know the community more personally. Player base is generally incredibly friendly and it is rare to encounter toxic teammates in this game.

After hundreds of hours of play, and a long ago posted positive review, the Devs sent me an E-mail asking me to review the game.  Again.  I assume this was sent as a mass message to all the players in hopes of drumming up positive feedback.  Beware what you wish for.

I have been playing Legion TD since it was a WC3 map and the steam version since before it was paid.  If I was required to pay for the game today, I'd simply uninstall it.  It's tollerable as a free to play game, but if I wanted to pay for toxicity, abuse and frustration I'd look at Blizzard products.

Primary reasons for changing my previous positive review to negative:

- The toxicity hasn't gotten better.  The higher you climb in the ranks, the worse it gets.  The lower ranks are filled with great players who are just there to have fun and don't really care much about winning big or progression, or are just learning still.  Manage to win too much though, and you'll be faced with a barrage of bs that will remind you of the worst of Fortenight or Rust.

- The new 1v1 match is a great concept, if matchmaking wasn't completely cluster-f'd.  Over the few days I've played, there have been multiple instances of going against the same player several times in a row.  Which is fine if you are evenly matched in skill, and better if you're winning, but to the one who's losing to the same person over and over, it just makes it not worth playing.  Eventually your ranking drops so low that you'll start playing other people who are supposedly closer to your level...till you start trouncing on them over and over, then go back to the same person who was just beating on you before.

- A lack of autotranslate or more robust communication feature.  With a game that is this global with so many players in other countries, the very limited in game flywheel communication system doesn't allow much in the way of strategy or understanding between a very diverse player group, and will usually lead to misunderstanding, irritation and repeated lack of victory.

A good game with interesting and engaging strategy and tactics requirements.

Feels like, I suppose literally is, a professionally made custom-map from WC3. That second part is the downside. WC3 custom maps were often these wild and crazy things for of all sorts of stupid ideas. You'd have 300 towers with all sorts of crazy synergies, you had no idea wtf was going on half the time, and you'd do something new every other game just to explore the game.

This game has none of that. There are hardly any "towers" (or auto-battling units), they rarely have abilities and when they do they're not any exciting. There are almost no synergies to speak of. Every game would be identical if the game didn't have completely-RNG "rerolls" that let you randomly roll available towers to build, another terrible idea that makes the game extremely boring after a while. You get like 6 available towers, and while you can choose some "masterminds" to allow you several rerolls, but even with the RNG, because the number of towers is so low, the games all feel the same. You use the strategy you've learned to be best so far, until you learn a better one and then you use that one instead, no real thought behind it, with the RNG ultimately making it less varied and more frustrating as you keep rolling shit lineups that aren't fun to play.

Game would be more fun with ten times as many towers five times as many available to build at any given time, with more mechanics and abilities than you can keep track of. Of course, that would be borderline impossible to balance. Which is what makes "professional" games so fucking boring. They have to be balanced to be good and serious games. So they just end up being pretty boring, at the end of the day.

It's one of those games where if you are average to casual, it's a lot of fun and you'll probably enjoy yourself. It's competitive tower defense and the available interactions between your defense, offense, and economy provide meaningful choices and a lot of options for play style.

The result of the game rests on the slimmest hair, and rarely do you feel like you have a major influence on which way it skews.

Literally impossible. So you do the same. And high level play devolves into everyone just throwing and taking haymakers until someone dies.

Keep in mind it's more of an auto-battler than a tower defense game (but obviously, only the latter term existed back then during the time it was a Warcraft 3 mod). So, less like Bloons TD 6 and more like DOTA Underlords.

I think that compared to most auto-battlers, Legion TD 2 is the most dynamic. You control what mercenaries to send over to your enemies along with the mobs in the wave. You have to mind your workers because they give you mythium, the currency that allows you to buy & send mercenaries. If you purchase too many workers and spend most of your funds, you will be left with weaker defenses for the wave. If you don't buy enough workers, you won't have enough mythium to reach your opponent's King and win the game.

It's very strategic and you have to constantly read what your opponent is doing and adapt accordingly - there is no unique composition build that wrecks all others, and there's no single strategy that you employ all the time and it's infalible (veterans with 2k hours in the game might disagree but whatever). The balancing is also decent, and every unit plays out differently with their own gimmick - they're not just stat point sponges that are better than the cheaper stat point sponges.

That may sound daunting, but the matchmaking of the game has been quite good as far as I've played. You can always practice against bots or jump to the ranked play that will put you with closely ranked players. The newbie ranked players I went up against seemed to know as little as I did, and the higher I went (from bronze 4 to gold 3) the tougher the opponents were - with some being better than me, but not *that* much that it felt unfair and unbalanced. That said, of course players in a voice chat will have an advantage, but the matchmaking gives them opponents of a higher rank to compensate.

There isn't much content to learn about the game, but what we have is very detailed and thorough. I learned to play from reading the Steam guides, watching youtube videos about the basics from veteran players, and by playing the game itself & watching what my opponents were doing.

In-short, it's an easy to learn but complex, hard to master game due to mechanical complexity (splitting, sends, econ builds, damage resistance similar to Warcraft 3 etc.). It's a game that requires patience to learn and acceptance that you'll fail and misplay a lot until you finally start getting the hang of it, and even then you'll keep on failing. But for those who appreciate the strategic value and complexity of the game, it's very worth it.

I have really enjoyed this game. This is my first game I have every played with match making services ( I prefer to play single player or online co op with friends only). Overall this has been a pleasant first experience with a good game play loop. It requires a lot of thinking and teamwork to win if you want to go with the co op experience. I have never encountered anyone who was slaying slurs or being toxic. The worst most people can get it someone who does not communicate at all or someone who just leaves. The bots will take over for them which is nice. 

Pros:

Solid devoted community
Polite player base
Not pay to win (you can buy skins for certain units but it is only cosmetic and not forced upon you)
Nice and hardworking devs
Really addicting gameplay loop
Solid single player campaign
Sandbox mode to test out builds
A really fast, easy, and simple tutorial

Cons

Matchmaking can take up to a unit
Not a huge game like Dota 2 (1000- ~2500 in game at a time from what I have seen)
Ranked is frustrating because the only way to go up is in duos and partners can be non communicative and make you lose a match because you don't coordinate sends and king upgrades
Sometimes the match up can be a bit unfair (Two Gold 2s VS Gold 4 and Silver 1)

The servers are stable and people from all over the world can play and enjoy the game. I have really enjoyed my time in it and met some really awesome people. The game is worth a shot if you want a laid back tower defence strategy experience. It is very well made and has a great non toxic community with hardworking devs. The game would really benefit from adding new players into the mix so definitely go buy it and check it out!

I don't necessarily enjoy this game as much as other tower defenses I've played, and it's certainly not as eye catching as something like Bloons or Clash Royale, but Legion is devastatingly complex and infinitely replayable, so massive props for that. Theoretically you could play for the rest of time and never have two games even remotely similar, and I do have to admire the commitment from the devs to make something DEEP. Coming with that territory is of course the insane learning curve. I barely scratched the surface in about a 6 hour grind session. I was instantly intrigued, but I also haven't really felt the need to come back. It does scratch the itch for a competitive multiplayer game with layers on layers of strategy that would take a lifetime to master, but I also don't know how rewarding it feels. It's one of those classic situations where I admire the game more than I enjoy it, but I don't have much negative to say other than that.

Great game that really hits the itch from classic WC3 or SC2 custom games. 

It has deep strategic elements and keeps it fresh through the mastermind mode (ranked) were you get random towers to choose between. You can never figure one strategy out and go with that every time. Instead you need to constantly adapt your plan, both to the towers available to you and to your opponents playstyle and stratey. Once you really start to see the depth and complexity needed to balance between safety and economy it gets very addictive and fun.

I would compare it to auto battlers like leagues TFT and add that its simply better. While auto battlers put you at the mercy of RNG through which heros you can buy and what items you get there is no RNG in Legion TD, you never feel like you got screwed by bad luck/or other people simply having better luck. I noticed other reviewers complaining that its a team game and will also add that in 2v2 I have solo carried many games were my partner underperform. The game is almost always in your hands.

Note: I stayed away from the single player mode and only recommend the PvP

Written from the perspective of a Hell Halt TD 4.1.0.5 (W3) player. 

The game has a ton of potential but also some game-breaking issues that need to be fixed before it becomes a truly phenomenal title. 

--------------The Good Stuff-------------
-Gameplay mechanics are very well made and designed. It is mostly a spiritual successor to Legion TD (HellHalt) and not like the DotA -> DOTA2 transition. That said, I personally love it. 
-There is a lot of relearning of timings involved as well as synergies, but once again the actual gameplay is extremely polished and I consider this a major plus. 
-If you are coming from Legion TD on Warcraft, after a learning phase of maybe 10-15 hours. You will absolutely love the game. 

--------------The Bad Stuff-------------
-Ranked matchmaking is ***COMPLETELY*** broken. The game only plays ranked mode in a 2v2 scenario and you are entirely at the mercy of your matched teammate (most of whom will suck). The game is so designed that there is absolutely no need for a 2v2 ranked mode and could easily have been a 1v1 mode as well where you could climb only on the basis of your skills. 
-Ranked matchmaking does NOT take into account your skill difference even though it is calculated. The end screen shows you how skilled you were (power score) compared to your team mates but will NOT take that into account while deducting points or handing out points in ranked play. It will only look at the win or loss status of the match - even if you drastically outperformed your teammate (or your team mate carried you through the game). The problem with this is that very good players can get stuck in bronze if they continously get mated with bad players during the calibration matches.

This game is close to being good, I wanted it to be good and had fun most of the time. You can see on your first match that there are some really cool unit/ability synergies that require experimentation and experience to fully explore and make yourself a better player. 

This is not a straightforward thumbs down. Looking back at where I started I can see how my skill level and understanding of the game has increased, and that's exactly what you want from a competitive multiplayer game. Looking forward I don't see a way to get better and climb the ladder without memorizing build lists/orders/wave mechanics and it feels so bleak. 

If you are matched against a team with more experience or knowledge of build lists, you will lose. If you are teamed up with a newer player who hasn't memorized some kind of strategy, you will lose. One of the worst design choices is displaying how many wins each player has while connecting to the match server. Seeing someone on the other team with a four digit win-count is instantly demoralizing and matches where you can overcome that experience gap are extremely rare. Having to sit through an entire match knowing you are under-powered and will never catch up is an awful feeling and sucks all joy out of playing.

The developers want people to learn the game by playing the single player "campaign". This whole side of the game looks and feels unfinished. The music for the campaign map is shockingly awful - a mismatch in tone for the game, and the music is mixed in way too loud. Some of the 2D art looks like its from an old flash game. The tutorial was helpful and I think the developers should scrap the campaign mode to expand the tutorial further. Maybe even add a practice mode where you can pick a wave and units to test things out. I learned best by watching my teammates play and copying them, again reinforcing how much power experienced players wield in this game.

My last novice opinion is that the overall game design is held back by how much it has preserved from Warcraft III. I never played the original mod, but as a former DoTA masochist I can see some obvious holdovers - the overall level design (lanes), the visual representation of the mythium miners (pointless and a waste of map space), and how the camera functions (snap to commands aren't robust enough for the huge maps and the movement of units) stick out the most. These things and others I can't put my finger on adds a clunky, work-around sort of feeling that smells of "mod".

I would like to come back to this game someday and I hope the developers will continue their work. Getting out of the Warcraft III mod mindset and exploring all the opportunities a stand alone game provides could go a long way to show off the passion put into this game and the competitive multiplayer potential of the design.

Awesome multiplayer auto-battler, with a thriving, generally nice community, and ongoing development! 

[h2]Stop waves of enemies! [/h2]
In Legion TD 2 (LTD) you have to stop enemies that spawn in waves on your 'lane'. The enemies give a bounty for each kill, and with that gold you can buy new fighters in between the waves. The game gives a recommended value of your fighters for each wave consisting of the total possible value that comes spawning. Depending on the type of units you have put on your lane with all their synergies and positioning, this value can be either too high or too low. For instance, a collection of only tanks (units that soak damage well, but don't deal much themselves) will probably not clear a wave. 
The units that you 'leak' will attack your king! But not before your teammate's fighters that survived his wave have a chance to attack your leakage. The bounty now is shared between the both of you, and your opposing team also gets a cut! 
Units have one of four types of attacks and one of five types of defense. The types have bonuses and penalties towards each other, as seen on the ingame diagram, and these values aren't linear. A magic damage dealer will struggle against arcane armour, but will melt through nature armour!

[h3]Mythium and workers [/h3]
There is a second resource, called mythium. Mythium is used to hire mercenaries that will join the next wave of the opponent! Hiring mercenaries raises your income that you receive after a wave is finished. The mercenaries are dependant on the amount of mythium you spend how powerful they are. You can also choose more powerful units at a reduced income. And in this part is where most battles are fought. In recognising your opponents build to choose a wave to enhance. And of course synchronising your sends with teammate, however his opponent might be strong on that wave, so that may not be the best tactic. Another tactic is just to go for the best possible income, and deal with any opposition by shear value. 
You start with two workers that gather 1 mythium every ten seconds. New workers can be bought for gold. Your game is a balance between your workers and your fighters. It may be worth it to go a bit too lean on your fighters, and ahead with your workers! Purposely leaking one or two units gives you more juicy mythium, and if you are ahead on worker count, you will gain an advantage! 

[h2]The Legions & Mastermind [/h2]
The fighters belong to a Legion of fighters. There are Antelean, Divine, Element, Forsaken, Grove Mech, Noomad and Shrine, each with six tiers of fighters. Originally in the predecessors of this game you chose one Legion and battled with those. But this got a bit boring, so now you play with selected group of fighters from a random selection of all Legions. This makes for much more variety in the games, and less repetition. 
You can still play as a Legion in non-ranked modes. 

[h2]The history of LTD[/h2]
LTD was originally a custom map in Warcraft 3. I personally only knew and played the version of Starcraft 2: Squadron TD. I remember that I returned at some point to that game, and it was significantly different, with more 'Squadrons' and at some point a leaderboard. Very fond memories there, and I wish that map-layout gets implemented in this game, because I loved the shared buildingzone! 

[h2]Game modes[/h2]
Ranked - 2v2 games for an ELO rating. You can queue with a partner. 
Classic - 4v4 mayhem! There are more selections possible of fighters, such as the fully random 'hybrid'! Can be queued up to eight people! 
Custom game - games can have adjusted rules, such as high income 
Campaign - very challenging bosses which cheat! 
Vs AI - of different ladder rankings 
Weekly challenge - very hard puzzles to defeat a wave with selected fighters. The solution with the least gold value wins! 
Furthermore there is an extensive tutorial, you can browse top games of the best players, and can test builds in a sandbox. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2650502603

[h2]My experience [/h2]
When I saw this game arrive on early access four years ago, I immediately bought it, which is rare for me. I have such good memories of STD, playing so many games without even a ladder! But nowadays I'm not really looking for an endless game, and not just ladder for ladder's sake. So the game shifted to my backlog. Now that the game is fully released since two months, I've got a clear goal in getting all achievements! The biggest part is getting 100 wins in one season in both ranked and classic! I'm practically done with the ranked one, and felt it was time to review this. 
The ladder is quite special. My first games weren't very good, so I got to bronze ELO (below 1200). Now I got to around 1600-1700, maybe I will try for Diamond 1800. For a physically handicapped player I'm satisfied, because some waves I don't have enough time to do the things I'd like to do. 
The players are generally kind. Every now and then you encounter someone who rages when you don't execute his plan. You are obviously the reason he isn't on top of the ladder, hehe! 

This game is a true gem! With a dedicated development! Do I have anything bad to say? Yes I don't understand why creating a guild is behind a paywall. They say only cosmetic items are available for money,  but in that case it's untrue. Yes you can also grind like 400 games to create one, my point is that a social feature doesn't belong behind any wall whatsoever. 

Play this game!! 

95/100
