In order to talk about this game I really feel like I need to talk to two separate audiences, those that are coming to it after playing the Starcraft 2 version and those coming in without any prior experience. Because of that, I will be breaking this review into two sections catering to each audience.

TLDR: For first time players this is going to be a bit of up front work to get into but is a blast if you really sink your teeth into the competitive play, for returning players it is a refreshing look at the same formula with some significant changes that you will need to adjust to before you will feel comfortable with it again.

First Time Players: The game is on the surface fairly simple, each player is responsible for building units to defend their lane and sending units to attack the opposing players lanes. The game takes place on teams of two with each player being responsible for a single lane but being able to help clean up "leaks" from their ally and vice versa. If both players fail to stop the leaks then the creatures will continue on to fight your king and if your king dies then you lose. You gain gold by killing the creatures which attack your lane and through passive income which is increased by sending mercenaries to attack the enemy lanes or by using the same resource to boost your king's strength. This all sounds simple and digestible, but the level of depth and complexity in the strategy is immense and could easily be overwhelming to brand new players. Should you save your resources giving up future income in order to send a big wave of mercenaries to cripple the enemy team's economy or send the most efficient resource building units to out-macro them instead? Should you invest in your defenses to prevent leaks or build more workers? The game gives you enough tools to interact with these questions meaningfully, but it is a careful tight rope to walk and a few key missteps can easily result in a loss once you get to the higher ranks. For brand new players I would suggest leaving mercenary sends on automatic and just focusing on managing workers/defenses until you are more comfortable with the game, then start exploring options for optimizing the effectiveness of your offenses. I think that this is most of what should be known to brand new players but I would caution anyone who is not particularly drawn to RTS games or tower defenses specifically as there is probably not enough PvE content to satisfy those not interested in the PvP aspects of the game. That being said, if you have gotten this far and are still undecided you will probably be able to glean a bit more information from the next section, though it may refer to some things that you are unfamiliar with.

Starcraft 2 Players: For players coming from the Starcraft 2 custom map version of the game there have been some major changes that will significantly impact the way you play the game. First off, most of your knowledge about specific units will not be helpful as the units are mostly radically different in this version. For example Proton in the SC2 version of the game did pure damage and built up mana by attacking in order to temporarily increase it's attack speed but in LTD2 it does typed damage and instead has a near infinitely ramping damage that does not go back down until the round ends. There are other changes that have made the game a lot more user friendly though. For starters, they added a recommended value which allows you to have a pretty good idea about how much gold investment you need on the board in order to prevent leaks. You will have to deviate depending on what the enemy is sending, but for the most part the recommendations seem to be good in a vacuum. Another huge change is that ranked play no longer allows you to choose a race. Instead, you select a "mastermind" mode which determines how you build your team of defenders. The default mode, and so far the one I prefer, allows you to select one unit to lock and gives you five other random units. You are then allowed to draw four more random units and swap out as many as you prefer ending with a total of six units to play with. You can either do this right away, or wait until later if you want to swap out units that are good early on for better late game options, though I am not experienced enough to offer meaningful advice to that end. Most of the other changes are quality of life improvements that make the game feel a lot smoother than its predecessor. A good example would be that they have tweaked the way leaks work to make them significantly less punishing as long as they don't make it all the way to your king and instead of you losing loads of resources when you leak, your opponent gains resources instead. This goes a long way towards preventing the death spiral blowouts that were so common in the SC2 version.

All in all, Legion TD2 is a significant evolution over it's predecessor and if you are a returning fan or a fan of competitive TDs in general then it is a no brainer purchase for a relatively low stress and high fun competitive experience. If you are not a fan of TDs or don't like RTSs then there's a good chance you will bounce off of this particular offering.

I really love Legion TD2. The core game is very well thought out and has a shockingly high skill cap. The basic premise is 2v2 tower defense where you fend of waves of enemies and simultaneously can send monsters into your opponents waves. Very fun in coop. At the time of writing this, I have only played a single match of PvP. The core campaign, coop, and ai battles are plenty for me. I think one the reasons for this is the nature of the tower defense and intermixed rng lend very well to playing and optimizing your own game without worrying too much about what your opponents are doing. Given the rng nature of the game (you can start with start random units and select from a random pool for example) give the game lots of replay-ability. This is a prefect game for coop and for hopping in solo to play a game or 2 when you have like 30 minutes to spare.

Again the game has a shockingly high skill cap. To really climb ranks or play against harder bots you will probably need to look up guides on how the game is best played, it has tons of depth to it. To start though, playing through the campaign and some of the easier bots is very new player friendly and enjoyable. Very highly recommended by me overall.

Interesting Concept with a somewhat steep learning curve in the beginning if you never played the wc3 version (seriously you will lose a lot of your first matches). Still there are some changes to it, the biggest one being 2v2 instead of 4v4, which alienated some players. I personally think 2v2 is more fun as it allows for more impactful and informed decisions in the game. 4v4 is still around as a casual game mode, though! Finding matches at the average elo range does not take too long. The Devs are steadily releasing patches and new content, the pace is a bit slow maybe, but it is a small team of 4 people so it's understadable. All in all I recommend this game as it already came a long way since the early access release here and there is still lots of potential.

Edit: Game is released and you can play 2v2 and 4v4 competitively.

I reccomend the game to Legion TD beginners and Legion TD (1) players, who have no problem with losing all the games and playing with very bad beginners. 
Explanation: If you lose the first games, when you are still looking how to play the new builders your rating falls down, then you play with some others at your rating, these are normally players who leak from wave 5 onwards or send even when the others want to save. Thats like a trap, beacause there are other good players, who fall down, so you can hold yourself on a very low level, but it¬¥s very hard to get up again. You have to tell your team how to play good to win, but they won¬¥t listen, and still do what they think it¬¥s the best so that THEY get mvp or don¬¥t leak or something else, and dont play for the team.

pretty good game overall, but it's a little shallow.  I wish there were better upgrades for units instead of just 1 choice for most.  The games also cap out at 21 waves, which makes late-game pretty minimal.  So it never feels like you're building to something bigger or more exciting for your squad.

Once you find a faction you like, the game also becomes a bit formulaic.  It's a good price point for what the game is; essentially a fleshed out mod.

Extremely entertaining, if you've ever played the Wc3 version of Legion TD or the SC2 version of Squadron TD, they play very similar to those maps from back in the day.

If you haven't played either of those maps from the aforementioned games then allow me to explain.

Legion TD 2 is a tower defense (duh) that utilizes a defense and offense mechanic in that you can influence your income per wave by sending mercenaries to the enemy team's lane.  This improves your income between waves and allows you to field more "towers" which function like units and turns into an autobattler each wave, each unit has its own strength and weaknesses, allowing for varied styles of play.  The game boils down to managing your income with building your towers while sending mercenaries that counter the enemies towers.  The game has a surprising amount of strategy involved instead of just vomiting units at the enemy blindly.

The game is designed in a way to be entertaining to newbies and tryhards alike and involves a lot of improvement by the individual as a whole, there is always room for improvement and the game gives you every opportunity to improve with the various tips, hints and general information given to the player.

If you enjoy tower defenses I'd suggest trying this out, it's well worth the $$$ for it and if you're on the fence for the game then I highly suggest you check out a few youtube videos regarding the game.  It has a learning curve but it's still enjoyable while being on said curve.

Sure the game has its issues here and there but I haven't run across any personally and I really enjoy everything (so far) being obtainable with ingame currency and not locked behind any paywalls, everything is obtainable via "essence" and includes exclusively cosmetics currently (huge plus imo).

I would highly recommend the game if you enjoy any kind of tower defense or autobattler style game.

Three word review: Can't stop playing

It is based on an old Warcraft 3 custom game before Blizzard destroyed that fine old game. It has been floating around in various forms for years and has even appeared on the Starcraft custom scene. 

As a result there is decades of game play balances and feedback which has been distilled by the devs in to what is one of the finest TD games ever. The  matches themselves are short affairs lasting no more than 25-30 mins but there is always plenty to do in terms of tweaking your build and looking at the enemies to figure out how to take theirs apart. 

All of this comes in to make an almost endlessly re-playable game which is great fun, even more so if you can recruit a friend/family member or pet to play a duo lane with for some fantastic double builds. Top game.

Its no longer for me.

The base of the game came from Legion Tower Defense, a mod/custom game for Warcraft III, but because the new reforged version broke the original game and Blizzard announced that any new custom games would be their property. An example would be Dota, they don't want that kind of game to get away from them again.

Enter Legion TD2. Just like Dota 2, its awesome and fun and the devs seem to care and are constantly rebalancing. Also Also, its not a pre-order or an early access title... It's been fully released now! They're committed! The game is in a great place right now and you should buy it!

This game is a faithful spiritual successor to the classic Warcraft III mod. As far as game play is concerned, the introduction of The King as an income generator, minion killer, and upgrade-able home base creates interesting moments of tension and forces players to adopt new strategies with regards to mercenary deployments. The worker/unit dynamic is difficult to get adjusted to at first as income generation is critical in surviving some of the later waves. Without it, and you may very well be left behind earlier than you would think. Players will need to think carefully about how many units they place down and how many workers they take on while also taking into consideration the attack/defense types of every unit they use and defend against. Overall, there's a lot of complexity here and is a game suited for fans of tower defense and strategy games. Card game fans may also take a liking to it. As for me, 8.5/10!

Legion TD2 is very fun and it's the good kind of difficult, when i loose i wanna play again and fix my mistakes. I also appreciate that it isn't an APM heavy game, even though it has timers you aren't rushed to click click click as fast as possible to get an advantage. Its a thinker more than it is a clicker and that is just my speed. All the units are fun, and the "factions" give a nice variety for aesthetic purposes. Of course i hope they add more units/factions/evolutions, but there is a nice variety as is and when you play the mastermind games you really get to pick and choose your team. if you like League or DOTA and you also like warcraft/starcraft this has elements of both to me. It is multiplayer but there is a good amount of solo things to help you learn the concepts and the bots are hard enough to actually push you to get better and kind of force you to look at your errors, especially early on. if you think you might like it, you probably will.

It's a tower defense game combined with auto-battler aspects that has reasonable strategic depth, high replayability, a ranked queue, and strong duo-queue potential for those that like to play with friends. Games are 20-30 minutes long, so it's easy to time your game play with other activities and obligations. My only request would be to give a little more interactivity during the battle phase. If you could have a playable character with the ability to focus fire or drop buffs for your army, that could both add more tactical game play as well as giving you more interaction during fights. Still, I can highly recommend to those that enjoy games with a combination of real-time and turn-based strategy.

Well designed game for competitive fun. Especially nice if you like strategy games and dont like playing with reaction as in MOBAs, FPS, etc.

The team that works on it is small, and you may notice some minor UI quirks. The quality of the game more than makes up for it.

Having spent many hours in WC3s Legion TD, and after spending over 15 hours with this game so far, I have to say I have enjoyed this iteration. It is worth supporting if you enjoy a good competitive tower defense. The game is a little heavy handed with tutorials and forcing you through the campaign whether you want to or not.

For the price of this game, I think it's worth picking up and checking out. I am certainly enjoying myself.

I bought this on sale since I'm a big TD player... But I quickly found out this is less of a TD and more of an Autochess like Riot's Teamfight Tactics, which is not a bad thing but is quite misleading. I would say it's around 70% Autochess and 30% TD.

As for the actual game, it has a lot of complexity and mechanics that keeps me interested in playing, with a wide range of game modes from ranked to campaign. What I liked the most was the massive number of unique "towers" each with their own abilities, strengths, weaknesses, and synergies. This game is clearly designed by gamers. 

What I did not like was the team-play aspect, and this is really the game killer for me. Although it's 4v4 (2v2 in ranked), it does not feel like I'm playing in a 4-man team. It's more like I'm playing solo on the same side as 3 other people. You can't build "towers" with your team mates. You can't actively help each other. The only team play is if you leak, your teammates can kill your leaks (at which point you are just dragging everyone down). This might as well be a 1v1 game... or a 1v1 round-robin like TFT or Hearthstone Battlegrrounds. 

Sounds, Graphics, and UI is beautifully done. Nothing wrong here. Reminds me of Dota2 blended with League of Legends.

Games alot of fun, classic Legion TD in a nutshell. Played it way back in the WC3 days. My only gripe is campaign is more of a "puzzle" mode than a mode to playing with fundamentals of legion TD as a whole. The bots get super powers basically and you're stuck racking your brain over and over again to make something work. While I'll admit it has gotten me way up to par compared to how I was back then when I played this game.. It's definitely rough for newer players to differentiate the difference between actual smart plays and just a puzzle style system. 

I've 3 starred half the campaign so far. Tommy was by far the hardest because I feel its COMPLETE RNG, sometimes he just dogpiles you so hard its not even funny other times you can really pressure him, and pray he doesn't send the best units with the myth he just found on the ground. Mama Mayrna is pretty difficult because it shows the scaling difference of Income and she has some tight windows to really hurt her kind. The rest are just generally going against the grain to really flesh out a strategy to beat them, (I try my hardest to stick to fundamentals and not cheese the AI too so it makes it harder in general for me.)

But nonetheless I seen the premium currency can be earned via a little description on the shop, I do hope thats true. Would feel pretty bad to play the game religiously and never have cosmetics because people refuse to open their wallet for a game that already yielded $20.00 just to play, when they can play at any time on WC3. Hopefully not too many hoops just to get a couple cosmetics.

Other than that, its Legion TD with some additions, Round 20 is the max (as far as I could tell so far), Has a nice little rating system like the WC3 model had, has a campaign, vs bots, and other game modes which people didn't have access to in the past. Was really rough for new players to learn this game on WC3 cause it was a very hardcore, cutthroat community that didn't care to teach people and played solely to win. So overall I'd say its worth it if you enjoy competitive TD style games.
If you like general Tower Defense games, PvP games, TCG games, or games like TFT, this is a must play. In my opinion, it's the best one out there. Play it!

PVP Tower Defense.

It's easy to get into and relaxing as a newbie, but the game has a lot to master and seems concentration-intensive for high-end gameplay. 

For example, you get 40 sec between waves to upgrade towers, build workers, and send attackers to your enemies, which is a lot of time to do them at a basic level. However, to build the maximum amount of workers while spending the absolute bare minimum on towers to not get breached and determining which waves your opponent is weak against so that you can send attackers to breach your opponent, 40 sec + the battling time is a surprisingly tight time constraint. This high-level play is made difficult because each tower and enemies have damage types and armour types that works in a rock-paper-scissors system, which requires you to have knowledge of every unit in the game and to have quick recall/reflexes to exploit your strengths and your opponent's weaknesses.


I've update my opinion as I gain further mastery of the game.

Very chill game once you have the basic understanding of the game. I am new to Legion TD 2 and how I learned a bit of the game was the campaign and some coop vs AI. I also watched a few YouTube videos as well.

Has a lot of depth to possible strategies and is pretty fun to play. Overall would recommend, but there are a few things to watch out for:
- Learning curve is extremely steep. You have to learn all the different units/enemies/mercenaries as soon as you start playing, and a lot of it feels arbitrary. There is no simple game mode to help you learn this bit by bit. The tutorials only explain basic game mechanics and there are not really any good resources in the game to teach strategy and how games play out.
- Microtransactions in a paid game always feels bad.
The team balancing in this game is terrible

Game has very negative tooltips. Even in the tutorial even decision seems to be met with a prompt that you bought the wrong thing or spend too much gold. If you buy workers it tells you that you should buy more guys. If you buy guys it tells you that you overbought and dont have enough workers. Even when I got a victory with 0 leaks there was a message saying I had messed up on wave 1.

If I wanted to constantly be berated for every decision I made I can just play any online multiplayer game I already own.

Was sceptical about it at first but once you learn a few tricks its a lot of fun, the matches take around 25-35 minutes. The community is really friendly, there a lot of ways you can build and a lot of strategies you can use. I would say the more hardcore and advanced you become the more fun it becomes to play, you have to pay a lot of attention and burn a lot of focus if you are at higher elos. You can also play more casual and just experiment with builds which can be rly interesting. There isn't much guides on builds online so you gotta figure out something yourself and if it works stick with it.

I would really not recommend this game to people with addictive personalities, it is made in a way to hook you in and make you stay, just like csgo and league of legends, you can spend a lot of hours playing this and still not realize how quickly it flew away. This game is like crack, don't play it if you can't control yourself.

Taking a page from DOTA2, it's a polished up map mod from the RTSs of old. Simple concept with complex variations of unit types and placement. It's clean and easy to play multiplayer. I've been in matches with Russian, Spanish, and Korean speakers, and yet we can still coordinate strategies by the right click "pings" on everything from unit placements, to waves you want to rush, to amount of resources you have. Very clever.

My one complaint is how long it takes to load up a solo campaign map. It feels like I'm loading into a MP game, which gets tiresome when you just want to quick restart because you leaked 3% on a zero leaks run.

This is not your typical tower defense game where you place towers, instead you build an army utilizing the strengths and weaknesses of your force; all while also managing your economy trying to find your opponents weak spot and sending  an army to them while not risking too much. There is very well big risk/reward aspects of this, you can slowly build your economy for late game; or ruin your late game by trying to end your opponents too fast. The game is very competitive and will keep you challenged. It will take you many hours to master it, learning the sweet spot of balancing everything and developing strategies, which is the best thing about it. I think its definitely worth the $20 if you are into competitive tower defense games or even strategy games.

Two weeks ago all I could talk to my friends about was this game that I had just found. My friends and myself all love this game, but this "matchmaking" update in the 4v4 mode has absolutely killed any desire I had to play this game. Its been 5 or so games in a row now that this "matchmaking" has placed me (a silver 4 in 2v2 ranked) against diamond or higher in the casual 4v4 games. Now, I am not saying that all matchmaking needs to go away, but maybe just make a separate 4v4 ranked mode and a casual 2v2 mode. I think that having the casual modes (non-ranked) with no "matchmaking" made this game way more fun.

Its with a very heavy heart that i leave a negative review, only because of the latest update:

they added matchmaking, which seems to mean it tries to give you a 50% winrate. Meaning every other game, you'll fight some guy in diamond with 700 wins vs your 50.

The game was MUCH more fun pre-matchmaking (save that for ranked where people want to tryhard), where you were much less likely to get a GOD tier player, and if you did they likely had random normal players mixed in. 

Seriously, my entire friend group is having the isssue, our winrate has absolutely plummeted and every game is a 1 sided stomp. I havent seen a game shoot itself in the foot so hard with a update, and can only hope the dev realizes this and undoes this horrifying mistake

Right so here is how it stand atm for me:

The game is very fun with lots of variability in the way you choose to play. The concept is pretty unique and refreshing and it is easy to pick up.

That being said; I am not a fan of the fact that your game is reliant on other people failing instead of you failing. The idea of a tower defence, at least is my eyes, is defending your kingdom, town, city or home. I often find myself in situations where I fight back from 4 waves of leaked enemies, finally getting my power level and gold growth back up to par and getting excited for the next few rounds to see if I can fight it back just for the idiot on the other side of the map too let too many things through and getting their king killed. All of a sudden my amazing comeback is pointless and my victory feels hollow, rather I would like to be able to play an endless wave for as long as I possible can manage after my opponents die, not only for some extra XP or in game goodies but also just too see how well the build that I envision will hold up.

Sure you automatically win when your opponents in the game die, but why should that end my run? At the very least I would like to be able to keep playing that game until I fail as well. Maybe this could be an extra game mode added in future updates? Or maybe I am just too new at the game to have found it yet, either way those are my thoughts. 

Still highly recommended for the price

This game is amazing and basically the game I have been looking for for years.

The gameplay feels like Starcraft without micro.  There is still macro, economy, build decisions and build orders, unit positioning, and decisions on when to push economy and when to send units at the enemy.  

But you do not have to control your units in combat, no need to have high APM, or wear out your hands clicking a million things.  (That said, unit positioning is a very big deal, and controls how your units take aggro, so it is still quite skill based).

Alternately, you could describe it as autochess/teamfight tactics without the set collection minigame, and instead more focus on the economy side of the game, and when to use the ability to put extra pressure on your opponent by sending extra units.

This is the RTS for people who like thinking and decision making, not micro, twitch reactions, and APM/clicking fast.

Although this game has a lot to learn, it is very fun. Essentially, it is a tower defence game where you are sending 'mercenaries' to opponents to try and break their defences and kill their king and your opponents are trying to do the same to you.

I highly recommend this to people who want a great competitive game to play, just keep in mind that the skill in this game comes from being able to determine the best way to place your units, when to buy workers so you can scale better or units to clear the wave, recognising what waves your opponent is weak on and which mercenaries would be most effective to send etc etc

Again, highly recommend this game, definitely a new favourite of mine. I know I will be playing it for a long time

Very little content. I quickly discovered that two thirds of the content is "coming soon", and that every single match is identical, featuring an unchanging sequence of pre-planned waves that never vary. There is no terrain, no maps, no variation at all. Imagine League of Legends, except with no heroes or terrain features, just a single lane of AI controlled units that you have no direct interaction with. You pick units, but you can then get a snack, because nothing you do during a wave matters. Do that ten or twenty times and it's a match.

Aside from that, I'm currently staring at an error screen in Legion TD 2, which informs me that the game won't work because of a vague problem with servers.

I have a strong preference against games that cannot be played without connecting to a service, and this one makes no effort to inform you in advance that it belongs to that category. I feel like a dupe for paying $20.

Easily worth the amount of money. I would recommend BUT....

Always online for campaign mode?
No direct peer to peer connection? (OK, this one isn't that bad)

It will be a not recommended from me until you can play parts of this game offline.

THIS ISN'T A TOWER DEFENSE GAME!

Tedious, counter intuitive, repetitive, confusing, theme less, story less, uninspired, but worst, patently not an actual team tower defense game. Imagine Tetris, except you cant see the other side, and instead of fitting blocks, your trying to optimize perk vulnerabilities in waves.

There are no walls or creap pathing, the strategies aren't really geometric as much as vulnerability matching, it's more like color coding, and none of it makes any thematic sense it's all random nonsense. In ONE strait lane. ? Every match? Forever?

It's just awful.

You can't see the other lanes you are competing against unless you scroll away from your own.

Get ready to fall asleep repeating 10-20 levels of your factions optimal creap placement every match.

I'm sure it will be popular with South Korean Starcraft players looking to practice minimal time key binding optimized strats, ug, just don't.

I was suprised to find out Legion TD got released as it's own, separate game. Sure, already happened with Dota a long time ago, but this game is nowhere as big as Dota. Still it's a very popular map in W3 and SC2, so why not I guess.

The concept is simple - build your fighters to defend waves, keep increasing your income, send creatures, overpower the other team eventually. After you get the basics, there's a whole lot of depth and strategic planning to comprehend. Enough to give the game a competetive feel and keep it interesting for a long time. 

It's fun. It's the good old concept that just works, reviwed in a polished, smooth edition. Graphics are aesthetic and pleasant to look at, sound is clear and nice (the theme that starts before wave 21 is awesome, I'd love to hear an extended version of it). Overall a very good experience that will keep me playing in the upcoming weeks for sure.

Definitely a worthy addition to any steam library.

This game is basically CHESS in the form of Kriegsspiel -- the war game the Prussian Army (known as the greatest army of its day) would play on two chess boards. It was played on a blind double board then after positions were established, a proctor  would lift the blind to see who would win based on unit and positioning. I don't know if the developers just stumbled on that or knew what they were doing but this reworking of Kriegsspiel is absolutely brilliant. This is one of the greatest games I've ever played, and my top two of all time. Congrats!

Highest recommendation to anyone who likes strategy games and especially likes tower defense. Simple but tons of strategy and depth in this tower defense game. Easier to learn than Teamfight Tactics (TFT), just the right amount of depth, short games (20-30 min), and tons of replayability and features such as ranked leaderboard, guilds, in-game coach, match history, and unit statistics. 

Absolutely no pay-to-win mechanics, and the game seems to offer everything that you need by only buying the base game. Money is purely for cosmetics.

Want to play against bots and your internet's down? Infinite hang on the loading screen, you need to ctrl+alt+del or alt+f4 out.

Want to play solo campaign and their own server is experiencing difficulties? That loading screen is sticking around, son.

Want to play any tutorial mission? Hey, maybe the loading screen is ten seconds, maybe it's ten minutes, maybe more.

Maybe this doesn't bother you, you're comfortable just shutting it off and coming back the next day to try, but I find it inexcusable a thirty dollar flash game is this needy.

So as a whole I'd give the game as of 10/13/21 a solid 6.5 / 10 and I will list out the Pros and Cons because the game over all does play and feel nice but there can be improvements.
Pros
The mechanical game play of the units are fun to watch 
The Game has a Type system where certain damage types or defense types are wave by wave based are are stronger or weaker than others
The game has a unique currency system for during the in-game process where you need workers, mythrim, and gold to grow
The game has multiple decks to choose from each with their own unique types and play style
The Game has a 2v2 and a 4v4 game mode which is INSANELY COOL along with actually challenging bots of various difficulties 
The game has a up to 8 player party system

CONS.
When you are playing in a party with a friend and the game is over it disbands the party so you have to re invite friends which is just inconvenient 
other than a random 4 extra unit pool there is no actual "deck" building or customization
The game is a bit repetitive since the waves dont switch up or change
The store has literally nothing worth purchasing other than bot handicap match perks

Other than that the game is solid enough that I'd say it's worth getting

To the Devs if you do read this and think there may be a way to innovate game modes and a system for these suggestions
i'd like to see more units for decks and a actual custom deck builder in the game
also 1v1's and 3v3's would be super cool to introduce with bots customs, and 1v1 ranked
The store has literally nothing worth purchasing other than bot handicap match perks
so if possible input some new units you can use the ingame earned currency to purchase along with decks
The mercenaries are super well put so i couldn't think of anything to switch them up. maybe a upgrade after lvl 10 as a chance like the how theres a perk for the snail maybe there is one you can introduce for specifically mercs.
i'd definitely say that different waves of enemies {Except Boss Rounds} would be nice to introduce so the waves and types dont feel like i have to play in a repetitive fashion which in the event of custom deck building you can have a system of how expensive a deck is or what types a player may or may not have resistances or advantages against.
I'd say may in the late future have custom skins for units and mercs. in game currency

Fun and great graphics. Has some nice improvements over the original and has single player. My only complaint is that your units don't focus the same target. A lot of time I leak one enemy my units were all attacking 2-4 different targets at once instead of focusing a target. I had no familiarity with the original mod, but was intrigued by mechanics and development story. I was looking for an auto-battler, unit drafting game, and was hoping this would scratch that itch. This game is not that.

I was on the fence to purchase this after researching it and wasn't quite able to grasp the flow and control of the game. There's a ton of nuance to each turn and units you need to learn. I love tower defense, but am not a fan of RTS at all. I decided to take the plunge because curiosity got the best of me and I saw it had a well established following with the potential to grow. Also had growing FOMO about this becoming the next big new genre and wanted in on the first wave. 

Incredibly happy I took the plunge, this game is a ton of fun. I don't think this would normally be my cup of tea but so much about the gameplay works so well. I'd say there is a moderately steep learning curve to it, and after a week I'm only slightly starting to feel a little more comfortable understanding what I'm doing (and why). Something really interesting to me is that the waves are static, so opening strategy and placement can be optimized, but there is still tons of strategy and skill required. There's a lot factors to evaluate each round and each game feels different.

The launch product is very stable, has great newb friendly features (excellent tutorial/campaign, UI guides and references, well written in-game codex, etc), and dev team is super active in the community. 

This is certainly a game to keep an eye on, and hopefully it grows into a major success.

Super fun and improved version og the WC3 classic. Especially when playing with friends.

If you ever find yourself wanting a TD to play on multiplayer, this one, is currently the best of the market and also the most replayable one. You can play it solo or with a friend and its a really nice game to chill and have some fun.

Its polished, and if u played the map on wc3 and enjoyed, u should buy it, since its a lot better and improved.

I do also belive the price is more then just, I'd pay even higher for this game.

But leting the wc3 fan base aside... Legion TD2 is a great game with one huge problem. Its very non-intuitive. 

Its really hard to understand the positioning sistem of the game, and units dont respect it, moving over one another because they have no collision, making kinda of a messy battlefield witch for me is a huge downside in a TD game and almost an unforgivable one.

The economy part of the game is also non-intuitive but a little easier to understand than the unit placement process.

The game competitive cenario could be better, because it does not have a single player Ladder match, and since the game is very complicated to understand, many, and seriosly... MANY people screw it up. From rank 4000 to 1000 u still find people who did not got how the game works exactly yet, and I dont blame them since those things are not very well explained inside the game or even showed properly by it on the screen.

If u really want to master it, u probably will need to read some guides or end up like one of those that think you got it, but did not.

The game has a lot of decisions for a TD game, making you think a lot if you did learn it and are facing someone that also learned it. Saddly this does not happens every single match yet, but its amazing when it does. 

Altho if u do take your time to learn the game, and if u do manage to understand it, I think its worth every penny. No other TD offers the amount of strategy and moves inside its mechanic that this one does.

I've only encountered two toxic players in 60+ hours of play, so the community seams polite enought, and should reflex that the atmosphere of the game itself is chill and fun even in competitive scenarios.

Sugestion for the devs:
-Add a faction ladder match, factions are fun, and would be nice if they made their way to the competitive part of the game.

-Add a single player ladder match. I know the game was designed to be a team TD game from the scratch, but some people do like single player matches (myself included) expecialy in ladder scenarios and I do honestly think this would make the player base grow and survive longer


Sory for the bad english, hope this review helped you decide if u want or not Legion TD for you.

This is very good if you like PvP competitive games. (The solo content for this game pretty much stops at fighting bots.)

There is a very big learning curve in the game which is maybe a little too much for a "small" game like this.
You have to learn:
- Overall the flow of the game and how to build an economy since it's unlike any other game.
- All 20 waves. Which are easiest, which are hardest.
- All 6 of the units for at least 1 faction. Their strength, weaknesses, synergies, ideal positions, possible upgrades etc..
- Probably repeat the last step for the 7 other factions.
- Learn all the mercenaries you can recruit. (There are 16 of them I believe.) Especially the expensive ones because some of them will specifically synergizes with a wave or counter an opponent's setup.

The game gives you a lot of help to go through that but it's still a lot and won't happen in less than a few hours.

And you can absolutely enjoy the game without doing all that, it's simply what I foresee myself having to do so I won't keep spending half of my games reading description.

And if you're like me, you're asking: "Wait so a factions always has the same 6 units and always receives the same waves? So you just have to pretty much know the best setup for your faction and you're good?"
The answer is... pretty much yeah. You have to play around the mercenaries your opponent is sending but it might not change your core setup that much.

And that's where mastermind mode comes in. It's the ranked mode, the way I see it, the way the game is intended to be played. Instead to having a preset of 6 units, you get a randomised selection which forces you to improvise and adapt to what you're getting. To me that sounds very fun but it makes that learning curve all the more important to properly be able to play mastermind.

Anyway. Very unique game and fun to learn. Maybe a little too rigid in the way you have to play and learn it and very PvP/competitive focused.

Great little game. Sends me back to the Warcraft 3 Custom Map days, but its definitely of greater quality.

Gameplay is great. It has a lot of depth and room for minor optimizations, whether that's learning tower-to-unit match ups, synergies between towers, mercenary-unit synergies, mercenary-tower counters, mythrium and gold management. And while the depth is there, it doesn't feel like it gatekeeps the experience from new players. Its complex, yes, but also easy to pick up. Though, this is coming from someone who has played a lot of these types of games. The depth also lends to the games replayability, which has kept me entertained thus far. The number of towers and the randomization between them every game lends to matches feeling fresh while still feeling like you have control of your fate.

The general polish its pretty good for a game with this price tag. Has an (incomplete) single-player campaign, which is great to learn on without having multiplayer stress. Finding a online game has little resistance. And no pay to win or pay to unlock mechanics separating you from other players.

If you liked the old Warcraft and Starcraft maps, or like competitive tower defence games, definitely check this out!

*Armour types and attack types that can be the difference between winning and losing depending on how you build. Also worth noting that every wave changes the armour and attack types that you'll be facing.
*Teamwork and cooperation requirement
*8 play lobby based, two teams of 4
*Elo mm system that puts you on the leaderboards for all and for your country.
*Developers who love their own game, and play it. Who communicates(via discord) and uses feedback. 
*Playing the game hard isn't bad since there isn't a set way to play unless you decide to.
*Actually takes some getting use to. Have to put some thought into what you're doing and when you do it. That said, don't expect to just jump in and be gg. Let the game sink in. Don't rush it and don't expect to win all your games very early on without some knowlede or experience playing it.
*This probably shouldn't be a point but, Boss Fights.
*Amount of life for your team left does not matter., If you've played any TD before. Instead the game forces one of the teams to win, wave after wave until a team wins.
*Helpful community, most of the time x)
*Satisfies my cravings from way back, Warcraft 3 days custom tds, though legion was my favorite since then.
*Integrated steam friends and messages, which is similar to dotas, basically allows you to see steam messages as in game whispers and your steam friends list intact.

So these are the reasons I like the game.  It's worth it.

I have not played ranked as of writing this and have only played casual multiplayer matches and the campaign.

Pros:
+ Very addicting
+ Great unit diversity among the teams
+ Units working with other units abilities to be even more powerful is a nice touch
+ Great tutorial that teaches the basics of the game
+ The in-game coach actually does a really good job to help people learn
+ The campaign is actually very neat and a very pleasant surprise in this type of game genre
+ Mama Mayra's theme slaps

Cons:
- I don't know how to come back when i'm falling behind as it always seems near impossible to do so. You need money to buy workers to generate more income. It also leads to the enemy that you're attacking to have more reign to do as they please since you can't keep up with workers to do any real damage anymore, unless you save mithium for a few waves which only hurts more of your gold income and causes you to start leaking for just about the rest of the match
- Unit recommendations are sometimes more harmful than they are helpful
- Some teams you can choose are just greatly surpassed by other team options
- Some units have to be upgraded to be of any use or they are just a waste to put down in the first place
- If one side's king takes damage early on then the other team has practically already won with such a large lead

Overall:
It's a great game and I would recommend trying it if you love games kind of like TFT or Dota Underlords, but it takes some getting used to before you can really start enjoying it.

As a preface, I harken from the earliest Legion/Squad TD days, and seeing this release was very exciting to me, so there may be some rose-coloured glasses involved, but:

PROS
I can go on about the games balance and visual design, which I thoroughly enjoy, but I want to emphasize two major points that secure this game as my current game of choice for relaxing with friends.
I) The Coop environment and accessibility - Want to run a competitive game? Bring a pal along. Want to play in Classic? Bring 3 pals along. Want to play the Campaign and practice up? BRING A PAL OR FOUR. I love this. I appreciate it. I am grateful it exists and gives my friends and I a multiplayer game with a lot less toxicity than our past titles. Thank you.

II) The Dev Support - Between REDDIT and in-game support, I think this may be one of my favorite dev-presences in an indie-title I've ever seen. I truly appreciate the availability and transparency of the Dev's, and I hope it brings more to this game and gives them the success they deserve. Keep it up, Devs, you're awesome.

CON
Mild Con, on my cabal of friend's computers, including mine, the main menu seems to crash on exit 90% of the time. I don't REALLY care, as I'm exiting the game anyway. But I feel like I should put in a CON and that's all I got. That should tell you enough about this game.

I must have been hiding under a rock when this game mode was popular on Warcraft 3/Starcraft 2. Having no exposure to the mod or sub-genre it's shocking how good this game is. You won't get a good idea watching gameplay of this, especially not from twitch. 

This game is closest to the auto battler genre, games like auto chess, TFT, etc. It feels really good juggling your own economics, making judgment calls on the units you place down and the units you send to your opponents. It has a lot of good systems here and it's incredibly replayable. I bought the game expecting to return it in the 2 hour refund window and at the time of this review I'm at 25 hours+.

Would highly recommend this game to those looking for an excellent cross between tower defense and auto battlers with plenty of room for strategy and tactics. For everyone else on the fence, use the 2 hour window; you'll get an idea in the first hour if it's your cup of tea or not.

In general, I really like the game so far. 

This is good and polished competitive skill-based game.

There is a wide variety of statistics and graphs, the ability to view the formation on each wave in the match history, etc., which is very cool.
Not as much customization as I would like, but with the release of the game there will likely be more in the future.
The game has a couple of bugs, but the developers are actively working on this.

I hope the release of the game from early access and the influx of new players will help the developers and they will continue to improve their game.

I struggle to refer to this as Co-op. Sure there is another player on your team, but your actual interactions are minimal, in fact the only way you can contribute to the team as a whole is by upgrading the king, that is the only thing you share with your co-op partner, no resource share, no resource gifting, and the only way you can help with your allies defence if they let units leak. It feels less like co-op and more parallel play, you interact more with your enemy then you do with your partner, and even then, only one of the enemies, this is a 2v2 game where you barely interact with most of the other players.

Also with only one very plain map, and with the enemy waves always being the same (barring mercs), the gameplay quickly gets repetitive, especially after you figure out the order of purchase for your chosen faction. maybe some more map variety might increase the replayability, like some where the build areas intersect, or with only one build area you share, so as to make the game more interesting and co-operative, perhaps adding a bit more variability to the enemy waves, so you don't just autopilot through your fighter placement, and actually have to strategize about what to put when.

I'll give it a tentative thumbs up since I did have fun, but I can't really imagine picking this up again, nor can I really imagine recommending it to, or playing with, a friend.

Just want to start off by saying that I love this game and that I don't generally toss something like 200+ hours into any game I play. The first several hours of this game are by far the most fun. Experimenting with the different races, units, and exciting combos of these units can be a blast. You can almost always find a new combo of units that you didn't think of before making the game continuously exciting and engaging.

As you progress further and further the game then becomes more about optimizing the amount of workers you can reasonably buy while still being able to hold the opponents "sends." This is also means having a plethora of knowledge about what units are considered "good" or "viable," while also having an understanding of what other units go well with those. Knowing what certain units are good and bad at so you can make up for those weaknesses with other units is a big part of the game. This "meta" part of the game is still fun and enjoyable in its own right to me. Knowing and understanding the meta, tends to separate the good players from the bad ones and I don't think having a meta is a bad thing at all for a game. I think it is actually quite healthy for a video game in fact.

Please keep in mind that I do truly believe that the developers put a lot of time and effort into making this game as good as it can be. This is by no means an easy thing to do and I would like to give them credit for that, as this is truly a great game.

NOW having said all that, this is a point I've always wanted to talk about for a LONG time. The content releases for the game are sometimes extremely slow and can make the game stale really fast. There aren't really any units that get added to the game on a regular basis and it seems to me like its been an eternity since the last new race came out. Maybe I'm just spoiled by other big game companies that can release plenty of content month after month but that doesn't change the fact that I don't feel like enough new units/races are being added to keep me playing the game constantly. I would love to see more content releases if at all possible on a fairly regular basis.

This brings me to another point. The patch notes in this game are sometimes the most boring thing I've come across. In other games like league of legends or something like Path of Exile, patch notes are something that a lot of players look forward to. Seeing a whole list of new changes, including some that can be meta breaking, even, is super exciting. The patch notes for this game tend to be something as follows: X unit is over-performing so were gonna take a little bit of power from it -40 HP from a unit that has 3200 HP..... Or even, were gonna give Y unit some firepower that we feel its been lacking +.02 attack speed to its .70 attack speed... I understand that some of these changes can be the difference between a unit holding waves 1 and 2 or not being able to hold them at all. That doesn't change the fact that I feel as though balance changes don't rough up the meta or try to make an drastic changes that shift the meta dramatically. Even for the highest level of play, being able to adapt to a constantly shifting meta is super important and I think the game would be more exciting if larger changes were made each patch. (even if it can be a little scary to add more than .02 attack speed *winky face*)

The game begins to stale out once you start climbing the ladder and you start to learn that the game requires some pretty insane positioning knowledge and memorization to perform the best you can. There is a unit in the game called the "Priestess of the Abyss" that heals for a large percentage of its HP over time whenever it casts its special ability. This unit plays a hybrid role of dealing damage while also partially being used to soak damage considering its healing ability. This means that to use this unit perfectly, you have do hours of testing and trail and error with different waves, other units, and such so that you can maximize the healing aspect of the Priestess while also making sure it doesn't die. Not that this doesn't separate the bad players from the good players, but I just want to point out that the game can feel really tedious after a certain point if you want to climb so keep that in mind.

I know I went on a really big rant about the stuff that I don't exactly like about the game but overall I think the game is 100% worth buying. Its super fun and will keep you entertained for hours on end.

When I saw it, I couldn't believe there was finally a "standalone" game from TD mode from warcraft or starcraft 2 (and also from the original creators). It cost me ‚Ç¨ 13, and for this price it offers many, many hours of play before it gets repetitive. I've been playing for almost 20 hours and I've only played classic games, a few in "chaos" mode and some ranked. I still have to complete the tutorials, the campaign, the weekly challenge, unlock new styles of play and continue playing all the modes. The team will be releasing updates and has already advanced an interesting roadmap. If they do, this game will probably offer me more than 50h and much more. I think that many improvements and some new mechanics and features can still be added to the gameplay to make the game even a little more complex and deep, and of course, more polished.
Very good

I have played lots of the original Legion TD back in the day and would play it religiously with friends (and still do). I can imagine that some people might look at Legion TD 2 and say "[i]Pfft, why don't I just play the original on WC3?[/i]". This game does improve the original and introduces QoL changes to make the game better overall. Granted I haven't played the game for hundreds of hours yet but there are some clear standout improvements.

[list]
[*] [b]Matchmaking[/b]. Something WC3 custom games doesn't have.
[*] [b]Offering simplicity without sacrificing complexity[/b]. For example, buildings are just buttons and menus now, so it's much faster now.
[*] [b]Single Player content[/b]. If you are uncormfortable with PvP games or just want to relax and practice, there are plenty of single player stuff. It has a campaign that gives you different challengs to overcome and a Vs. AI mode as well.
[*] [b]Teaches you to play the game and helps you improve[/b]. This game has plenty tutorials and an ingame helper that gives tips on how to improve. This is a great feature for both newcomers and players that want to improve.
[*] [b]Party system[/b]. Queue up with friends for some 2v2 ranked or just 4v4 with the boys.
[*] [b]Better balancing and game pacing.[/b] There were some cheesy strats in LTD1 (mass sending on wave 7 amrite?) and the game ends earlier, meaning you can more ;)
[*] [b]Great devs that respond quickly.[/b] I talked a bit on the offical discord server, and the devs are quick to recognize problems and are quick to solve them. It's rare to see passionate dev teams sometimes, so I thought it was worth pointing out.
[/list]

The only real criticism I have is the sound effects and voices. Not terrible, but obviously not the charming WC3 sounds you might be used to hear. It's no biggie though, the game plays wonderfully.

I definitely think this game is worth looking at :)

OK so quick review time - I never played the WC3 version and I never experienced this type of game before. All I got was a SivHD recommendation and decided to try it out. Picked up on the logic pretty quick and the tutorials helped immensely. If you don't know anything about the genre or never played it, I recommend trying the tutorials, campaign and a couple of casual games and seeing if it will suit your tastes. If it does not, you will still have time left over from the 2h refund window.

I have only one very small issue -> When I started playing ranked, I was bombarded with too much info - pick a character, then form a team, and start your turn in 1 minute. I didn't realize I had to actually spend my gold in the same time frame as picking my team, which resulted in the game starting, me not placing anything and being kicked for AFK-ing... Noob mistake, I know, and I never repeated it, but I would like to point out that in my sub-1000 rating games many other players were repeating my mistake. Moving from the tutorials to the campaign to a single casual game and then ranked (which is recommended) I didn't know what to do! I'm sure this can easily be fixed with either some prompt or the "ready" button having 2 states -> ready from picking and ready to start; but that's game design decisions, not really my cup of tea.

TL:DR
This is not the LEGION TD you are looking for to replace, if you insist playing this as a successor/sequel then you are going to be disappointed because there's almost nothing looks/feel close like the old mod legion on WC3. From new players perspective this looks and feel more like auto chess.

[b]Full Version[/b]
I bought this game solely because I play legion more than I play Dota/Dota2 in general, and I spent a lot of time for both game.
Legion TD is generic Tower defense game, with WC3 Interface it's really easy game to play, EASY to play, but hard to master.

It's very simple, you pick a builder, build tower/units that you can afford, a wave of monsters will spawn, and tower/units that you build will fight the wave, if your tower lose then the rest of the wave will get to the king, unless your teammates can hold their on wave and killed what you leaked.

If only they made the name other than LEGION TD, I can accept it and play it as a NEW GAME, I remember LEGION TD mechanism, all the wave monster, type or attack/armor, when the good time to send, or how many worker/wisp I can push for lumber etc. With this game I have to forget all of that because new armor/type of attack is being used rather using classic name, even on the dota2 workshop that legion td mod trying to recreate that experiences.

- No builder, you just given tower to pick from the list. 
- No Minimap or map.
- Can't control king or whatever the title/name dev game to it now.
- Can't upgrade king after wave starts, so if your team leaked hard then nothing you can do even you have lot's of lumber or whatever name dev gave to it now.
- Can't see your teammates list of towers/units (or maybe you can, but I don't know how to see it)
- There's no multiplier in gathering lumber or whatever name dev gave to it now.
- The UI is weird, instead of using classic WC/Dota2 UI for hero/units/tower that put it on the MIDDLE OF YOUR SCREEN they put tiny stats on the top of screen, and we need to hover into units ability to read what it do. Why make it so complicated???

I am completely okay if this wasn't named as [b]LEGION TD 2[/b] so I can enjoy the game as it intended to be without going back into my memory lane how I used to play legion td, but this is not legion td and that's what makes me sad. It's not like LEGION TD it self is stopped being played, regardless what people says about WC3 (reforged or not) Bnet is still up and running, you can find legion match probably faster you can find with this game.

If you new players who didn't know anything about legion td, you probably enjoy it, specially if you like Tower Defense genre.
Great game. Lots to learn and multiplayer a blast. Challenge and matching very good, lots of variety of units. Very unexpected from tower defense game.

The problem is that you're not guaranteed to make it to the menu screen.  You have to 'login' to even play single player.  A good amount of my time has been spent simply waiting to either just log into the main menu or get queued up for a multiplayer game (which is the point of this) only to wait tens of minutes only to get re-queued or get logged out.  I have great internet, a good computer and have no trouble with other games such as Vermintide 2, Deep Rock, Titanfall 2, etc.

Also, I've played plenty of other indie titles from small or single person teams and have never had this much trouble.  I believe Morty gave Summer some great advice which I will give these Devs.  Get your $h1T together, put it in a $h1T bag, bring it to a $h1T Museum, I don't care.  Moral of the story, get your $h1T together.

Otherwise, if this did work it could be a great casual game to play and relax.  At this point I would stay clear.

First tower defense that truly brings me back to the days of Warcraft 3. Thanks for this.

If you are looking for a solid and competitive TD, then this is it. It lacks some rich content and somewhat the gameplay is really repetitive BUT you can't get enough of it: like a MOBA game. Gameplay is fun and you can always improve yourself as there are different units / armor types etc...

The game itself is basicly building defenses and increasing your income by sending units to the enemy, Also you can send enemy harder creatures but this means getting less income. But if you succeed to kill their defenses then your creatures can attack their king and you can get more gold. Also on every 10th wave you can pick a bonus. These two last mechanics mentioned adds game somewhat of a strategy aspect which can make every game exciting. 

Generally players playing ranked are all try hard so I cannot blame any teammate for ruining the game. Everyone is trying their best. Also players are not toxic. Some players just don't communicate and it can be frustrating since seding units to enemy at the same time can really change the wind of battle. So playing with a friend is not mandatory, you can also meet with really good players in the game and become friends.

I find this game rather relaxing (if you are not on "try hard, kill yourself and try to win" mode. Since you have time to think and strategize. You can relax, have your coffee and play it. I think it is really worth the price.

To Summarize:

THE POSITIVE :)
-a really polished bug free game
-a challenging TD
-good player base
-high replayability 
-makes you think and use your brain power to defeat enemies
-game seems balanced

THE NEGATIVE  :(
-some people can get bored after grasping the concept (i did not get bored myself)
-if enemies do everything perfectly then they start to get more income then you and the game itself does not do much to help you catch up to them. I would love to see League of Legends Style bounties that can help the guy getting destroyed having a chance (there is bounty in game but it is too little and really hard to achieve)

So for the price tag is it worth it? Considering even the possibility of getting bored, I think it is worth to buy and play this game with the current price-tag. In game market is only about cosmetics and doesn't affect the game in any way and it is a good way to support these guys. These are the guys that made this game as a mode to Warcraft III for free for years and everyone played it and enjoyed it much so I don't think it is unfair. So giving them negative review only for that aspect is somewhat over-reacting.

For the guys that played Warcraft III, what has changed? The game is bug-free, balanced, there is ranked option where you can play 2 vs 2 and normal option where you can play 4 vs 4 and some other modes. Graphics are more like Dota but it is, of course, better then Warcraft III.

Solid overall game. As it's based on the Warcraft series in terms of world and mechanics, I'll talk about the one glaring issue that another game in that world has, Dota 2, and that's the tutorial. 

Thousands of hours sunk into that game and still learning more- I can't afford to do that again. The game's tutorial is short, and hand-holdy, and for something this complex, it can't stay that way. 

Did all of the tutorial and tried a bot game. Suddenly I can upgrade my King unit, choose 1 of 3 spells which I assume are permanent buffs and whenever the opponent leaked, it seemed to have some units sat between the leaked creeps, and its King. I didn't. I didn't know how to do that. I don't know what these spells are. They were never explained. I don't need to know the best one to choose, but I at least need to know when I can get these, or have some idea of when I SHOULD. Rerolling my units? I don't know how that works. I pressed it, and then whenever I try again it says it's maxed out. I presume that means I only get to use it once per match, but there's nothing that teaches you that in the tutorial. 

The tutorial bounces you between a few different teams. These influence what units you'll build to defend yourself. Okay, cool, options are great, I do like this, but since the tutorial makes you switch the team you choose, you build no relationship with these units. You're picking them solely based off of what the next wave(s) is going to bring, as it recommends you build X or Y unit based on their affinities, being attack and defense typing.

I can't tell you if a unit is good or not, because I don't know. The combat is such a cluster too that it's hard, though not impossible, to tell what on your team is doing well, or what's doing the damage to you. Creep waves coming at you seem to have enemies stacked on top of eachother, so it's hard to tell if you're even winning, or if there are other units under the Whale that you're currently taking out. The Whales are damn adorable though. 

I'm going to fall in love with this game, it ticks all the boxes for me, but judging from the people uploading gameplay videos, guides, etc, it's for nerds. That's fine, I love nerds, I'm one too, however sinking a huge amount of hours into the game isn't something I'm prepared to do just to learn it. If I do something, it should be either explained to me, or clear, whether what I did was good or not. 

Other than the lack of teaching, I have no issues it looks great, but knowing what you're doing allows for a player to feel engaged and is massively important as feeling as if I have no agency over what happens means I may aswell just be watching. This is a game that demands you to search outside the game to be able to understand it. I appreciate the Steam Broadcast being up so that people know where to look, but this should really be in game. At least touch on every aspect of the game, even if you won't explain it all.

Not really a fan of the genre, has experiences in playing both Dota 2 and LoL prior playing the game but I was really hooked the moment I started. Gameplay is like Dota Underlords or TFT but is more indepth and built with a competitive setting in mind. Very accessible yet deep gameplay mechanics, highly recommend for everyone to give this a try, especially with its affordable selling price.

If DotA taught us anything, its that WC3 mods are really good. Legion TD 2 is a continuation of a great autobattler from the WC3 days and I dare say its more fun than that of Autochess and TFT.

The game has a lot of strategy despite seeming rather simple at first. Fun synergies between units, random units every game with mid-game rerolling, bouncing economy and unit efficiency all while trying to send enough units to kill the opposing King or upgrading to defend yours. A turn-based PvP autobattler with a ton of real-time strategy which I have come to discover and learn to love very quickly.

TLDR: High IQ tower defense game that can be played in either a relaxed fashion, or a hyper competitive level that require lots of game sense and knowledge. The game has a few simple mechanics that are easy to pick up, and lots of different towers/troops to synergize together. 


Things I think this game nailed:

Pacing of the game. Not too long, not too short. 

Ranked comp from launch

The ability to work as a team to take out the enemy team. You can really work together to call in some powerful push combos

The tutorial does an amazing job explaining the basics



A few things that I think can be improved on:

More maps or map skins. It would be nice to have different atmospheres

More cosmetics/ progression to work towards

Multiple or mix up the waves so its not predictable (in comp in particular.)

Completely unplayable. I have no clue why this game has any positive reviews because it doesn't even work on my end. I have a decent gaming laptop, but the default settings on this game would only work on a space-age "hardcore" PC. Right off the bat, you load the game and the UI is atrociously small for absolutely no reason. It's not like it makes the game WOW you from seeing more of the title screen. Nothing about the graphics are even that great, but you still need the latest gear to run them. If you can somehow manage to find the options screen with a magnifying glass, you have to go through 3 menus to find the interface enlarger, you have to immediately drag it to the max to double the interface. It's actually readable now, but it's still way too small. 0 times 2 is still 0. I then went to video and dragged all of the graphics options to very low and now the game looks like crap AND STILL RUNS SLOW. Mind you, I don't have the latest gaming gear, but I can still run Starcraft 2 on max settings on this computer without any lag. The only way to make this run better is by changing the resolution which they give you 20 different options on doing. Unfortunately, all 20 options make the game unplayable because it just shrinks the screen and cuts off more interface. Also, if you click any of the options other than the top 3, the zoomed in menu covers the entire screen and you're stuck and have to ctl alt delete to get out of the game and restart. WHY WOULD YOU PUT A FEATURE IN THAT LITERALLY BREAKS THE GAME??? I thought this game would be fun because I saw a few streamers playing it and I liked the original one in warcraft 3, but damn dude. I just wasted 15 bucks on a title screen. 0/10

Was excited to try playing legion TD 2 and man is it not worth the money.
Like, it's not bad considering it started as a warcraft mod, but man is the gameplay boring and kinda bullshit.
It's one of those games where you can be kicking ass on a run throughout the whole thing, but then you suddenly lose everything in a single turn because of seemingly no reason.
Like, your forces can be more powerful than the oncoming wave and you'll somehow lose even though you've been demolishing every wave prior, which is mostly a headache when you're playing the "campaign" (I put it in quotations because it's hardly a campaign).

So single player aspects aside, the fact that you have to pay to play this game and then they also have premium currency that you have to pay real money for to unlock cosmetics is one of those disgusting money grubbing moves you would expect from EA or Blizzard, which immediately killed my opinion of the game upon launching it for the first time.

Then there's the fact that you can play as any single faction or run with "mastermind" which gives you a random shuffle of units to play with and you can reroll in match if you aren't happy with what you got.
Sounds nice, but you would think they would also include the option to just play with the units of your choice without needing to rely on random chance or being stuck to one faction (each faction has its strengths and weaknesses, but the best builds are definitely a mix of multiple factions).

So in the end, it gets real boring real fast and the lack of anything to make it feel like you're actually making a significant strategy or even anything to make it feel unique ends up with this feeling no different from any other TD game that you could have found in a flash game over a decade ago.

Seems kinda fun, and I loved Legion TD back in WC3. My problem is the in-game shop being a thing that exists. I already paid for the game, and buying in-game currency with real world money is a huge problem to me.

Really fun game, micro transactions are cosmetic only (yes, its 2021 so obviously you have things to buy in a game you buy up front... because you know... why get a bunch of players with a F2P model when you can double dip on far fewer?).


Overall the game is really well done. As a new player I have some minor things I feel would make getting into the game easier:

 - Hovering a unit or clicking it should more visibly show what aura it has/what it does/etc. The top left corner has the unit card with its abilities really small underneath, but it really just isn't very intuitive or new user friendly. I played Squad TD on Starcraft 2 and it was easy to see what each unit did and how it worked. This game makes it a little more difficult to figure things out regarding specific units (primarily upgraded versions of them). 

- Please fix the UI scaling. Text boxes go crazy when you use it, but without it on 1440p the UI is hard to read.

Honestly that's it. Figuring out the units is really the only thing annoying me so far, everything else in the game is pretty intuitive. I'll update this if anything else comes to mind. Still a great game though, the things above are quite minor.

In my experience, this is one of the best tower defense games out there. The Warcraft III mod was great and so is this. The only downside is that it has a steep learning curve. You have to know exactly how to spend your Gold to push workers at the right time to win against everyone. It's fun to learn how to push workers and find the right minions to hold waves. It does not get old fast. Great value for he money

Legion TD 2 is a good game... But, with a huge warning. Yes, this is a  TD game - But, it's also a super ugly TD and "Old Skool" TD game which will turn off certain players.

You know those old WC3 mod games? Imagine a more uggo that. But! Despite that, the mechanics? Absurdly good. It's like... got German engineering design where some elite team afflicted with only the highest levels of autism developed a TD game but somehow got one fat dude with a voice mod to do all the unit voices. 

You really need to watch someone stream this to see if it is for you. But, for those people looking for that old TD 4/4 feel, this is it.
Yes.
love it

It's a really, really super fun game. I love the 2v2 format, I have only experienced 4v4 once but it was also a great experience.

If you're looking for a game that is fun to play from the get go, but that has also a lot to learn about, this is a good game for that. I'm not even in a positive ratio of win / loss at the moment in ranked, but that's fine ! It's just motivating to see my opponents do things that I don't understand yet, things that I can pick up and adapt to my playstyle.

This game (at least in low elo, which is the only thing I experienced so far) allows creativity, you can approach each game with different strategies in mind (some players absolutely want fast wins, some other are more comfortable building towards late game), every game is different with different units to play with. It has that feeling of "unfairness" at first, but every little thing you learn reduces that, this game is a lot less rng than it might seem at a first glance.

I love the build and Tower placement and the micromanagement between waves building the right tower and sending the correct mercenary to attach opposing team during the wave. 

SO YES I AM ASKING YOU ONE FAVOR PLEASE DOWNLOAD AND PLAY THIS GAME, I CANNOT THANK THE DEVELOPERS ENOUGH!!! YOU ARE TRULY LIFE SAVERS!!!

Coming from the Starcraft 2 Mod Squadron TD2, I liked the concept of the mod/gamemode already. I Loved the units and all and when I saw that this was in the making I was pretty hyped for a game to play on the side. I was there for the Alpha and Beta and played it on and off and I really like what it has become. The game back then felt rough around the Edges but it gets more polish and thought put into it with each update which I value a lot.

Gameplay wise, it's a Tower Defense-ish game. You have to survive Waves, each with different Attack and Defense Types. So in order to withstand the different types of enemies, you have to build a good mix of everything. The newly added Units/Factions add a lot to the fun, each theme is cool in of itself and offers so much more variety for the Mastermind Builder, basically a "get a random assortment of everything" kind of builder. This is where the magic happens and where the fun begins, when you get through that initial window of learning the mechanics and get to the point where you can just try shit out. What also helps a lot is the Campaign and Build Testing Support. I am currently hooked to beating the hard modes of the Campaign, which also give you good opportunity to actually learn and try out different things.

All in all, I have been coming back to this game on a half-yearly-basis and I enjoy it now more than ever because of the new variety of Units and their potential. Great to see this game come along so well and I can definitely recommend this game for Fans of Tower Defense of the expanded kind. As a Teamfight Tactics Player I needed a fresh wind and this game keeps on bringing me back, for multiple years already.
Worth it!
