[h1]The Good Old Games of the past brought back to modern age[/h1]

This is a game mod for Warcraft 3, now professionally done as a stand-alone game by their previous creators. We don't get games like this anymore.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

The main gameplay of this game is building your own lane while sending mercenaries to enemy's lane while building your economy with spare gold. A simple concept, but it is incredibly complex to master. First, game feels like a puzzle game. Waves are always the same. You have to figure out the most optimal strategy for each wave. You can pick or roll unit roster. Each roster will have unique strengths and weaknesses. This will define how well or poorly your early game will be and vice versa, how strong your end game units are going to be. There are plenty of openers which defines how well you can scale, which are your strong and weak waves. You have to learn all of it while following what the enemy is doing and punishing its mistakes. You can do a mistake by building too much units and not purchasing enough workers. If enemy is doing that, instead of sending mercenaries, save them for a bigger wave. If enemy is under-building and purchasing workers for late-game scalling, send mercenaries. This is how you are going to break through his lane and get free gold which will allow you to scale better and to ultimately overwhelm enemies with resource advantage. This interaction is very deep, it requires you to constantly see what your opponent is doing, know myriad of viable openers and nuances to them. Then build on their strengths and exploit their weaknesses in your opponent. First half of a game is like chess, it requires figuring out the most optimal build for any key combination of units.

Second part of a game is where you get a lot of gold. Where enemy armor and damage becomes powerful. Where your and enemy will have myriad of different units, different damage types and armor. It will become up to you to figure out against what they are weak, against what they are strong. In which waves they are going to perform well and poorly. What kind of mercenaries will perform well or poorly. Game becomes a lot more intuitive as there are way too many variables to ever to figure out. Gameplay changes from a puzzle to scalling. It is up to you to make most OP lane possible in order to deal with ever more insane waves. If neither manages to beat each other and game drags out, game will be decided by most insane build as they will delay and weaken waves the most which will cause game to be lost via attrition.

[h1]AI & Solo Play[/h1]

This game has surprisingly strong AI which will help you to figure out your strategies and how to play. If you would beat all non-cheating AI modes, you will be better than 70% of all players. Game also has campaign mode to play more casual battles against AI which is scripted to go for one or the other strategy. Game has tons of solo content and most of my time spent on this game was on solo content.

[h1]The Fun[/h1]

To me, the fun part is figuring out combinations, builds, unit placements. Figuring out mercenaries and for what they are good for. Game has ton of depth and literally thousands of hours of exploration. While game is static, your opponent provides a dynamic element which makes game unpredictable.

[h1]Game is not for everyone[/h1]

Some people might not like it, because it feels like a puzzle game until 11 wave and it is true. Your valid options are quite limited and you can figure out 1 best solution to your unit combination and to counter your enemy. Only later game becomes more dynamic and allows improvization. Game feels static and limited. You have to get hooked on desire to optimize and to figure out better strategies. This game rewards players who want to know every little detail about every unit and such information is needed if you want to progress far on leaderboards. 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

Game is not for everyone. It requires patience, desire to figure out inner mechanics, to figure out best builds. Game is a puzzle game at the start and stacking advantages at the end. Game is very competitive and requires a lot of experience and practice to play. It is fun game for people who like those kind of games and a blast from the past. I highly recommend for anyone who has interest in such games to give it a try.

- Some towers are just utterly rubbish, which is sad

Overall I'd still recommend this game but definitely needs a lot of improvement!

I've played this game since it's first iteration on the Original Battle.net Warcraft III Engine before the policy changes (And gutting of the original WC3), and I am happy they got their own platform. I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys Strategy Combat and Tower Defenses. And I am fairly certain I have owned this game since it's inception. Only thing that strikes me as odd is how it's still any early access game in Season 8. >.>

Currently close to 1200 hours in, I'm one of the top players of this game, so my review would be completely biased since I'm obviously addicted to the game because I've dedicated so much time to it, but I'll do my best to be as objective as possible from a new player's PoV.

Pros:
- can get addictive if you really enjoy these kind of games
- fast matchmaking, even though it currently has some balance issues
- really focused on the competitive aspect, so if you are a competitive player, this is the game for you. Sadly, the competitiveness comes at the sake of sacrificing some of the fun.
- fairly high replayability IF you are dedicated to learning the game, otherwise you'll find the game stale after a few matches.

Cons:
- slow content release
We were promised a new unit every 2 weeks, yet a legion which has a total of 6 units is released like once every 7-8 months due to development downtime and other issues.
- small playerbase
Game became 2v2 because of this, a change which arguably made the game less fun for many players. (This game is fun with friends, less friends, less fun for most people). The game is also pretty much dead during NA day/EU night, as there are only around 150 players online. So if you wanna play, I'd suggest you play during EU peak time.
- really STEEP learning curve
The tutorial doesn't cover nearly enough aspects of the game. You'll find yourself getting stomped for probably like the first 20-30h without having any idea why you lost/what you did wrong in the first place. There are not enough content creators providing quality guides for new players to learn how to actually play the game properly.
- ocasional client bugs
- toxic community
I guess this can be said about every multiplayer game. You'll probably find yourself the same toxic players as you found in games like LoL, DotA, CS:GO and others
THE MAIN CON:
- the price tag.
If you are really obsessed with this game, it can be worth 20$, but for ~97% of the players, it isn't.
If you really wanna try this game, it can be worth 10$ during the occasional sales, but even like that, probably around 50% of the players will stop playing after a few hours of gameplay, so keep that in mind when deciding to purchase it.

Honest opinion, you are better off waiting for WC3 Reforged, getting your Legion TD fix from wc3/sc2 custom maps (ignore DotA 2 LTD version, that thing is trash), unless the price tag on LTD2 goes down by a lot, or unless the development of this game speeds up by A LOT.

Some people might think this review might be biased because of my large amount of hours playing this game or by the fact that I am very invested in the evolution of the game and the growth of it. I promise however to be as objective as possible in this review.

TL;DR : I love this game, there are flaws, but so much fun can be had while playing and most of the community and developers are always willing to help any players with their problems. For that I recommend it for you, but I cannot decide for you. Create your own opinion.

To start by stating the facts, this game is made by a very devoted team of 4 developers. The result is not perfect, there are some few bugs here and there, but they are very open to those bugs and encourage any report of them to try and correct them in the following patch. This shows the willingness of the team to make the game better and attracting to all new players.

Speaking of new player experience, the honest truth is that the game seems pretty basic (place towers and hold incoming waves of enemies while trying to disrupt the hold of your opponent), but the skill ceiling is incredibly high and hard to reach. You need a lot of time investment to try and reach the top of the leaderboard and understand the different aspect of the game if you so wish to compete at the top. There are also some tournaments for those top players if they so wish to test themselves amongst the best. However, there are many different things a new player can do to try and improve or just play for fun, like playing the campaigns, playing against the AI, trying to beat the weekly challenge or even play a casual match of 4v4.

For those who want to improve, there is sadly not a lot of guides to go to and for that, there is two main reasons : the game is constantly evolving and the shear amount of possible combination and situations make it too large of a time commitment for non full-time content creators. Alas, do not fear, the top players of this game are often willing to answer any questions on the discord or on their streams and even analyse your previous game to tell you what you could have done or improved. This case by case approach is not ideal of course, but seems to be working well for the moment. The community will need to adapt to a larger number of players but there is already a large effort by the community (including myself) to include content on youtube to help players see the game the way top players sees it.

Also, the rate of content release is expected to be very slow due to the small team that is working on this game. However, every updates are treated with special care, often asking the opinion of the community to see if the update makes sense in term of power levels, playability and feeling. The base buffs and nerfs are however carefully treated thanks to a large amount of data including winrate and playrate. These numbers do not always tell the full story and that is why the top players often gives their thoughts on the current game state and unit state through some tier lists. This further helps the balancing of the game. 

To finish, we need to address the elephant in the room, it is a competitive game and thus is not protected from the judgement of the skills of others and sometime can lead to toxicity. There is a ban system and chat restriction implemented in the game and is reliant on the individual reports of the players. Since the community is small at the moment, the toxic behaviours are mostly suppressed at least in the range of players I encounter (which I admit is a small fraction). Online competitive games will never be fully protected from that because humans are humans and they are as they are, but the system to deal with it is implemented and well functional. I do however believe that the willingness of top players and the developers to help the community is a proof that the game wants to minimise the toxicity and do not promote it.

To the brave souls who went through the trouble of reading all of this, I do hope it was helpful to give you an overview of what the game wants to aim to be and how the community and developers are committed to keeping this game in constant evolution by doing updates, promoting tournaments and leagues as well as creating content on different platforms to help the playerbase improve and grow.

I cannot decide for you to buy this game or not, but I do recommend it even just as a casual game to play with your friends, trying combos, playing against yourselves, test your skills on the ladder or goof around in casual play while testing different units and synergies.

The possibilities only stop where the mind of the players decide to stop, thus creating a possible strategy or build to emerge at anytime if only one player decides to go further than the others.

This rec comes with a caveat: 
The majority of consumers will not have played a game like this before. In many ways, this point should be taken positively-- this is a unique experience that tries things most players haven't seen before. Very cool stuff.
On the other hand.... This game is $20. Normally, if a game so unique is only $20 I would call it a steal. In this case, the game is a multiplayer-focused play on the tower-defense genre; while there is (in my view) near endless replay value, and countless strategies to try out and play with.... 
It's going to feel like you're doing the same thing over and over. Which isn't the worst thing! Plus, they have implemented a solo & simple co-op, meaning you can enjoy the game without ever touching the multiplayer.
But it's something that weighs on me when I want to share this game with friends.

'Hey, look at this cool game; it's like nothing you've ever seen and we can play together. I've loved it since it was a custom game on Warcraft III and I backed their crowdfund. I think everyone should try this super cool passion-project.' 
But I gush knowing it just doesn't look like a $20 game. Quite frankly, I don't think it is a $20 game. I think it should be $10 tops. At a lower price point, this rec would be about how everyone should pick this up and try it.
Since it's $20, the uniqueness begins to work against the game. You're paying $20 to try something new, which is great, but because of its uniqueness I can't guarantee it's for everyone. Because it's so small, if it isn't for you it just isn't for you.
If this game were $5, I would be yelling from the mountaintops about how everyone needs to try this game; no excuses, it's $5 for something totally new for you and your pals to fall in love with.

But it's not. It's $20.

So I can tell you I adore this game, and that it's great for a few short games or a 3-hour marathon of games.
I think you should try it. You can probably do the tutorial and try a few games before the refund time runs out. If you like it, it'll be a game you can always come back to and I think you'll find your $20 well-spent.
But it is unique, it is small, and it is $20.

As a former [GGEZPZ] master of Squadron TD on StarCraft II, I was looking for a similar tower defense game with higher depth, and a developer team that valued community feedback. Squadron TD was, and still somewhat is a fun game, but the irregular updates and lack of metrics or analysis, due to the limitations of the StarCraft II Arcade, kept that game from reaching its full potential. Insert Legion TD 2.

LTD2 first caught my attention as a Kickstarter project that billed itself as "The first ever competitive TD for PC." This successor, being a standalone title, allows the devs to incorporate any additions or changes to the game without being limited by the mercy of the original game engine. The inclusion of a global leaderboard that tracks ELO ratings to identify how I stack up among all players really helps sets it apart from others. Skill recognizes skill: ranked badges, from Bronze to Legend, are awarded to players who obtain higher ELO tiers, and displayed for all to see next to your name; these ranks are also present on your frame for the following season.

This game has come a long way since it debuted in late 2017 when it featured only four legions. At first, I was off-put by how slow the pace of the game was. LTD2 initially promised shorter game times than the competition (https://beta.legiontd2.com/featuresgrid/). In contrast, coming from STD, the actions or animations were lethargic and felt like they were being played 25% slower; battles during waves felt like they were unnecessarily taking several seconds longer to play out which dragged matches on for several minutes longer than they needed to be. I, along with other players, expressed similar resentment in the Feature Requests board on the official LTD2. The following patch, the battles were sped up some.

Something else I wanted was post-game analysis. A way for me to get better was learning from my mistakes, but LTD2 did not have much in the way to allow for studying you or your opponents builds and sends besides tabs in the post-game screen only available after each match that only listed what towers were built, and what creeps were sent on each wave; even STD had interactive video replays. I wanted more, and posted my vision on the same Features Request board (https://legiontd2.com/community/threads/view-previous-games-history.14564/). The devs apparently listened because wave-by-wave build tables and send data were present in-game on a following patch shortly after. The devs are also active on the official LTD2 discord where they respond to any questions or issues in a timely manner.

Over the years, LTD2 has nearly its legions from 4 to 7+, and also added some new creeps that allow for greater versatility in attacking opponents. The Ranked game mode currently features competitive 2v2 mastermind (i.e., randomized, but selectable towers from different legions) play against opponents with similar ELO, halved from the original 4v4 matchups due to a relatively small playerbase that could not support a short match queue time. At high ELOs, queues can run several minutes before a match is found due to the relatively small size of the aforementioned playerbase. For 8-player games, a Classic mode consisting of 4v4 matches with all legion builders at disposal against players of all skill levels still remains. Official tournaments such as the semi-annual Master's Cup, open to qualified players, promote sportsmanship and reward special cosmetic unlockables. This is NOT a pay-to-win game.

One of my few gripes is the lack of a Chaos Builder or Chaos Mode. In STD, Chaos Mode features a mastermind builder that rotates out every 4 waves with a new set of towers which makes things more wild, but fun. In LTD2, once you select your assortment of towers at the start of the game, you can only re-roll your towers, from a reduced pool nonetheless, once more throughout the rest of the game which places a critical amount of importance on the initial selection phase. As such, games can feel a bit static as you navigate through the rest of the match with at most a dozen or less fighters. On the flip side, the addition selectable Legion Spells or in-game upgrades on Wave 11 adds some spice to the game.

Overall, the game feels fairly balanced. The devs constantly provide updates to tweak overused or underused units to ensure they are neither too overpowered nor weak. Casual players may appreciate the diversity of different towers while hardcore players will study the intricacies and synergies between towers and their placements to ensure they operate at optimal performance. Players are rewarded for strategically saving up mythium and striking during vulnerable waves instead of brainlessly sending every wave, with options to upgrade the king if they feel endangered. With 7+ different legions, 21+ waves, over a hundred towers, and dozens of creeps, there's a lot to learn, and even more to master.

AutoAttack Games is a small dev team consisting of a close group of friends, but they are as committed as they come as they regularly respond to community feedback and improve the game with constant updates. The devs are active in the community and high ELO players themselves, so if you play well, you have a decent chance of running into them as a partner or opponent in one of your matches. New content such as single-player campaigns, weekly challenges, or new towers are being added regularly. If you are a fan of STD or the original LTD, please give this game a try. Welcome to Nova!

I'll give this a sideways vote. Whilst i do enjoy this game, it could be much better. It seems to be a bit too meta/puzzle game rather than a wave brawler. The waves are the same every round, every game and only by working out the puzzle of different types of attacks and different types of defense used each wave can really get any enjoyment out of the game.

All units are static and cannot be moved unless refunded and repurchased to a different position. As previously stated, the waves are fixed not random, so it can get repetitive rather quickly. I really wish it had more randomized waves and less of a static puzzle.

My second problem with the game is that it is almost entirely decided in between waves 10-16. Wave 15 can be tough and everything past wave 15 is crazy tough. 
I think I've had maybe 3/100 games decided post wave 16 and sometimes i find myself not trying so hard just to let the enemy survive and go on to the next wave. I just think the game goes from too easy to too hard a little fast and not much in between time, so it mends rather abruptly. 

More Spells to choose from would be great, you can get sick of the same few options. Big snails, health regen, extra mythium etc.

Although it has it's flaws, it is still a fun game. But it needs something more to it and more optimisation. 
(Although it is EA still)

Get it on sale and definitely worth the price.

Also please add some kind of option when playing with ai to be able to block your team mate from sending. Sometimes i send a feint if i need an extra 6 gold, such as one snail, yet my ai partner will throw kitchen sink.

When the devs have built in a very specific way to get past each wave, that becomes more of a puzzle than a game. That is what this feels like. Failing to divine their intent for each of the first waves can really set you back badly. They know it so much that they've implemented a "tutor" to tell you how you were off, b/c the way to be on is so narrow that they can define that.

I'd say that defense is far too strong on creeps early in the game, making it so that your build needs to be nearly exactly to fit it or they will steamroll you in the first 10 waves. This needs some toning down. That's my 2 cents.

The game could be a ton of fun, but I want to *play* it. I don't want to figure out the exact way the devs intended for each wave to be dealt with. That's them playing and me repeating. I've seen too many TD games get ruined this way.

This game has a ton of potential, but it needs some very serious tuning on the early waves to make it more about playing your own style than playing the very narrow methods devs want you to play.
Not quite as good as the Warcraft version, but this could be due to my personal nostalgia. It's still a very suitable substitute, and continues to improve with each update.

Great adaption of a great WC3 mod. Good quality of life features like statistics and ranked matchmaking as well as some nice new strategic twists. It is hands down the best version of Legion TD ever built - nothing more, nothing less.

The general pace of the game is much higher than in the original versions. One 2v2 game lasts around 15-25 minutes which is just the right amount to keep you engaged while not having to sit through an already lost game. Speaking of which: -ff to forfeit the game if all players agree is a very useful command. 

The only downside currently is the price. The concept of the card collection and the shop feel a little bit out of touch with the fact that it's a full-price game. One would expect such mechanics in a free game with cosmetics to purchase for $$$, but here you somehow find both. There are even some game changing mechanics that have to be purchased for an ingame currency which you generate while playing - or you purchase it for real money. But those are very basic and not breaking the balance at all.

LTD2 is a different take on TD games, you get to play both sides of the game, both attacking and defending sides. You have to handle resources that result in either your victory or your downfall. You can win/lose early, or play the long game.

The game, much like Shrek has layers. When you first start the game you have a pretty basic understanding. Place your tanks in front of your dps and send units for income. As you play more the game peels back the layers. If you ever watch a high elo game you'll see exactly what I mean. Placement down to the square becomes crucial, buffs sharing to 6 units instead of just 4, tanks BEHIND the dps but still tanking, splitting the wave so that "sends" (what your opponent adds to the wave) go to one side and stop buffing as many units. Seems like the more you play the higher the skill cap gets from you. 

If you like competitive games, and knowing your the reason your team won or lost (trust me as soon as you leak or catch 101% of a wave you'll know) this is up your alley. I think the game lacks most in exposure. It has a smaller following (as of April 2021) and currently teeters on a balance of no one online, and the servers are down because everyone decided to play to day. I hope it continues to grow as it has and gets more server help.

All in all, if you like very high level tactics, a friendly entry level but brutal ranked system. This is for you.

Bought LegionTD2 on release (4 years ago) after having played the Warcraft 3 mod (LegionTD) frequently. After just a couple of rounds I went back to the Warcraft3 Mod because the visuals were bland and the game felt clunky. I did not touch the game for 3 years, but I picked it up again recently and already clocked in over 200 hours. 

The Devs really did a great job improving the game over the years it seems. They stuck with the game despite the massive drop of active players after the first months after release (3000 to 300). 

That being said the game has a active community and getting into games takes about a minute even in ranked matchmaking. 

The game itself is easy to learn but hard to master, which can be frustrating for newer players. 
Some reviews pointed out that the community is toxic but I have encountered only 5 toxic teammates in around 400 ranked games (2vs2).

If a competitive tower defense game sounds like a lot of fun to you, check it out.

ORIGINAL REVIEW: 

Difficult to learn. The unranked / classic version of the game - which is the only option to play against other people until you reach level 3, is overwhelmed by premade 4 man groups. There is no option to play the game unranked vs people who are also new, you are just matched with anyone and everyone. 

If matchmaking is fixed, the game itself is fun, complex to learn with many different tactics and strategies. But unfortunately until any fix is made, I'll be constantly losing to a 4 man group of German players with 1000+ hours.

UPDATE:

The additional options of solo and co-op campaigns allow you to learn the game without the frustration of being matched against higher skilled players

Classic is still quite overwhelmingly experienced players and groups, however with the offline content, you can learn how to play to combat these individuals. 
Ranked is definitely balanced and you will play people of similar skill levels to you

At best, this is a distant relative of the game that originated on battlenet, except lacking all of the eclectic strategies that made the original wonderful.  At worst, it's an unbalanced turd that you shouldn't buy into unless you can get it on a sale for /maybe/ five bucks.  Even then, within about 20 or 30 games, you've seen everything you're ever going to see.  

One of the chief problems with the game is just how obsolete most of the "towers" you can build are.  There's a select few strategies that work, and everything else is a novelty at best.  There's also nothing, absolutely nothing, segregating experienced plays from the new ones, and because this game has such a steep learning ceiling wrought with nuance, the winner of the game is almost always decided by the tenth wave.  From there, you're simply entertaining the players that are having a blast spanking you around.

They've attempted to implement mechanics that balance out the disparity between players, but it, simply put, does not work well, in fact, in 20+ games I've played since the update that introduced the mechanic, I've never, absolutely ever seen it make any sort of different, no matter whether you're on the receiving end of the winning team, or you're the ones winning.

Do not let the positive reviews fool you - the game is fun, almost addicting even in the same way those old Battlenet custom maps were - but the reality is that people tend to review this game while still in that very, very short "honeymoon" phase, rather than giving it about 30-40 or more hours to adjust and learn the nuances of the game.

At the end of the day, unless you can find a full group of four players to team up with and learn the game with, I wouldn't waste my time.  Games like this -never- balance out.  When a single player can ruin your entire experience and force a loss, you know you've discovered a stinker.

I could honestly go on and on about the negative aspects of this game - but I simply just don't want to invest that much into it.  If you're reading this, chances are you've already made up your mind one way or the other anyway.  There are better games out there that do this much better.  If nothing else, wait till it fully releases and they have (hopefully) improved the game and balanced it out.  

I suspect this game will never fully release and will fade into obscurity like most games of this caliber do.  Which is why I encourage you to only purchase this when it's on sale - if you're /that/ headstrong about buying into it.  Good luck!

This game is based from the various mods in other games - for me Squad TD in Starcraft 2 is the one i was familiar with, i haven't played mods for other games so assume the below is based on my experience of the Starcraft 2 mod.

The game is very similar to aforementioned mod. 21 waves, build 'towers' to defend the waves and send mercenaries to thwart your opposition.

Game option are 2v2 Mastermind (ranked) and 4v4 Classic (unranked) and a Custom Game section
I have only played the 4v4 Classic section at this stage. A new feature is the ability to 'roll' and get a new set of towers to exchange with your existing ones.
There is also the option to play against the AI and a Sandbox mode for trying out builds.

In my experience it takes about 1-2 minutes for a 4v4 games to start once queuing. I work normal hours for the UK so this may be peak times, i can't speak for daytime queue lengths.

Game modes are unlocked by earning Essense which you get from playing the game - there is Premium Essence (which you buy) to unlock cosmetics.

Chaos and Hybrid builders are available to buy with Essense, along with Mastermind perks - one being 5 income per wave and the other 3 income per wave + 2 re-rolls. I haven't played mastermind yet, but my understanding is you roll 10 towers and need to pick 6 to play with and this is the format for ranked 2v2 play.

Another great feature is your Match History where you can see what builds people used, sends and leaks, wave by wave. 

I have not been playing ranked but so far I have not experienced any toxicity in the community.

There is a Discord where the developers are both active and extraordinarilly responsive to issues.

I would say if you liked Squad TD, you will like this.

it's a massive pile of shit.

Not to say it's a bad game, it's just shit no matter how you slice it.

1). Horrible ratio of tutorial vs complexity.  It's like the tutorials, by design, are only meant for bot play.

2). Severe imbalance.  There are units("Towers") that are practically and effectively worthless.  I expect better from a game in EA for a year, let alone the 3 years this title's been milking.

3). Homogenized factions.  I don't know why they chose this mix'n'match method, but it basically makes the game get old a lot faster because there's no identity.  You play starcraft, age of empires, or any strategy game.  Each race/faction/etc feels unique.  Mix'n'match just pressures the devs too much to over-nerf certain units, over-buff others, and every single new faction introduces new broken synergies that constantly breaks what I can only loosely call "The meta".

Is it worth $10 bucks?  Yeah, probably.  It captured my attention long enough that I'm still iffy on whether I wasted the money or not.  $20 is a fuckin' scam, though.

Its just not good enough in its current state that I would tell friends they should get the game and play with me. If you are looking for an autobrawler type of game to replace some thing like Dota Underlords, TFT, Dota Autochess, etc, that has less RNG mechanics and more skill based play then this is the game for you. I definitely can't go back to something like Underlords after playing this; this is just a better game in most ways. The constant battle pass update screen after a match finishes and heavy RNG mechanics in Underlords (as well as constant meta shifts and other bad changes to the game) have ruined it for me. I am glad that I have discovered this game that doesn't have battle passes, has minimal RNG, has the depth of strategy that and RTS game has, and has a mostly balanced meta. I understand why this game has 'tower defense' in the name, but its more of a hybrid between an autobrawler and turn based strategy game.
The gameplay is just a little bit stale to me. Comebacks in Legion TD are hard to pull off because falling behind means a very difficult uphill battle and since this is a team based game, one player on your team can cause the entire team to fail and you often feel hopeless in trying to help that player catch up because you can't do anything like sending some of your troops or gold to protect them like you can in an RTS game to defend them while they build their economy and army up. All you can do in this game is catch their leaks but you have no option to help the player get back to their feet. Another thing that makes the gameplay stale to me is that you can't easily rearrange your army. Once you place a troop down, it stays in that spot for the rest of the game unless you sell it and repurchase it which will drag your economy. Similar autobrawler games let you rearrange your individual unit's placement. This lets the player react to the opponent. In this game each wave is static staying the same every match, but your opponent can use their economy to send extra attackers and if my opponent seems to have a favorite attacker like maybe they love to send lizard spams or maybe Froggo witches are strong against my composition so they keep sending those every wave, I would have so much more fun if I was enabled to rearrange my units to try to make it so my opponent has to start trying a new attack strategy on me instead of feeling oppressed by my opponent doing the same thing every wave while I wait to get enough gold to add to or upgrade my army enough to overcome it. Because I can reroll my available units to gain access to some different units, I often wish I could rearrange my placement mid match and I feel like the depth of the game is retarded by not allowing dynamic repositions between waves. This servers in this game also aren't good enough to have things like leavers penalties. Too many times I have had a game lag out when the match ends and either mine or my opponent team's King will be left at 1 or 2% health instead of dying and the game gets stuck then I am sent to the main menu and get a warning about being AFK or abandoning a match. I know that my connection is fine and I don't expect the servers to be as stable as big games that have dedicated servers and huge budgets, but it is very frustrating to get penalties when I know I am not at fault. Unless the servers either become a lot better or penalties are removed from casual game mode I will never suggest this game to other people knowing that there's a possibility of them getting temporary and permanent bans for issues that they are at no fault for.

VERY much like the custom game for WCIII but with its own ranking systems and guilds. Its a great game if you're a fan of tower defense games and want to add a bit more challenge with competition against others. The coolest part of this game is that you can send waves / monsters to your opponents lane.

Game Economy - Simple explanation of currencies and what they are used for.
1. You build your towers with gold.
--- Gold is earned from killing monsters in waves, and sending monsters to your opponents.
2. You gather resources similar to mineral mining in StarCraft with a miner.
--- This is the currency you use to send monsters to your opponent. 
--- You gain gold income from sending monsters to your opponents.

Legion TD2 is in one word awesome and a raw diamond of a game. First, having a competitive Tower Defense is not something you see often, and you're never bored of it because you're not trying to beat your level 18967 record by building the same tower 200 times.
You just want to smartly crush your opponents and see them write "gg" in all chat by building the best combinations of the 6 units the game gave you out of the 50+ available, and sending them more and more powerful mercenaries to support the initial creep wave, from the yummy, the sneaky, the underrated snail; to the almighty and merciless Kraken.

The game is very well balanced and updated quite regularly by the team, and unlike a lot of other competitive games, the community is very friendly and there are always top ranked players willing to give advices to the newcomers, whether it is during the streams, the Discord server, or even during a game (well, maybe only in fun unranked ones, because otherwise they're busy crushing their opponents to reach the top ladder)

And last but not least, this game is not P2W at all, the only thing you buy is the game itself, and newly added dope skins.

LTD2 is in my eyes the best strategy game out there!
The game is well balanced and updated every few weeks.
Since the release in 2017 a lot has changed and this only with a team of now 4 devs.

A lot of unique strategy features give the game a depth that you can spend thousands of hours in it as you see:D

All in all the game is absolutely worth a try for every fan of strategy games!

Team based kinda Tower Defense Game with the possibilty to play as a team of 4 while making income for yourself with sending stuff to your enemys, i really enjoy this kind of gameplay.

First off everything about this game needs to be speed up by at least 15, if not 25%. 3 years later and every session of this game still takes twice as long as it should.

 The balance of this game is still terrible. Tier 1 and 2 towers for most factions are just not good, most are either spammable or literal trash. As far as offense goes, the 40-100 tier sends are way more powerful than they have any right to be. Aura sends in general are cancer.

Improve the balance of this game. tier 4-6 towers should not be buildable in the early 2-5 waves when t1-2 towers are generally trash unless massed. There are too many tanky t3-5 towers that can carry the early game while building an economy, yet literally everything falls off in the face of the DPS of rounds 16+. The gold costs of everything in this game are completely off when a tier 4-5 unit can be build round 1 yet dumpstered in the late mid game.

Legion TD 2 is a really fun game to play, especially if you are a fan of Tower Defense games. In this review I will explain to you what the basic concepts are of the game and what I think about it.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Legion TD 2 is a game where you have to fight monsters each wave to protect the king. You do this by placing down fighters or "towers" in your lane. You gain 6 towers when you select your "Legion", your class. All Legions have their own unique towers, and some towers have special abilities like taking less damage or healing allies.
Whenever you kill the monsters in your lane you gain some gold. However if you are unable to kill all the monsters and your towers die then you "leak". Your monsters will go to your king. If your ally was able to kill all his monsters, then his towers are teleported to the king to defend. If you and your ally are both unable to defeat the monsters, they will attack the king and the enemy team will get even more gold.

But how can I make my enemy leak? This is where workers and mercenaries come into play. You can spend gold to buy a worker, and that worker will gather "mythium" over time. These crystals are used to hire mercenaries that will attack the enemy lane. Some mercenaries are simple, however others have special abilities like slowing the attack speed of an enemy tower or healing monsters that attack the enemy. Use these to your advantage to make the enemy player leak.

Mercenaries also give some "income", however mercenaries with abilites give a little less. Income is gold that is given to you at the end of each round. Income is important because otherwise you won't have enough gold to kill the monsters and mercenaries in your lane. However, do you save some mythium this round so you can try to send a stronger mercenary next round to make the enemy leak? [u]That's where the game starts to become really fun.[/u] You have to manage both your income and how much mythium you save to get stronger than your opponent and win the game. However, I recommend that you don't save too many rounds because then you will lose out on a lot of income.

You can also use mythium to upgrade the king. So when you leak and the king gets attacked, he will have more damage, heal more and deal more damage with his spell.

Something else you need to keep in mind is that all creatures have an attack and defense type. Pierce attacks are good against Swift and Arcane creatures, however creatures with Fortified or Natural defense take less damage. So try to make sure that you have all attack and defense types covered, and try to build the right attack and defense against the monsters that will attack you next round.

Finally, there are "Legion Spells". These are randomized every game and are unlocked at round 10. These can give gold, mythium, income or some neat effects. Do you want to overwhelm the enemy? Take Press the Attack or All Out Assault, which gives a big amount of mythium so you can send bigger mercenaries. Do you want your towers to heal whenever they attack? Then take Vampire, which makes it heal 20% of the damage dealt. Do you want [b]big[/b] snails to be sent to your opponent? Get Giant Snails so make these little critters a fiersome nightmare.

[h1]What makes it fun?[/h1]
This game is all about holding the enemy monsters and mercenaries, and making your opponent leak. This means you have to be very creative with what towers you use. Is your opponent mostly using Magic attack type towers? Then send on a wave where there are Arcane defense monsters and make the opponent leak, making him lose gold and giving you some extra gold. That gold can be spent by building even more towers, which allows you to hold the monsters and mercenaries in your lane. Over time you will gather enough of a lead to defeat the opponents and end the game.

Does your tower deal a lot of damage? Maybe I should place down a tower with an "aura" right next to it to give an effect that heals it whenever it deals damage. Or do I built a defense that is weak this round, so I am very strong next round? Do I save some mythium now, so I can send a very big mercenary next round?
These are all aspects of the game that take a little while to learn, however when you do understand these mechanics then the game becomes extremely fun.

[h1]What keeps it new?[/h1]
Probably the top #1 what makes this game good is the "Mastermind" legion. This gives a roll of 10 random units that you can pick from. This means that each game you play is somewhat different. You will also learn about all the towers in the game, which means that you will discover new strengths and weaknesses that give you a small advantage against your opponents. Also notice that in competitive play (Ranked) all players are locked into Mastermind, making not only your rolls but all players rolls unique and different.

Besides that, the game is constantly changing and updating. Currently they are busy designing a new legion, Divine, and whenever they finish a new tower they publish it and allow you to play it early in Mastermind. This allows you to experiment with new tower and test out new tower combinations, keeping the game fresh.

[h1]What is the game missing?[/h1]
[b]Daily/Weekly/Monthly content[/b]
This is my biggest problem with the game. Please give us some basic quests that we can complete daily, like "Reach Wave 15" or "Have 100 Income at the end of the game", which will spice up your playstyle a bit. We already have some form of weekly content, a single player mode called the "Weekly Challenge" where you have a set amount of towers and you need to hold the enemy monsters and mercenaries which quite a few people like. However, I think it's quite boring and usually I just beat it for the reward and I don't try to improve my high score. Instead, give us special challenges where you have to defeat monsters from wave 2 and 8 together. Or maybe we have to fight a single king-sized unit from wave 18, with increased stats and maybe even special effects. Just give us something new, not "yes play ranked but solo and you have to win this round". A weekly and monthly quest would also be nice, like "Win 7 games" (weekly) or "Beat the Weekly Challenge 3 times" (monthly). Maybe give a very small amount of premium currency for the monthly challenge to keep people engaged.

For me, this is the bigget why I don't play the game that much (only 750 hours compared to 1000/2000 hours played by people in my friends list).

[h1]Would I recommend the game?[/h1]
Definitely! The gameplay is fun and they are constantly adding new content and changing the game. The developers are great and I've had a few conversations with them, both on the forums and private chat. They are daily active on the forums and they have a special Discord channel where you can ask all kinds of questions about the game. A lot of players are very nice and forgiving, however like all competitive games you will have some bad apples here and there. 2020 was a good year, since a [b]lot[/b] of new content was added to the game, and it can only go up from here.

By far one of the best competitive Tower Defense games I have ever played. The challenge of balancing how much fighter/worker value is so different every game, yet so satisfying when you get it right.

Also the community is always there to help with any questions about the game. As most of the higher ranked players really enjoy and understand this game, they will try to help anyone else to understand and enjoy it too.

Would 100% recommend this game if you enjoy Tower Defense, you won't be disappointed

From windows perspective: This is a great game with hours and hours entertainment, replayability 8/10, addictiveness 9/10. Get this game.

From Mac perspective: Absolutely do not get this game yet. To say it's riddled with bugs is an understatement. I'm lucky enough to have both PC and Mac so I could just switch over and it didn't affect me but if you're playing on Mac only then you need to wait until at least half of the issues are handled before even thinking about buying. Horrendous graphic bugs from startup, crashes randomly, but also after playing for a certain period of time (2-4 games), game occasionally freezes up for like ten-twenty seconds before unlocking again, only the match has continued while you were gone...
Just don't. Wait for a more stable version.

But yeah, great game. Will be playing it a lot.

The pool of players are quite limited and you may play against the same opponent consecutively. For toxicity wise, I did not encounter a single toxic player from all my games so far. The gameplay is amazing, with a wide array of strategy to learn from. The UI is simple but gets the job done. 

While there is a tutorial provided for beginners who have joined the game, it doesn't really go in depth in explaining it. As such, beginners will probably fumble about in their first few games until they got the gist of it, provided that they haven't refund the game yet.

The 'store' feature has also not been implemented yet but is not much of an issue as it doesn't impact the gameplay at all.

[b] TLDR [/b]

Legion TD 2 will prove to be a very fun and addictive game if you equip yourself with the [strike]right[/strike] lethal knowledge.

PS. Check out the Community Forum in Legion TD 2 website for beginner's tips and strategy guides.

This is another game that I didn't even think I would enjoy and bought out of complete boredom. A friend of mine has 1000+ hours on it, so I had to see what would cause him to invest so much time.

I was surprised. Yes, the game plays like I thought it would, but there is really a good amount of strategy here. You have to learn which guys to summon at which time, where to place them, how the various waves will bend to the right or left, do AOE, fast attack, tank, or ranged, as well as the rock paper scissors game of dmg type vs armor type. Then plan on how much to invest in your immediate needs vs buying workers which give you a secondary resource that you can screw over your enemy with and boost your own long term economy with.

The game plays like this (In Ranked):

At the start you pick your roster from a random set, making sure you have different damage types and defense types covered, while looking for synergy or combos. At wave 10 you also get 3 spells to choose 1 from and which 3 you will choose from is also available at the start, so you can take that into account.

Then you place minions before the wave starts trying to have just enough offense and defense to overcome the wave, but also trying to guess if your opponent will send extra baddies at you based on what they did previously. Each minion you place costs gold, which accrues as you defeat the wave, kill the opponents baddies they send, and when your both your opponents fail to hold their waves and their king gets damaged.

You also have the option to send extra baddies at your opponent. It costs a second resource to do so, called mythril. The baddies you send have different abilities that synergize with different waves and counters different opponent setups. These baddies will also boost your economy a little or alot as you buy them. So you can play the compound interest game, or try to take advantage of your opponents while they are vulnerable. It's all very push pull timing , making judgement calls on what is going to reap you the most rewards and/or win the game and when.

You win by breaking through and taking out their king.

Oh, and they can also spend mythril to make their king stronger, so it attacks and defends better vs the baddies that break through. So that is another decision that has to take place each wave. Are they going to break through?

It really has quite a bit of decision making and working with your ally. I always say, the more decisions a game has, the better. This game is great for some 30 minutes spurts, of strategic goodness. For the price tag being so low, I've gotten at least an hour for every 10 cents. Highly recommend!

So I've played this game for 680+ hours and even wrote a build order guide for my favorite legion in it, yet somehow after three years of enjoyment I neglected to actually write a review. Oops.

Well, spoiler alert, I like this game. A lot. And I like it most for what it isn't: Legion TD2 is not your typical TD experience. You're not building a maze, nor are you placing static towers along a preset path. You're also not playing alone - you are but one person on a team that is competing against another team for survival.

So what ARE you doing? Making tactical decisions. Choosing carefully which fighters to place and where (don't be fooled - the lack of mazing doesn't diminish the importance of proper placement). Managing resources. Scouting your opponents to try and anticipate their next move. Losing a lot while learning, but getting better and better with every game. Figuring out when to push economy vs when to build up defenses. Sending mercs into their lanes while dealing with their mercs that were sent to yours.

The devs have made valiant attempts to make this game accessible, but there's no denying it has a steep learning curve. Expect to spend several hours across multiple defeats before things start clicking and you start building more efficiently. This game is all about nuance and has incredible depth for those who are willing to put in the time and effort. Don't be afraid to ask questions - there's an official forums, a discord server, and an in-game chat.

Definitely worth the money in my book.
A bit of a steep learning curve, but overall a varied and fairly balanced strategy game that provides hours and hours of entertainment.

TLDR: IF YOU PLAYED LEGION TD WC3 YOU WILL LOVE THIS GAME 100% SO GET IT YOU WONT REGRET!
-match making is v fast, -pretty hard but winnable, - great pvp, -lots of builders and play styles

Coming from someone who played Legion TD on WC3 over 15 years ago for a very long time, Legion TD 2 is basically that but streamlined and refined in every way - Lumbering is more straight forward, easy to build your team, i absolutely love it and it's so addictive; 8 hrs disappeared before i knew it while i was playing with a friend that i used to play WC3 legion with back in the day. Matchmaking is super quick too. It's a more fast paced game than the original mod on WC3 as well so games do end a lot quicker which isn't bad but it's really hard to reach late game. 

There're a few things that need some work though; Late game is high skill cap only.
-the game is very unforgiving - i can't get passed wave 16 and i came first 6 classic un-ranked matchmaking games in a row; if the game allowed for at least 3-4 more waves before it hit that difficulty then you'd be able to deal with it + get a little further after that given the increase lumber or "mythium" as it's now called. 

The reason this needs fixing is because this pressure of maximising early really only allows for a few different builds in each builder and you can't really experiment much- padding it out and would at least allow for more variations on how/what you built in your team.

This game pace ends up making the game highly dependent on smashing your opponents with coordinated creep waves where you send like 6 brutes collectively at the same time say on a boss wave; as opposed to the game being more about your build and layout.

- Menus and stuff could do with some work - your party disbands after the end of a customer game; that being said you're waiting max 30 seconds before the end the last game and start of the next which is great.
- if the game was patched to allow for easier waves until say wave 20, games would last longer which i'd personally love because i love having a nice chunky layout build to attack with
- AI is super hard, but now unbeatable and would be great for varied difficulties; my friend and i beat them maybe 15% of the games we played. It's a good skill test but their far too perfect in lumbering and sending creeps at the right times. 

Fantastic game, needs a few touch ups, super worth buying, if you loved it in WC3 you will 100% love this
Best part of WC3  as a stand alone

pretty fun game. it helps that i played legion td back before DoTA consumed all wc3 custom games, amongst many other co-op and competitive oriented tower defense games since then. so how's the learning curve for someone that only remembers legion TD by name?

well, if you're familiar with basic concepts like maximizing your economy (which any solo or PvE oriented tower defense will grind into you), you already have your foot in the door. early on, you can probably play this very similarly to a single player tower defense, as matchmaking will pair you up with players approximating your skill. the tutorial did enough to teach me game specific mechanics (such as auras and the multiple resources available), but nothing can really replace just getting into games and seeing what works. 

my experience with the community so far has been fairly positive - i've exclusively played random matchmaking games (both casual and ranked, though leaning heavily towards ranked), and while many players are silent, i'd say that more than half of the time, my teammate has offered feedback on how to respond to what the enemy team is up to. a willingness to concede to the opinion of someone more experienced than myself has helped expose me to strategies i wouldn't have considered, which has also allowed me to see the tactical depth of the game. following their advice hasn't always resulted in a win (the advice may not have been perfect, i may have executed the advice poorly), a willingness to try new things and implement a strategy of some sort is a must in order to win or enjoy the game.

I think this game exists adjacent to modern autobattlers, but i personally find this more engaging. the positioning of my units feels like it has more impact, and not having to prepare a squad that can enter into one of 7 random matchups makes it easier for me to learn what works and what doesn't. matches are short enough that i feel comfortable squeezing them into shorter breaks i may have, but they're also long enough to feel a good variety of gameplay, even within a single match.

the size of the community seems more than sufficient for the matchmaking options the game has. i've tried playing at many different times of day, and have rarely had to wait more than 40 seconds for a ranked match. the game is fun, and i can play when i want, for as long as i want, without feeling punished for not hitting arbitrary progression milestones - a strong point in this games' favor, compared to a free to play game like minion masters. some may balk at the price, but having picked the game up on sale, i found myself wishing there was some way to show additional support for the team, like cosmetics to reskin my board or units.

As someone who bought this knowing nothing of it I have to say the first impressions of the game is that it's not very good, I haven't played much yet but overall it hasn't done much to endear me to it.

The tutorial wasn't particularly useful as it didn't so much as teach me as it instead told to put down a certain unit somewhere without actually explaining anything.

The game itself once I started playing was a long slog not really doing much mixed in with having to meticulously place units, the placing of which is an annoyance by itself as once you place a unit heaven forbid you want to shift them around or happen to misplace a unit, no instead you have to first sell a unit or units and a reduced cost.

One of the worst things about the game is that I don't know what it is I'm doing wrong when something happens and I get wiped, is it a bad match up? are some units not worth getting as a cost to unit ratio? do I have too many or too little tank units? there just isn't any feedback to my decisions and in pretty much any other strategy game you can tell if your way of building and playing is working but with this whether you win a particular round feels arbitrary and not a product of my actions.

The community and interacting with it leaves much to be desired as it seems to propagate the same screeching toxicity present in MOBA games and that is all I want to say about the social interaction with other players.

Overall not particularly enjoyable and no, trying to force  someones twitch stream on me when I'm in the main menu is not going to make me want to watch it.

There's a bunch of problems with this game. One would be the queue. Matches are highly imbalanced. I think this is because of the smaller playerbase (something the devs have chosen to hide- you used to be able to see how many players were online, but no longer) Another problem is the rolling at the start of competitive matches likes to give you all the same damage/defense types and you often can find yourself stuck with a group of low DPS units that are impractical on higher waves. One of the other problems is the units you can send against your opponent- everyone spams brute and early on with a mediocre to bad roll it can effectively destroy your whole economy and the game just becomes a slow loss. My biggest gripe is I always get paired either with someone much better or much worse than me. It never feels like a close game like it used to. It's either a slaughter or a potato match.

This game has a very unique and interesting economy system where investing in one area now will pay off with another resource later, which is used to further progress. The majority of the game seems to be about getting that balance of resource investment correct as you play. 
Unfortunately as much as I like the game and the idea, I cannot recommend it. The game is quite difficult to get in to, because there is basically nothing out there to teach new players. All of the guides are far out of date and even if they were still applicable, the information provided doesn't really help a new player understand where they are making mistakes and how to properly start. I've been to the Steam forums, official forums, Discord, and YouTube looking to improve at this game, and basically it seems that the current playerbase is what it is and is not looking to expand. 
Also I question the current format offerings. You can play unranked at 4v4 or ranked at 2v2. The problem is that a) the 4v4 format operates a bit differently from 2v2, and because it's unranked you get people trying things that have no chance of working. There isn't a lot you can do to interact with your team mates or help, so a poor or afk player will ruin the game. 
Then the ranked format forces all players to use the "Mastermind" allegiance, which is a random selection of units from all factions. You can re-roll to get hopefully better options, but this is really meant for people that have a deep understanding of all the units in the game. In essence, the unranked games are generally bad and the ranked format is for experts. 

There is the ability to do custom matches, but the playerbase is already so small that it can't really support this.

What Legion TD2 does right is keeping setup and gameplay simple. It should be readily understandable and playable by any Tower Defense fan. However, the added hook of constantly finding ways to break (or leak through) your opponent's defenses gives Legion an entertainment edge not found in most static TD games.

It's simple drag and drop placement and click to send mercenaries UI is efficient. What new players will want to focus on is the build orders and defense strategies for their units. That will take some time to get used to. Once you have "it" though, the game really opens up. It has been a blast facing players from all over the world (player nation flags are displayed next to their name), and facing all kinds of different strategy ideas. 

The basics of the game is to overwhelm your opponent with units, to break their defenses. Each wave of enemies are of a certain type, melee or ranged, pierce/impact/magic damage, with respective defenses. Planning which mercenary (additional units you can hire to augment the incoming wave) to use and anticipating your opponents next wave is what drives me to keep playing this game.

The game is supported by what seems to be just two developers and I think they do a great job with regular updates, patch notes, and more. I would love to see a more competitive arena, more modes, and even a graphics overhaul or two -- but overall for the amount of hours I have fun (and continue to have fun) with this game it was worth 10x the amount I paid for it.

The Devs are really behind it and try to balance the game as much as they can. They are communicating with the community nicely and bring up new content regularly. 
Buy it! The community needs to grow!
To me it‚Äôs one of those little diamonds in the gameworld, as it is cheap, easy to understand but you can still grind it really really really hard, if you like, without being bored by repetition or enraged by devs that do not care a bit about their own work.

I love tower defense games, it is in my top 3 game genres and I have played countless different ones.  If you love the Starcraft 2 arcade game, "Squadron TD", you will definitely enjoy this game.  With that said....

There are quite a few bugs still, but it is early access so it is kind of a give in.  It seems that the updates for the game are getting smaller and smaller, and doing less and less in terms of new content and features.  This game is still really fun and has plenty of re-playability if you are a TD lover.

Sadly, the community on this game is very small and can lead to fairly long queue times at the off-hours, but during the peak hours it isn't too bad to find a game.  Usually less than 5 minutes.

Overall, I do recommend this game and I think it has a lot of potential.  I'm excited to see what the future holds for it, and I really hope that the devs are working on some cool stuff.

Legion TD 2 is a port of a pretty old Warcraft 3 map, just as DOTA 2 was before it. Unlike DOTA however, this is a team-based tower defense, as the name would imply. It's ranked mode is a 2v2 match where you build towers in a lane that become units to fight an oncoming wave of preset creatures, both in creature type and number of creatures, but the attacking wave is also bolstered by the enemy team through mercenaries bought with mythium, this games version of lumber, a resource gathered by workers which also increases the amount of gold you gain at the end of every wave. Workers can be bought for 50 gold and compound in value over time, but this is where the game gets interesting. The game revolves around your relation between army value and worker count, I.E your standing defense and your income. The more income you have, the higher level creatures you can send to your opponent, making it more likely he will leak, however this also requires you to sacrifice army value which may cause YOU to leak instead. It creates a dynamic that leads to fun gameplay, though it might not be very exciting to watch given the incredibly slow pace at which the game is played. Overall, it's a good successor to its original inspiration and well worth the purchase if you like tower defense games, however the community is pretty toxic, so don't bother if you can't handle some cunt from the US or Sweden whining at you.

This game had me hooked from day 1 after getting it. While heavily disputed by some members of the community, the devs keep a constant patch cycle and always add more to the game, in order to reach a similar status of variance as there was back in their Warcraft 3 map. Yes, according to my information they were part of the original creators of that map. 

That being said, as of lately, a new major patch was deployed. By removing the supply cap, it shifted the weight from intensive planning ahead for ressources to an even more casual or arcade style of game play, which I think is a good decision to help new players getting into the game more easy. Some mechanics and nearly all units have been touched up, so that the meta game was broken and the new ranked season could start off fresh. Good thing! 

This is a game, where you are required not only to manage your own defense, but have to plan the offense carefully and in consensus with your team mate(s). You can make a lot of different decisions each game which adds to a very diverting gameplay, all the while a match rarely ever reaches 30min playtime. It is a nice game to just hop in for one or two matches, but may also lead to all-nighters. 
Check it out, join the fun and help this indie team to grow ;) 

Kind regards!

The popular WC3 mod made into a standalone game. While the playerbase is relatively small, it is not too bad and finding games is usually not a problem. The game is easy to learn, but somewhat hard to master. As you play more, you will discover that the game has multiple layers of strategy. The price is reasonable, especially on sale, and the game offers hours of entertainment. I recommend this game all the way, it really needs a bigger playerbase.

Ive played legion td since wc3, this version on and off since early closed testing. They raised quite a bit of funding and the team has since done a great job, you still get that legion td feeling but now in a modern, competitive format which will definitively help grow the player base even further. There were slight worries in the beginning since a lot of the basic functionality wasnt in place when the players were let loose on to the game. But a lot has happened since those days, today it's a very clean, fast and fun experience. I really do recommend this game for those of you who like the moba style games, or simply played the mod back then. Well done Lisk & co.

I just read a couple of reviews of the game which made me write this one. 

Some people complain that there no longer is legions in the game, which turns the game into a RNG party. That is just false. In ranked (2v2) it is true you no longer can pick a legion, but is it unbalanced? No. The very active devs have made the game balanced by having every damage and defense type present in your roll. They even added some AI roll helper to help new players select a good roll. +1 for that. 
However, it is true there no longer is competetive 4v4, but I see that as a positive thing, as your decision has greater impact on the game in 2v2. If you truly love 4v4 you can still play it casually though. :-) If you're a new player (which you still are, even though you played the WC3 mod) i recommend you play 4v4 and learn the basics. How to effectively push workers, good unit positioning, sends, dmg/defense types etc. 
I would say the game has a pretty steep learning curve if you want to play competetively and I love that. Makes the game more fun and strategic the higher elo you climb to :-)

Very active developers ensure that the game is fun to play and doesn't get boring. Many patches are being released. New legions are being added and filled up with new units, it is a project I have loved to follow over the months I have been playing. Look forward to many more months. I currently put 564 hours into the game, a lot of afk, but still quite a few games :p 752 games to be exact :-)

I have really been enjoying this game so far and over 200 hours in now and I still have tons to learn. Legion TD2 is a surprisingly deep game with many layers of strategy. The different legions and the units within them all feel unique and full of character. Matches can often be unpredictable, and your decisions and knowledge of damage types, defences, mercenaries and minions will make or break you. It is a great feeling when you outsmart your opponents and work together to bring them down. 

The only issue I have had with the game is that it is quite unintuitive. Often you will have one game where you do well and sail through the match and others where you fail miserably, leak every wave and be unable to make any sort of comeback. When the latter is the case it is very hard to figure out exactly what it was that went so horribly wrong. This makes it harder to improve how you play. 

Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone who loves tower defences with a lot or character, and deep strategy. I look forward to seeing it develop further and trying out the new legions and their minions as they come out.

Do you want your classic 4v4 competitive Legion TD? Forget it. Because at first, they outright REMOVED 4v4. Then they brought back 4v4 for just CASUAL but also removed FUCKING LEGIONS. YOU CANNOT PLAY LEGIONS IN LEGION MOTHERTRUCKING TOWER DEFENSE right now. Yeah, only Mastermind. RNGFest. Why? Because devs refuse to bang their head against a wall called balance. Instead, make the ranked play mode RNG only so when someone gets a bad roll, they can only complain about the randomness element rather than balance of the Legions. I bought this game to play Legion TD. And last time I checked, I could play Legions in Legion TD. Not anymore. At least not after season 2 wrapped up.

Long story short; You can't play Legions in ranked, ONLY Mastermind 2v2 RNG moshpit. 4v4 and Legions are available in casual only. If you wanted competitive matchmaking and ELO in your good old regular Legion TD, this is not that game anymore.
So after playing this game for about 500+ hours I can strongly recommend it for all LTD wc3 fans. Some mechanics are completely changed but it's still a great game. Waiting for new units

This game might seem a little shallow and simple at first glance, but it has an amazing depth. Its easy to get started, but hard to get good.
When playing ranked, you are forced to figure out a new tactic in every game, as you are given a pool of random units to choose from, and must figure out the best combination. For the same reason its hard to come by a manual for this game, as not two games are the same. You have to rely on your own experience and calculations.
This is really appealing to me, as I hate when the pro-scene dictates whats right and wrong, and where people feel like there is no room for experimentation. Of course there are general rules and stuff to learn, but you cannot watch a replay of a good player, and just copy his tactic and moves, you need to think for your self in every ranked game! If you don't like thinking for your self, I wouldn't recommend this game.
Another thing I like about this game, is that it does not rely on your mouse-skills or how fast your reaction is, as its kinda turn-based. 
This is a competitive, relaxing game where its about being smarter than your opponent.
Love it, nice and simple but highly addictive :)

Legion TD 2 is a "continuation" too the custom WC3 Map Legion TD. 

In my opinion, although with only 10 hours of gametime so far (there will be much more to come)
this is a true successor to the original wc3 custom map. It improves in various aspects of gameplay, and will only continue to improve, no doubt.

Surprisingly well balanced, each match is completely different from the last, and you have to continuously adapt your builds and playstyle round-per-round depending on how your opponent acts, giving a more direct and deep strategic experience, this was also how the original Legion TD played out, but no where near as exciting and polished as this lovely game.

The game consists of either vs Bots, a casual 4v4 matchup vs other players to learn the game and improve - and a 2v2 ranking system that i've yet to try. 

Graphically the game is fairly unique imo, it fits what i'd expect from a modern day TD, and gives a unique feeling.

I recommend this game to anyone who's interested in competitive / casual TD games where you're fighting other players.

2019: 4v4 is back, i am happy... Now i'm waiting for the 6v6

2018: The problem comes down to my expectancies, see, my friends and I bought this game with the hope of it being our long-sought co-op game, that we could play on and off with two, three or four people for an unlimited amount of time, it was the flexibility of this game that attracted us. And that was the reason why we played the first Warcraft 3 mod Legion TD, and it's why we decided this new game was worth our money. And at first it was, it met all of our expectancies, we spent hours having fun. However, the game developers decided to change it, on a noble attempt to balance matchmaking they removed our one dealbreaker factor, its flexibility, we could no longer play with more than 2 people (well sure in custom games we could but ranked and casual games were the bulk of the fun) the move of changing the game from a 4 vs 4 to a 2 vs 2 made me and all of my friends regret buying it, it felt like they gave us this great thing, the game we were looking for almost 4 months and then just took it from us. The game was one thing at the beginning, and another at the present, it feels like being cheated or lied to, we loved it for what it was but cannot deal with what it turned into.

At the current state of game, some features are different from the map in WC3:
- No team duels after every 10th wave
- Only 2v2 instead of going up to 4v4
- Can't upgrade the king(this makes the game more difficult in my experience so far, leaking after wave 14 is highly risky)
- New class skills(or should I say passives) after 10th wave(a nice feature but I think it needs some work, most of them feel reduntant/unnecessary)
Overall, I could recommend this game to all previous Legend TD lovers and those who wanna try out a TD that is competitve and has PvP.

First - can't believe I delayed writing a review so long.  This game is straight up awesome if you enjoy Tower defenses and turn based strategy. The tower war set up pits you and an opponent against two others. It is fun at a casual level and competitive. The armor types, attack damage and special abilities for units keep the gameplay fairly dynamic and regular patches keep mixing up the meta.  The creators Jules and Lisk are engaged with the community around the game and pay attention to feedback.  There are regular updates which continue to enrich the game. 

I was originally leery about the purchase price and paid full price for the game to support the developers (and admittedly played the original on Warcraft 3) and have zero regrets. I hope to see the player base continue to expand!  All in all, if you are on the fence, buy the damn game - it is great.

I googled a Legion TD guide for warcraft 3 and ended up finding out about this game. Needless to say.. I've been playing the warcraft version for over 5 years so I bought it without hesitation instantly and got into the game. The game-play is very similar to the original, but they made it much simpler, as in you no longer have a builder, you just select a unit and build on the tile. AOE ranges are displayed, buff ranges are displayed, and sending income and gathering workers is one click of a button. Overall, I'm very impressed with what they've done with the game, but I still feel like it's lacking. They made it so that the game is only 2vs2 instead of the traditional 4vs4, which makes it much more slow-paced and a little "bleh" in terms of competitiveness. Apparently there used to be a 4vs4 option earlier on but the devs thought it would be a good idea to remove it(it wasn't) and make it only 2vs2. If you're REALLY into Legion TD like I am.. I'd say buy this game.. And hope that they eventually re-introduce 4vs4 so we can play the game like it was intended to be played. But if you're just a player who doesn't know what Legion TD is, or you're looking for something "exciting" or "fast-paced", this is definitely not it, and you should avoid it.
