[b] How do we make robots?	[/b]1


Imagine building a robot in three stages.

First you have to build the skeleton of the robot. Just like with the human body, a robot‚Äôs skeleton is able to keep it in place, as well as provide parts for the muscles, or motors and actuators in this case, to mount on.

Adding the motors and actuators is the second step. The motors can be controlled by wires and electronics.

The last part involves building the brain. The brain can be a computer or some other piece of software that‚Äôs running to tell all the motors what to do.

There are many different types of robots. Opportunity and Curiosity are two rover-style robots currently on Mars being used to advance science. Other robots include drones you see flying around that can be used to take videos or explore areas.

Some robots may run on your phone, like Siri on iPhones, for example. Siri does not have the mechanical aspects of a skeleton and muscles, but has a brain, and is still a robot or an intelligence.


This year the robot will be a Mars rover style robot that will be used for outreach events and robotics competitions.

Here's a few pros and cons:
PROS:
-Frequent Updates - Their team is growing! from 2 to 3 and now to almost a dozen. I see updates almost every week, with new balances, occasionally new units, and features.
-Community Contribution - The devs asked if people could help translate Legion TD 2 and as soon as they did, several language packs were created by help from the community.
-2v2 or 4v4 - To climb ladder, the games are 2v2; however, you can play 4v4 by creating a custom game and joining it.
-Variety in Builds - After gaining a few levels (which happens pretty quick), there is a mastermind legion.  It allows you to create a custom pool of units from the 5 legions, but you only have 10(?) that are available to choose from the 27 (currently).  It keeps the game entertaining and fun.

CONS:
-Learning Curve - There is still a learning curve, but they now included a crash course on how to play the game.  Definitely helpful to go through as it shows the ebb and flow of how the game works.
-Small User Count - Its not @ 100k yet, but its steadily growing slowly but surely.
-Peak Times at odd hours - Since I'm on a work hiatus, I noticed the 
-$20?? - As of now, I don't think the game is worth $20, but it has been occassionally on sale.  As the devs are creating more content, i believe it will one day be worth $20, but as of now its to help out this great game get launched!

I will make this a fairly simple review for those interested in purchasing the game.

Pro's:

- Active development, developers are actually involved within their own community
- Relatively short queue times (Sometimes 10 seconds, max a minute in ranked for me)
- Great "modern" remake of the Warcraft3 Custom Map
- Some extra strategic involvement due to the armor/damage type system
- A lot of friendly players in the community willing to help you improve

Con's:

- 2v2 instead of 4v4 to keep the queue times short
- Few players that cant handle the competitive atmosphere and can flame from time to time (But we got a report button for that)
- Tutorial is a bit buggy (Recently implemented, and as they're a small team this still needs some work)

This just my personal opinion after playing this game for around 35 hours.

The TD That Wishes It Was a MOBA

I played the original release of Legion on WC3. I was involved in the original forum. I was in a clan that split it's time between LTD and Battleships. Through the years, I'd walk away from battle.net and go play other things, but then I'd get a craving for custom games and go back. I've seen many many iterations of Legion through the years. 

In it's current form, we've got a clean ui, nicer graphics, and no need to deal with the different bot hosts and all the garbage that comes along with bots and their specific rules. There's an official forum, three game modes (four if you count practice against bots), integrated player profiles, and a few other bells and whistles that none of us had in the original version. 

Fine. Great. I've put quite a few hours into it, and am one of the highest leveled people in the game at the moment. Unfortunately, there's some other issues going on with this standalone version. I'll leave it to you to review and decide what kind of tower defense gamer you are... 

1 - Lag issues.
Update: 6/19/18 - The lag issues have been resolved for the most part.

2 - Tutorials. There is an overall lack of communication for new players that have zero experience with WC3 / Legion. When you pick up this game, you'll be required to play against bots for a bit, and the mastermind (we'll get to that later) mode will be locked to you. Sadly, you do not get a primer on why armor and attack types are important. There is documentation on the forum about all the units and their attack and armor types, but you need to find it. You need to have a basic understanding of the old system. Blah blah blah. They've implemented a spell system that grants you one major bonus after level ten. There isn't much documentation on that, and you'll have to visit the forums for what little is there. 

This lack of in-game tutorials has resulted in a lot of players just parroting things that they saw someone win with once and spamming units senselessly. They don't understand why going aggressive against certain units on wave X is bad because they've seen wins on X wave many times, and they're just going to keep parroting. As it is a team game, your rating will suffer from many matchups with someone just parroting what they saw someone else do... 

3 - Legion types (builders). You get in game and see three builders that should be pretty familiar if you've played earlier versions. There's also a fourth called mastermind. This should also be familiar if you've played versions that scramble the units from other builders. You get several units offered from the other three builders. You keep six and start playing. 

Fine. Good. However, this is the preferred builder by the elite. The developers have taken note that the elite prefer this builder and have been tailoring all of their tweaks to units based on numbers they're crunching from mastermind games. Surprise! This has made the other three regular builders virtually unplayable. In fact, the game gives you bonuses for choosing the mastermind builder, but nothing for choosing a regular builder. So if you do have a soft spot for say... elemental... expect future tweaks to your units to be a reflection of what mastermind players have been doing to one or two of your units. See where this is going? Good. Let's move on.

4 - The MOBA Mentality. This is a team TD. It should be a pretty casual experience to waste some hours on after a long day. Something that anybody of any age should be able to pick up, and eventually master after education (I covered that already) and experience. Unfortunately, I'm regularly reduced to a raging crazylady cussing out kids before, during, and after games. Here's why... 

One of the devs did some work for a very well known MOBA that I will not bother to mention. It shows in the rating system itself. It shows in how the devs are tweaking matchmaking, units, etc. It shows in the community. It shows in members of the community making smurfs. (Yes. Smurfs. For a TD. Let that sink in.) It shows in the rampant racism, sexism, and general bad mouthing in chat. It shows when there's so many streamers for a TD. (Most of them appear to be Alex P. Keaton cosplays with a German accent.) I can go on and on, about the MOBA mentality here, but you should get the idea by now.

Summary: It's ok now. It might soothe a hankering for a team TD for awhile. It could be great eventually. It needs to diversify it's builders and stop the MOBA mindset to reach a broader audience.

Legion TD2 is a strategic Tower Defense(TD) game with a solid core of active players.
Personaly; the community is a recommendation on his own!

Game: currently Legion TD2 is in a 2v2 competitive playstyle wich makes it possible to play/farm/have fun with ur friend(s) in a 2v2 setup, you fight ur way to waves of enemy's and decide when to send ur creatures to ur opponents - with the main objective to kill their king in order to win the game.

Graphix: the ambiance is lovely, it's not a graphix based game but the details in the environment are amazing and a cherry on top of this (delicious) pie.

Balance: balancing the game (faction/unit strengts) is a important part of the game and the creators doing a great job on that, there is no worrie in playing a unbalanced game, becasue of the weekly updates/hotfixes i assure you this is on point.

Why to play: if you like strategic/towerdefense/30mins/great community/reagular updates/competitive playstyle/no game is the same - games, this is the game you need!
i've been playing this game over 350 hours and expect to put in way more!
playing solo or 2v2 (upcomming 4v4) with friends makes this a nice to have in ur steam library.

Feel free to ask questions in the comments, would love to help out.

Legion TD 2 is standalone game which was inspired by WC3 map. This custom map was created the same developers. So I hoped, they just make it better and more fun. But, the custom map and the game has a lot of differences.

The game starts with 2 teams. Each team has 2-4 players. Each player defends his road. He must summon towers. Then new wave start, towers become units and fight with enemies. If all your units dies, enemy units go to the king and attack him If the king dies - the game is over. Seems simple. 

It plays simple too. The game doesn't require a lot of actions from the player. Just place 1-2 tower between waves and watch how your units fight. The game is extremely repetitive. Each game you have the same map and stand against same enemy waves. The only difference is your race. Each race has an unique set of towers. But, Legion TD has only 4 builders, then original map had more than 10 builders.. tt


https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1369324786

Pros
- I think it's a first game in my review list where I can't find pros

Cons
- There are less content than in original map. Only 4 builders, 20 enemy waves

Fun in concept, but the games snowball hard. e.g., if you defend imperfectly, some minions get through and you lose gold income. Which means you can't defend as well next wave, leading to more loss of income, and so it continues. It's made worse that you also have to hire workers to collect a rare resource. This resource is used to increase your income even more via mercenaries.

Which just amplifies the snowballing. You fall behind on workers, which makes you fall even more behind on income and become even less able to defend. I'm not really fond of these sorts of mechanics.

If you liked Legion TD1, this is not for you.  The UI is garbage(super small and laggy) and the game has microtransactions.  I did not even know how to send creep waves until I watched a stream.  They have an option scale the UI, but it scales EVERYTHING on the UI, not just the things that need to be blown up.  The text and small little buff/type icons that you would have to roll over to see what they are miniscule and 9pt translucent font.  Utterly confusing, even for a longtime Legion TD player. 

 The 20 dollar asking price is steep for the value and replayability.  Game has 200 concurrent players on it's major popular day on being on the front page of steam as of right now.  It is dead.  150% population drop since release.  

The game is shady as well, with a very steep asking price, and having "sales" that slash the price once in a while.  This game is literally the price of the Full Skyrim Special Edition(20 dollars) or Dying light EE(23 dollars).  Is it worth more than those games?  The optomization is poor and not as much effort went into this game than into games other games of the same asking price.

I will be asking for a refund.

Talking about the value is of the game is something people should do more often.  We are here for the game, not to feel sorry for small developing teams.  Simpy put, the game did not deliver and pales in comparison to the original in WC3, TFT,and Dota 2.

"Hey friends, let's play this game! It will be a rework of the old TD and such games are fun to play. And the best thing, we can play this together, 4 players in 1 team! Yeah!"

And now they removed the 4 vs 4 gameplay, to make the matchmaking "better". Or better said: to get a "fairer" ranked +/- value. But even now they are more then often unfair (example: +8 if you win, - 18 if you lose). Why don't they just use a strict number like +16/-16 to handle that problem?
Ofc this problem might don't hit you, if you search alone. But I'm telling you something:
Me and my friends bought this ONLY because we could play this together as a team with 4! But no, now it's 2 vs. 2.
So, if you are a lonely singleplayer, go ahead and have fun (to lose if your teammate is shit).

They say, they want to change it "someday" to 4 vs 4 again, but until then, I highly won't play this anymore.

For the rest like balancing etc: they are working on it in like weekly patches. And that's definitely a good point!

But don't get me wrong!
I really like this game and it has potential, but it really really upset me and my friends. As long as it keeps beeing 2 vs 2, it won't be a game for me. Sorry.

So..the game is in alpha phase..so you can not compare the game here with the Warcraft 3 Map. The two games are the same in the basic kit, but in the execution very different. That means nothing bad but nothing good. The first games were a bit strange, as I know the Warcraft 3 map, but it was not bad and interesting to try and experiment with many builds, especially as there is a mastermind race that allows you to select random units from all races. You spend a good time perfecting your build in certain situations and what kind of creeps you can send in order to overpower the opposing lane. Tactical approach and team play are a must.
The problem is rather that your team members are not listening or leave...in a 4v4, which makes it difficult to win or unnecessarily lengthen the game.

I've spent almost 100 hours in the game and can only say in a nutshell that the game is far from perfect, but the excuse is simply ALPHA-PHASE.

Whoever has patience with the development of the game will know how much content we will expect when looking at the Warcraft 3 versions.

I hope I could help you guys a bit.

Legion TD2 is a great kind of competitive strategy game and so far, the community seems pretty nice for a competitive game.
And even though you can enjoy this game by yourself, it is, as most games, a lot more fun with nice team mates. They seem quite easy to find, though.

Since there is not really any mechanical skill required for any action, this game might appeal especially to players who like competitive pvp games without the stress of reaction or APM-based mechanics. 

What keeps this game fresh is instead the variety of different possible builds (which will only increase with future updates) and the ever changing team mates and enemies that get overwhelmed at different times, giving you different amounts of gold you have to work with every game.

So while you can follow certain builds that you can find online, as you could copy decks from pro players in card games, to get the most out of your opportunities every single game, you have to change and adjust your build every single game, granting even long-term fun.

It might not be the best game out there, but the only competitive stand-alone tower defense game that goes this deep into strategy, unit combos and teamplay that I know of.

Worth it's 20$ price tag.

But i do agree to the fact that the game might be overpriced, but I gladly give my money to these two(!) devs who earlier gave me alot of fun in the wc3 mod - for free. I bought this game on the 25% off sale and i believe that this is a more reasonable price for the game.

Something i really want, is a way to vote for draw if one player leaves. Some communities in the wc3 mods has this options. If 5 ppl vote for draw no one gets elo. Or atleast make so that the team who looses a player early do not loose elo.

Took the concept of the original Legion TD from Warcraft 3 and made it trash. All the magic that LTD Mega, Hellhalt TD and the original LTD had? Its not here at all. What the creators did was take a good game and make a terrible sequel to it trying to get nostalgic fanboys to buy the game.

Don't. If I had any other game to compare this sequel to, its not even Legion TD. Its a worse version of Squadron TD from Starcraft 2 except that Starcraft 2, a game made in 2010 has better graphics and gameplay. 

Pros: Just one - Its almost exactly the same as LTD. If you make the graphics worse, simplify the gameplay by 1000x and implement a shitty "meta". What in the fuck. Units are specifically designed to be worse or better than others. E.G protons, which are the supposed starter unit you should build as elemental but are so pathetically weak that even bots don't build them. 

Cons: Stupid fucking meta, terrible graphics, simplified gameplay,  connected lanes instead of parallel ones, boring and slow gameplay, the fact that you get like 10 exp from each game and need 200 to level up, having to figure out literally everything by yourself, not being able to control the fucking king, which is controlled by AI and just does fuck all. Uses abilities too early, doesn't use abilities, attacks targets with full hp instead of killing the low hp targets first. What the fuck? GARBAGE MOTHERFUCKING AI THAT DOESN'T FOCUS TARGETS AND JUST SPREADS IT SO ALL THE ENEMIES ARE LEFT WITH 10 HP BUT STILL ALIVE HOLY SHIT!! Ridiculous scaling where enemies are easily beaten one round and the next round mauls your entire defense while only losing one of their number.. Bosses being literally impossible to beat unless you get lucky as fuck, enemies stacking on top of each other so they just hide underneath a tank while they attack you and you can't touch them because of the hitbox...

There's a ridiculous amount of stupid issues and problems. Please don't fucking buy this. Instead, buy a good game like Warcraft 3 and play the original Legion TD and thousands of other custom games instead of this sad excuse for a money grabbing sequel. Fuckin hell.

Ive been playing warcraft 3 and the gmes that have spawned from its glorious custom matches for as long as i can remember. My step-dad introduced me to it when i was just 4 years old a year or so after the Frozen Throne expansion dropped. I treasure the many hours I spent on LegionTD 1, Island Defense, Dota 1, Dark Invasion, and countless other custom games. 

Therefore, when i saw that the developers were making a LegionTD 2, I was estatic. The very next paycheck i got, i immedietly threw 20 dollars at the game. I didnt, and still wouldnt care if the devs abandoned the project and just used it as a money grab, their hard work in makingthe previous Title LegionTD 1, and the hundreds of hours i spent on it is more than enough for me. 

That being said, it doesnt look like thats the case, with regular updated, constructive contact with the community, and a gameplay that is a unique blend of RTS, MOBA, TD, and potentially E-Sport. I dont know how else to put it other than this game is fantasticm and it seems to have a great chance of leaving early access succesfully and becoming a game enjoyed by many.

TL;DR I wholeheartedly reccomend this game to anyone who enjoys TD, and especially to anyone who had the oppourtunity to play Dota 1, Legion TD 1, and Island Defense.

Play the Starcraft version or DotA version. What this game proves is that just because you're able to create a fantastic custom game within another game, does not mean that you're ready to make your own standalone version.

I value games by 'fun factor', less content.

While the price may be steep,  and I would recommend and even buy this game for my friends if it was $5-10,  I still find it's worth the price.

MP only games are in a weird spot where they may lack a story driven experience,  this game WILL provide me with many hours of fun.   I don't know how many hours i dumped on Legion TD and other TD maps across WC3 and SC:BW, but that alone was enough to make me give this game a shot.

Active balancing, ELO system could use some work,  A lot of people will say this game has a toxic community,  while I've only peaked at 1332 rating,  I do find people get more "passionate" as the games get higher,  but like most games,  It's very easy to ignore people.

AI is decent,  I was able to acclimate to this new game and develop strategies without feeling they were too easy or I was getting carried,  dev's even say the AI is better than the majority of the player base.

If you really like Legion TD for WC3 this game is 100% worth,  if you just want a decent TD game, there's probably cheaper options.

After 100+ hours of testing, here is my review:
Toxic community, like LoL or CoD. The global chat is full off hate, racism etc. and there are no moderators/scripts to stop them. It¬¥s an early access title for 20‚Ç¨, but at this state, the game is insanely overpriced. There are 4 different playable races in Legion TD 2, which is kinda underwhelming if you compare the game to the famous Starcraft and Warcraft funmaps. The game has many balance issues and bugs, especially unit behaviour and pathing issues. Legion TD 2¬¥s Matchmaking is a bloody mess, which endores you to play in a 2-4 stack party in game where the "tactical" possibilities are: when to save, when to send, when to value, what to send and cross or else you will have a bad time. It¬¥s kinda funny, that the developers think this game would be competitive material when top players spam their builts (exept Mastermind) every game with very little variation and team up with "low elo smurf" players to match weaker teams. Another problem of the game is the wave + mercenaries pathing issue. When you send the same mercenaries 5 times on the same wave against the exact same building order, you will have 5 diffrent outcomes, which kills every "competitive" possibility.

Legion TD 2 is a copy of the WC and SC funmaps in now standalone game. It¬¥s insanely overpriced even for this 2-man studio. Get it on sale or leave it unless you¬¥re a big TD fan.

brings you back to the good old days playing WC3 with ur mates on LAN or multiplayer but with a ranking system which kinda makes u rage when u lose and hurray when you win, the community ive met so far is generally great, they listen for the most and its actually a very very strategical td. lost like first 5 games, was complete shit had no idea what i was doing (i was still kinda good at legion TD on WC3) after losing 5 games we pulled a win at wave 10 and really got into what we needed to do so we won a couple of games, got the rank back up lost 5 games, saw new strategies played them started winning again and this is like within a 50 rating bracket... Great community highly addictive game which at first view u might think will be incredibly repetitive since its not far into development with low amount of races but the NOSTALGIA is incredible. cant stress how nice this community is in general and they actually listen to u since if 1 person fucks up here u kinda lose the game
Love it <3

So, Legion TD 2.

I played the original custom Warcraft 3 mod which this Legion is based on and really enjoyed that. I was pretty hyped about this game for months, finally bought it few days ago. This standalone version looks very promising, considering it is still just Early Access Alpha. Graphics are fine, though I hope the map will be more detailed and changed over time. Gameplay is smooth, you don't need high-end computer to run this on Ultra details. I am running it on a GTX 950 and i5-4460 with 16 gigs of RAM on Ultra with stable 60fps.

There are currently 4 legions you can play for + one called Mastermind which randomly combines units from each of those legions. Devs are currently working on 5th legion, I hope there will be more legions to choose from in time.

But I have to say that I am a little bit disappointed in the whole elo distribution and frustration that comes from constant losing. Out of about 20 games I played, I won only 2 games. You might tell yourself - wow, you must suck balls dude. No. I am not a pro player in this, but the frustrating part is - it is a 4v4 game and even if you work really hard, have no wave leaks and do a good job, if your teammates fuck it up, you still lose. And honestly, I get as unlucky as I possibly can, because most of the time I just lose. It can get very frustrating. I just hope there will be added some 1v1 / 2v2 mode to make it more fair. Because honestly, when you solo queue 4v4, you either get premade against you or team that doesnt even properly communicate or sucks balls. 

Looks like there will be a shop added soon and various rewards for currency you have in game (Essence), so I am pretty much looking forward to that.

With everything that I have mentioned above, I still do recommend buying this game if you are a fan of Tower Defense games, or played the original WC3 Legion TD. Even if you have no experience in TD games, I still recommend it. This game can be both frustrating & addicting at same time. I'm looking forward for what this game yet has to offer and I hope the losing streaks end very soon. I'd give it 8,5/10.

I have played this game since I was like, 15-16 years old, and it is still one of my favorite TD games!

Sadly I can't recommend this game for solo players like me.

Reason: the game does not have separated queues for solo players and premade groups.

As obviously a premade group of 4 with teamspeak/discord is superior to a group of 4 randoms, there is a point in the game where you are forced to either join a group and find people to play with or get constantly buttf*cked by groups while desperately trying to communicate with the randoms in your team.

I get that seperate queues mean longer waiting times due to overall low player count. But that's ok. I'd rather wait 5-10 minutes for a fair game than wait 1 minute and get in a team that I can't communicate with (language barrier) while the other team is ra.ping us.

Other than that the game in general is fun and it's propably going to be a worth successor in a couple of patches...

Was in the closed alpha - can honestly say ignore the majority of the negative reviews. There was a lot of interest, so the login servers struggled the first day - all is fine now. Devs are great, really responsive, listen to the community, and push out updates often.

If you ever wanted a competitive tower defense game where you get to play against other folks - this is the game for you! The game is simple to start off but has a lot of depth that takes quite a few plays to really start to get a feel for. Worth the time!

The player base is really active and pretty nice. I've never waited more than 30s for a game.

$20 may be a high price tag for some, but if you like this sort of game, and understand early access, it's worth it. I've easily paid more for a game that I've played and enjoyed less. The meta is constantly shifting due to people figuring out new stuf and frequent patches. If you're generally hestiate about early access stuff, you may want to wait till they have more available but as a whole I've picked playing this over a lot of the newer games recently.

Although this game has a lot of room for improvement it is already really fun to play. A lot of features are still missing like actual options for your custom games and other game modes (I really want to see HELL from W3!), but overall this game is heading in the right direction. If you are patient enough and like this type of games then go and buy it, but keep in mind that this game is made by only 2 people, as passionate as they are, I don't think the development will be really that fast.

I know how to play legion TD2 cause i played a long time ago on SC2 so you can remove the "learning the game" out of my experience with legion TD2

You'll play one game and discover the towers, the minions. After 10 games you'll understand which tower is more OP than the other, same for minion. Then you'll learn to send exactly when it's best.

After you've learned all that, well that's it, the games are all gonna be very similar. But the time you get to that level, if you're a total new to this game, ~15 hours will have passed.

Lemme make a list.
The good:
+ Lots of tactical depth.
+ Has a practice mode where you play vs bots.
+ Also custom game lobbies for practice.
+ Lots of beginner guides on the forums.
+ Very active developers, around 1 new Update every other day at the moment.
+ Very competetive game with leaderboards.
+ Lots of active players, more than 10,000 individual players every day.
+ 4 Races with individual strengths and weaknesses to choose from, plus 1 random race.

The bad:
- Interface not very intuitive, many windows only available through chat commands.
- Games are somewhat RNG reliant, hope this will get fixed at some point by making pathing and unit focusing more consistent.
- If a player disconnects a bot takes over, this is fine for now but I hope they'll implement a more elegant solution in the future (for example if someone disconnects before wave 2 the game will be cancelled).
- Very hard for new players, even though you get all those practice opportunities a tutorial of some sorts would be appreciated.
- Matchmaking is ok for now but could use some improvements. Even though I'm somewhat high elo I constantly get matched with 1200 elo players who have no idea what they're doing. Though this will probably fix itself once even more players start playing the game.
- Features like the cosmetic shop not implemented yet, only 4 races as of right now, buit the base game is definitely there and ready to be expanded on.

Conclusion:
Over all the game is 100% strategy, knowledge and prediction what the enemy will do, it doesn't require a good internet connection nor your constant attention which makes it the perfect game for me and my 2mbits connection to play while also watching some youtube/twitch on the side.
Definitely a recommendation from me.

Skip the wall of text for TL;DR it's just a little backstory as to why I love this game so much.

I have always had a soft spot for tower defense games. Growing up I would play a multitude of TD style flash games and enjoy them greatly for a short time. Later in my gaming career I would play TD mods in vanilla Starcraft 2 like Desert strike or redstone TD. Those got a lot more play from me than the flash games but I'm sure I didn't break 30 hours in either of them and I quickly entered my cringey MOBA phase after that. After I burned out on League of Legumes and built a computer that could run DOTA 2 I dove into that. Sadly Valve took ages to implement the ever important arcade, after all the game started out as a simple Warcraft 3 mod. Well not that simple. Anyway after some Epic Boss Fight and Overthrow I saw Wagamama playing Legion TD on stream and from that point on I was enthralled. I trudged through 5 minute queues just to roll dice on if all 8 people would stay and play favorite tower defense game of all time. Even with just 3 builders I throughly enjoyed Legion TD for probably about 50 hours. It was something that was on and off and it was really difficult to find others to play with. I also favorited it more when my latency was awful. Sadly I didn't see the Kickstarter campaign until it had completed successfully so all I could do was add the steam title to my wishlist and bide my time. Darkness crept into my world and the one TD to rule them all became forgotten. Until I see the Early Access game get a release date. The only reason this game is rated average is all the negative reviews people left in the first 2 days when the game was unplayable. I was able to play 1 game during that time and it got my so excited for when the servers were stable.

TL;DR The best Tower Defense game I have ever played. Cannot be mastered by just learning a rigid build or figuring out the meta. The meta is ever changing and the gameplay is dynamic because of the competitive atmosphere. AutoAttack Games put their heart and soul into this game and it really shows. If you would like a Tower Defense game that does not get old then this is the game for you. Well worth the $20 pricetag and I'm so happy to support the developers.
Get it. Play it with friends.
best TD game ever.I highly recommend it.

This is my first time with this kind of TD (so I can't compare to WC3/SC2/DOTA2), and I have to say, I'm in love. 

For those like me who are new to the genre, here's an overview:

Legion TD2 is a "competitive tower defense" game. 2 teams of 4 fight against identical waves, defending their team's King from creeps. The game is split into two phases, night and day. During the night, you place, upgrade, and sell towers, and hire mercenaries. During the day, your towers wake up to defend various waves of creeps (sent by the game) and mercenaries (sent by your opponents). 

Currently there are 4 races (or legions), and one legion using random units from each other legion. It appears the devs are planning on adding more races, cosmetics, and mod support. However, the dev team is only 2 people, so I would expect mostly bugfixes and balancing to come before new features.

Currently, I would be catious about recommending the game.  It's fun, but $20 is pretty steep for what is currently a glorified mod. Keep your eye on it. Any sale above 25% off should be an insta-buy, and maybe in half a year, once more features are added, it'll be a must have. Or, if you've played counltess hours of WC3 Legion TD (as it seems many have), you shoudl grab it to support the devs.

edit: Being a new player, I was very skeptical of jumping straight into multiplayer, bu the community is really helpful. Even though most players are from Germany, many speak good enough english to help if you have any questions.  Streamers, as few as they are, are also very helpful, and were invaluable for helping me learn the game.  This is probably the most friendly and helpful community I've ever seen. Unfortunately, it's the only real way to learn the game, as there is no tutorial, and very few good videos that cover anything beyond the basics.

edit2: Ratings have been enabled, as have achievements, etc. Still only PVP, no custom games or v bots. In addition, there is no unranked PVP. I still recommend this game, been having a great time.

Finally we have Legion TD 2 which I waited a long time on. Apart from not being able to play against AI for now, this game is really fun and is worthy of the classics name. 

This game is all about perfecting your build, only to see that a few extra sends can topple it once again and you will have to rethink your strategy. What is set in stone can be crushed by better strategy and planning.
This leads to outcome of the game being decided by the teams capability and decision making.

For instance there was a game we lost on round 6 with all lanes not leaking before, just because the enemy decided to hold back on sends and add all of it on 6, resulting in a complete spillage, the yet weak king could not hold. Of course, this was a do or die scenario, as the enemy was really weak on income thus far, and would not have been able to hold anything afterwards.

You will have to wait in queue a bit for now, as of course they still have to build up their Server pool to be able to take a few thousand players, but im confident that they will manage in the long run.

I don't believe starting server issues are a objective cause for a bad review, if the game itself delivers and it does.

As someone who never played Legion TD, but is very familiar with Nexus Wars on StarCraft 2, the core loop feels very fresh and enjoyable -- the moment to moment gameplay is great and always makes you want to learn more, expirement and get better. 

Unfortunately Legion TD 2 had a rocky launch, but it feels better today (11/26/2017) and the disconnects are few and far between and the lag is almost non-existent. 

Now, I firmly believe the developers explanation for the rocky launch and I do believe they'll fix it.This is a great surprise and a game I had no idea existed -- but now it's looking like my next "main game".

Here's a quick look showcasing a full match so you can see how it plays moment to moment.

https://youtu.be/rboZficsr_Y

Introduction:

This is a team based (4v4) competitive Tower Defence game in which you build towers against waves increasing difficult mobs. The twist of Legion TD is that at the end of the game you send your towers (they are actually living creatures not a stone tower in the literal sense) against the enemy team's towers in a showdown. And hence the difficulty lies in you have plan not only for the waves of mobs, but towards the enemy team as well. 

At higher levels of gameplay I can definately forsee build orders like Starcraft 2. There can also be pocket strategies in which one particular player does not build towers but focus on generating income through mining. So therefore I believe this game is complex enough to develop a competitive scene. 
 
(I admit I have only seen these advanced strategies in Legion TD 1/Warcraft 3, but the selling point of Legion TD 2 is its authenticity to LTD1/War3.)

The good: 

1) Plays exactly like Legion TD custom map on Warcraft III /Starcraft II. If you liked that you will like this. No controversial/unpopular mechanics changes so far. 

2) No Lootboxes (for now). Very rare these days.  

The bad:

1) I cannot imagine what their server infrastructure is like.  This game on launch has experienced server capacity issues on the levels of Diablo 3 and Simcity 2013. No one can ever login because they are stuck at the log in screen and if you do miraculously login, you can't play a game because your username is NULL as you cannot connect to the server that holds your username as well.  

I bought this on launch 20 November 2017 and found myself having connection issues. That's fine. I waited a few days and came back 23 November and it is still experiencing connections issues.

This is raising serious issues for the game's longevity. This sort of multiplayer only game need a large player base to sustain matchmaking of various skill levels, and I would hazard a guess a significant portion of the population has already refunded the game due to the game LITERALLY UNPLAYABLE. 

At this rate I wonder what is your server infrastucture is like. Is it a Pentium 4 3.0 Ghz powered by a hamster wheel?

TL;DR; This game is great recreation of a fan-favorite WC3 mod and the dev team is quick to respond and takes the community seriously.

Please do not be dissuaded by the negative reviews (none of which this game or its dev team deserves). Every negative review here (and I've read most of them) is written by someone who is impatient and does not understand game development at all - let alone what early access means. Early access is a way to greatly include the community in the development process and help the (2 man) development team to iterate on an already solid game *before it is fully released*. It also is a time for them to work out infrastructure issues - which we are currently experiencing. If you can't be patient with an early access game that is being actively developed then you should not purchase it and leave nasty, uneducated reviews. If that is you, just be patient and wait until the game is fully released to review it.

I am personally impressed that this game is made by a 2 man team and I'm not surprised they're having infrastructure problems. At the time I'm writing this it can take up to 5 minutes just to get into the lobby server. This is frustrating enough on it's own but to make things worse you reenter the lobby queue every time you finish a game. From my understanding this is only a temporary solution while they prop up more servers to handle the load which was 20x more than they anticipated at launch (so cut them some slack). I do appreciate their responsiveness to the community and, although this is a headache, I will gladly be patient while they work out the kinks. They've done a great job recreating and improving on the original WC3 mod and I am in no way dissapointed. I'd like to see improved lobby/menu UI which feels a little amatuer at the moment but that, again, is totally understandable as a 2 man team. I think this game has the potential to be a huge success and I'm happy to help support them. Can I donate more money to help?
Amazing game!

First of all, I like this game pretty much. I never played it back in Wacraft III (or atleast I can't remember to have specifically played this game). However, I like it the way it is today.

BUT let me warn you:
The game is still in EARLY ACCESS, that means:
The server are still not able to endure the sheer amount of players who try to login. Depending on the time of the day you have login times ranging from some seconds up to umpteen minutes. And that's just the login time for the lobby server. Right after that you can find a game pretty easily, IF you want to play alone, that is. If you want to try to play with one or more friends together, it gets even trickier. You don't always have a friendlist and can't invite your mates. Suddenly you are in a party with some random people, and when they start their queue you will be queued too!
Then, when you finished your game, you're right back in the login queue to get back to the lobby server, even to see your statistics. If you're unlucky you are unable to queue again (especially when trying with multiple people).

BUT when you get all that to work and bring the time or enough other stuff to do whilst in queue times, then this game is pure bliss. Especially for a mathematic driven person like me. You don't really need much skill or fast mouse movements to master this game, all you need is a really good game knowledge, the ability to use that knowledge, to adapt to your enemies and maybe some decent team mates (it's hard to win when one of your teammates goes afk wave 1). Even tho the players will be replaced by bots when leaving the game entirely. And they still have the ability to reconnect into the game later on.

I really can recommend the game itself, even tho the server stability is definitely not given yet.
Thanks for reading my review.

If you manage to get into the game it is amazing.

The game launched 2 days prior to me writing this review. I haven't been able to play due to severe server issues. Why these issues you might wonder:

Well, because the devs expected only 400 to maybe 600 people to play the game in the first few days. The amount of unique logins have reached 25k+ until now, only 49 hours after release. 25000. They prepared effectively for 500.

But since the game was released, they were trying their best to fix the servers, so that evens it out and I am not going to let that affect my early point of view of the game.

To the game itself:

Even though it might seem like a Tower Defense game where you have that one most effective strategy and certain most effective units (which would be expected, since the generated "waves" attacking your "towers" each wave are the same), this is not at all the case. Each game differs a little bit, due to the enemies being able to send mercenaries on your lane to attack your towers alongside the preset wave. And these little differences affect your game in a way that is crucial and changes your every game you play.

Graphics:
Simple. Nothing special, animations feel a bit off and "clumsy" at times. Especially when it comes to high attack speeds, the animations of certain units do not work very well. But overall, it can be looked at and doesn't cause your eyes to get cancer. 6/10.

Interface:
Simple, intuitive and it seems like thought was put into it. You can basically ping everything you see and make all important announcements to your team by pinging. Nothing I could think of to improve the UI, except for the design. The functionality is definetly on point, which is the most important aspect of the UI for a game like this. 9.5/10.

Gameplay:
Oh, Boy.
As mentioned in the short opening section, it is more unique than you might expect of your average tower defense game and fits perfectly for competetive play. You can do complex tactics, but also very simple ones that are effective for beginners. The towers and attacking monsters feature different attack and defense types and also different abilities. This game, like many other competetive games, have a steep learning curve and here, intelligent and strategic thinking is the key to success, not reaction time or quick thinking (although you need to be quick in order to not miss waves, so you cant just take all the time in the world to think of the best available tactic). You also need to observe the way the enemy builds his lane, so you can attack adjusted to his units. Due to the lack of action which one might lead to playing even more, 9/10.

Overall impression would land on a solid 8/10. Might get better with time and server fixes.
Wait until the servers are fixed before you buy the game, though.

I can't recommend it in the current format because it isn't a working product, but I suspect with slightly more realistic pricing and stable servers this will quite quickly become a big success.

I spent countless hours playing Legion TD during my WC3 days. My 3 go-to games were Island Troll Tribes, Island Defense and Legion TD. Of course, I spent thousands of hours playing these and the many other WC3 custom games, but this was truly a gem in the TD options. I wanted to buy it now because I fully support these developers in their efforts, and would love to see the game further developed to a point where they're proud to send it out as a full release.

In regards to their comment about possibly going free-to-play if players wanted it, I am perfectly fine with paying $20 for the game, but it would be disheartening if additional groups were added as DLC's. I would love to see any new content added as something that is free, or at the very least least freely obtainable with the option to purchase it if you just can't wait that long to earn it to try it. It seems like a popular thing with games now; shovel out loads paid DLC's for small additions to the game. But this is a horrible practice that has a massively negative view by players. I hope this doesn't become one of those.

I'm currently downloading the game as I'm writing this review, but I'm not expecting to be able to play and have a good experience on the day it launches. In my experience, many games have a rough launch date, but more often than not, it smooths out in a few days. It's great to see how many people are interested in playing, and I can't wait to get in and start playing too. I personally am going to save myself from a potential headache and wait a few days to better appreciate the game when it's more stable.

In order to post my review, I had to launch the game for at least 5 minutes. I was able to select my username and go to the lobby without any issue, but as expected, I was unable to connect to a game unfortunately. I was able to search for a game, was placed in a lobby with other players, found a server, and was connecting to the server. The game appeared to have started, but it never let me connect. Eventually it said I was disconnected, and then tried to reconnect again when it said I abandoned a game in progress. It disconnected me again, and the game closed. Based on the lobby, I was grouped with 3 Chinese players, and we were against 4 German players... so... there are probably 3 Chinese kids mad about my inability to connect to the game right now. As expected, there are server connection issues, but hopefully these will smooth out as time goes by. In other news, I'm glad that it supports my 2560x1080 resolution, and it looks great!

This game was one of the best alpha games I've ever experienced. I was lucky enough to be a part of the project from an early state, and had the pleasure of watching it grow immensely over the past few months. Always, the game would be patched with new features, balance changes, etc and it felt awesome. 

Please don't listen to the negative reviews demanding perfect servers. This is a 2 man team for a game in early access, it's going to have some kinks that WILL be worked out. The game itself is what should be judged, and if you can't access it right this second, wait to make a decision about it until you can. 

The gameplay is awesome, the mechanics feel nice and improved over the modded/custom map experience version.

Basically, this game is League of Legends back when Dota was just a WC3 map. It has a vast potential, and you will definitely regret shunning the game and not giving it a chance before actually taking the time to invest in the gameplay.

Hello there,
I have been testing this game in alpha. The game is awesome it can be played casualy but there is also a ladder for Competetive players.  
I dont wanna waster you time, so go and buy this game, because (trust me) you need it.

After playing 500 hours of this game during the Alpha, I can honestly say that i had a lot of fun. 
As someone who likes really competitive games with a good sense of skill scalling, Legion TD 2 gives you that great feeling of when you survive with 1% HP and you know that everything you do can and will have a big impact on the outcome of the game.
With that said, you also have a huge range of things that you can do every round, and that's what makes every game you play different from one another.
I would totally recommend anyone who has ever played any kind of tower defense. If you didn't, don't be shy and try it out, the community is great and everyone is welcoming, including the devs!
